PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT (HOUSING LOAN INTEREST) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Haines) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced:
A Bill for an Act to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to provide a rebate on housing loan interest.
Motion (by Senator Haines) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HAINES
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will enable people who are buying the house that they live in to get some tax relief on their home loan repayments. The Hawke Labor Government and the Liberal and National Party Coalition, give favoured tax treatment to people buying investment properties. In this Bill, the Australian Democrats will give much needed tax relief to Australians who are struggling to pay off the homes in which they live.

As I introduce this Bill, interest rates are high and rising. I am sure that in the future interest rates will fall, but nobody knows when. Maybe this will coincide with an election. Yet all Australians must realise now that in a deregulated financial system, interest rates can rise at any time and when interest rates on housing loans rise, many Australians suffer.

Those who have recently taken out mortgages find it difficult to meet the increased repayments. Some lose their homes. People who are about to purchase a home have to think again because they do not know whether they will be able to afford the increased repayments. Without doubt, deregulation has made it more difficult for many Australians to buy a home to live in. The same cannot be said for property investors who are encouraged to buy many homes with special tax concessions.

The Government has taken some action to reduce the pressure that foreign investors were putting on home prices in Australia. However, it was little action, very late. Following this action, foreign investors can and do buy property for development.

There seems to be something very wrong with this Government's housing priorities. Foreign investors can still push up home prices. Australian investors who already own a home and buy another one, two or three houses as investments, are allowed to claim the interest they pay on their home loans as a tax deduction. If they are making a loss on renting out their investment properties, they are allowed to deduct that loss against taxable income from other sources. The Hawke Government, with the support of the Liberal and National Party Coalition, reintroduced this mechanism of negative gearing to subsidise at the taxpayers' expense, the losses deliberately incurred by property investors. They are prepared to give a tax incentive to people who are not living in the houses they are buying.

It is sad indeed that the property investor can afford to pay more for a property than the person who is buying a home to occupy. It means that investors can outbid potential owner occupiers at an auction. This is the result of giving all the tax breaks to the property investor and nothing to the person buying a house in which to live. The property investor gets to deduct the loan repayments and to negatively gear. The owner occupier faces crippling interest rates which are still rising and meet the full home loan repayment with no tax relief.

This Bill, therefore, gives the tax benefit to Australians who are living in the houses they are buying. Australians who are currently finding it very difficult to keep increasing the payments on their housing loans while their real incomes are falling, need this help to stay in their homes. Australians who are contemplating buying a home to live in need this assurance that they will get some tax relief. Otherwise as their mortgage commitments rise, they risk financial hardship and eventually being thrown out of their homes when they can no longer afford to meet their loan repayments.

In essence, this Bill is similar to legislation introduced by the then Treasurer and now Leader of the Opposition, as part of the 1982-83 Budget. In those halcyon pre-deregulation days, he was prepared to deal with the problem of high interest rates making home ownership unaffordable to average Australian income earners.

This Bill will introduce a tax rebate on the interest paid in excess of 10% per annum on the first $80,000 of a housing loan. Those buying the most expensive houses will not abuse the system because the rebate is limited to interest paid on the first $80,000 of a loan. We will also prevent the highest income earners from getting the biggest benefit by applying the same 40% rebate to all owner occupiers with home loans, irrespective of their actual marginal rate of tax.

In Austria, Denmark, the Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Germany, Japan, New Zealand, the U.K. and the U.S.A., there is either full or partial tax allowance for interest on home loans for a principal residence. So this is not an unusual measure. Given the financial problems confronting Australians who have recently bought or who want to buy a home to live in, there is at least as great a need to introduce this legislation now, as there was when it was introduced in 1982.

The cost of this measure will vary as interest rates fluctuate. Obviously if we get home loan interest rates down to 10%, there will be no cost. However, at current interest rates, the costs are likely to be in the vicinity of $200 million.

If my Bill to exempt from tax the first $2,000 of interest earned from savings accounts with financial institutions that lend for housing is passed, then money at 12% or less will become available to institutions that lend for housing. Interest rates on home loans will then drop and the cost of this tax subsidy will be reduced.

Can we afford not to help Australians buy their own home? Can we afford to have more Australians trying to find accommodation in less public housing because they cannot afford to buy a house? Can we afford to sell Australian houses to foreign investors and allow housing to become unaffordable to average Australians? Can the Labor, Liberal and National Parties afford to deny tax relief to people buying a house to live in when they have voted to increase the tax incentives for property investors to buy many houses?
I commend this Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill is an omnibus bill for legislation administered within the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio. Its introduction will facilitate the passage of amendments to existing legislation.
Sugar Agreement Act 1985
The Bill provides for the repeal of the Sugar Agreement Act 1985 with effect from 1 Ju1y 1989.

The Act prohibits the importation of sugar and sugar products as described in the 1984 Commonwealth/Queensland Sugar Agreement. The Agreement is set out in the Schedule to the Act. The Agreement expires on 30 June 1989. This expiry notwithstanding, the Act provides that the import prohibition extends beyond 30 June 1989.

As part of the Government's Economic Statement of 25 May 1988, it was announced that the prohibition on the importation of sugar and sugar products was to be replaced by ad valorem tariffs of 35% and 25% on raw and refined sugar respectively, phasing down to 15 percent in 1992. The initial tariff rates are set to provide a similar level of support as the current import embargo and domestic price arrangements.

The Industry has sought a different form of tariff protection, and the government is considering that approach. In addition, the current domestic administered pricing arrangements will be terminated on the expiry on 30 June 1989 of the current Commonwealth/Queensland Sugar Agreement. The industry is considering the desirability of a future Commonwealth/ Queensland Sugar Agreement. The Government will introduce further legislation to implement such an agreement if necessary.

The revised arrangements for the sugar industry are part of a package of measures based upon the outcome of the recent review of Government programs and policies within the primary industries sector, known as the Industry Development Review.

The Review outcome, which was comprehensive and far reaching, was considered by the Government along with proposals for general industry assistance reductions and proposals for reforming the business taxation structure. This had the advantage of allowing consideration of the important linkages between assistance measures for various sectors as well as their interaction with taxation measures. One of the strengths of the package of measures is that it is not restricted to one or two sectors of the economy. As a result, the outcome should be far more effective than the sum of the individual contributions by each sector.
Repeals of Live-stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Legislation

The introduction on 1 July 1988 of a fee for service charging regime under the Export Control Act 1982, for export slaughter floor meat inspection by the Commonwealth, has obviated the need for the livestock slaughter export inspection charge legislation, which related to a per carcase charge on the slaughter of livestock.
Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977

The first amendment to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act removes the requirement that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy approve orders to be made by the AMLC in relation to the export shipping of meat or livestock. The change is consistent with the Government's policy of deregulating the activities of Statutory Authorities and will permit the implementation of agreements which have been negotiated between the AMLC and shipping companies on a commercial basis.

The second amendment is to vary sub-paragraph 30d (1) (a) (ii) of the Act, pertaining to the time requirements for notification of motions to be put to the Annual General Meeting of the Corporation. This amendment removes an inconsistency in the Act which resulted from amendments made in 1987.
Wool Marketing Act 1987

Wool is Australia's major export earner with exports valued at some $5.8 billion last year. To preserve the competitiveness of wool and its profile as a high quality fibre it is important that we maintain the confidence of buyers in the quality and description of the wool they are purchasing.

An important source of this confidence is the integrity of wool testing procedures. Nearly all wool sold at auction is tested for key characteristics which form the basis for a commercial assessment by buyers. This testing is done by testing houses on the basis of a sample. Buyers also visually appraise the wool for sale on the basis of a sample displayed on the show floor.

Section 127 of the Wool Marketing Act provides for regulations to be made in relation to registration and inspection of sampling sites and registration of wool test houses. An amendment to provide for the inspection of wool test houses is being considered by Parliament in these sittings.

However, there are no provisions for the registration and inspection of wool display areas and sample security areas which are central to the wool selling system. To ensure the integrity of the description of wool and the wool auction system, it is necessary to provide for registration and inspection of these areas.
Provision is also required for the payment of fees in relation to registration and inspection costs.

Regulation-making powers providing for registration and inspection of wool display areas and sample security areas and payment of fees in respect of these, will therefore be inserted in section 127 of the Act.
The proposed amendments in this Bill have no financial implications for the Commonwealth.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to clarify and refine the technical operation of ``grandfathering'' and related provisions in the Broadcasting Act 1942. The relevant provisions were introduced by the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Act 1988.

The Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Act introduced new radio and cross-media ownership and control limits in the Broadcasting Act. Relevant prescribed interests or directorships held before 29 October 1987 were protected, or ``grandfathered'', from the operation of the new media ownership limits. The then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, had announced the Government's intention to introduce these new limits on 28 October 1987.

In addition to these ``retrospective'' grandfathering rules for interests held before the date of announcement, the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Act introduced ``prospective'' grandfathering rules. These rules provide protection where relevant radio, television or cross-media limits are breached because of minor changes in the service areas of commercial radio or television stations or because of changes in Census Count population figures within relevant service areas.

This Bill improves the technical operation of the grandfathering and related provisions introduced by the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Act. A detailed outline of the amendments is provided in the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill.

The amendments are of a minor, technical nature and involve no change in the Government's policy toward the grandfathering of relevant interests. In essence, that policy is to protect legitimate interests acquired before the date of Government announcement or, where they were acquired after that date but only breach relevant ownership and control limits because of minor changes in service area populations.

The Bill will also allow the Minister to delegate his or her powers to make determinations for the purposes of relevant Gazette Notices that are necessary for the enforcement of the new ownership and control limits. These Gazette Notices relate to the populations within defined radio and television service areas as measured by the most recent Census Count results published by the Australian Statistician. The determinations made for the purpose of these Gazettals do not involve the exercise of any real discretionary power and are based purely on objective data. The delegation of these Ministerial determinations to an authorised officer in the Department of Transport and Communications will facilitate a more streamlined process for the updating of existing Gazette Notices.

The Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Act has completed a process of reform of media ownership policies in Australia. The present package of radio, television and cross-media rules in the Broadcasting Act has also complemented the Government's policies for the provision of additional commercial radio and television services, particularly in regional areas. The `fine tuning' amendments in this Bill are designed to ensure that the technical operation of the Ownership and Control Act is more certain and equitable for those persons who have a legitimate claim to protection under the grandfathering rules.
Financial Impact
There will be no additional costs to the Commonwealth in the administration of the provisions in the Bill.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum and commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 March, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems some time ago that I actually spoke to the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Amendment Bill. My colleagues have made some comments about the length of time it has taken me to deal with this, but I would like to put it on the record that it is no fault of mine and I have not been involved in the debates in the intervening period. Opposition senators will be looking very carefully at what progress has been made in sorting out the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission through the passage of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government has assured us again and again that the accord with the unions is central to its economic policy. One of the key elements of the accord is supposed to have been non-wage benefits-the social wage. There is a list of these benefits which are the cornerstone of the accord. Up near the top of the list the Government was to take steps to ensure a safer workplace for Australian workers. To date-as I said in the first part of my speech-the sorry record of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission cannot have been much comfort to the families of the eight people a week killed at work and the 6,000 a week injured.

The Government's failure to implement effectively such a central part of its deal with the Australian Council of Trade Unions indicates real ministerial incompetence. This was a Government priority. Yet the Labor Government-the so-called workers' government-has failed dismally in its promise to the workers of this country and, at the same time, Australian businesses and new enterprises are being strangled by excessive regulation. I move:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate notes that, while the Bill seeks, inter alia, to streamline the administration of the Commission, the Government has failed to implement effective procedures to reduce the burden of excessive regulations on industry.''

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Australian Democrats to support the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Amendment Bill and, hopefully, to make some observations which will contribute constructively to the debate on this very significant issue of occupational health and safety. It is also a very current issue in light of reports that have been tabled in the other place by the relevant Minister which highlight the magnitude of the challenge with which we are confronted in Australia concerning occupational health and safety.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's action in establishing the Commission was laudable. However, as others have observed, the outcome of that Commission to date has been extremely disappointing. In fact, there has been little improvement in Australia's abysmal record on occupational health and safety since the establishment of the Commission. The Bill addresses the fact that the challenge is still great, and that the machinery that was put in place has not yet proved to be effective. Indeed, some of the changes which will be implemented by this amendment Bill presumably are designed specifically to address that problem. Although on the one hand the Government has taken action, albeit it to little effect so far, I point out that, unfortunately, on this issue the Opposition has been, we believe, rather negative. If we look at the history of the Opposition's position, we see that it opposed the establishment of the Commission in 1983; it is now being critical of the Government, which has at least taken major steps towards resolving an extraordinarily serious problem relating to industrial relations and the health and safety of workers.

The Australian Democrats supported the establishment of the Commission. We certainly agree that its output and effect have been disappointing. We agree that it requires fine tuning, which was the expression used by the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) in his second reading speech on the Bill in this place. There is need for attention to be paid to the massive problem of occupational health and safety, and immediately a need to address the inadequacies or ineffectiveness of the Commission that was established to resolve those problems.

As Senator Patterson said, it is now a day and a half since the Senate addressed this problem. Perhaps it is worth taking a few moments to restate the magnitude of the challenge before us. Senator Patterson outlined it in detail in introducing the debate. However, it is worth returning briefly to see the magnitude and the relative size of this challenge to the Australian Government, the Australian people and workers in comparison with our overseas counterparts. The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission was established as a result of the Commission's establishing Act in 1985 with three broad objectives. These were to develop awareness of the problem; to provide a forum directed at resolving the problem; and to give a national focus for activities which would resolve the problem. The Commission consists of 17 members. Its name, in more popular terms, has been Worksafe Australia. It has two operational arms, the National Occupational Health and Safety Office which is responsible for policy and administrative support, and the Institute of Occupational Health and Safety which is responsible for scientific and technical research. The challenge of the Commission was to resolve a problem of enormous relative magnitude.

Australian workers are exposed to great health hazards and occupational danger. The figures previously cited clearly illustrate this. According to figures cited by the Minister, each year in Australia 550 Australians die as a result of work related accidents or illness, with over 300 of those deaths occurring in the workplace itself. The conservative estimate of the Minister was that these injuries and illnesses involve $6 billion of expense per year to the Australian economy and community. The cost of workers compensation alone is in the vicinity of $3,000m per annum. The magnitude of these fatalities and illnesses and the subsequent costs are clearly indicative of the size of the challenge which faces the Commission. The Commission has addressed itself to the challenge but, sadly, the judgments of those who have examined the performance of the Commission are that it has been relatively ineffective.

Recently, Senator Patterson drew our attention to some of the limitations concerning the achievements and effectiveness of the Commission which were cited in the McKay report which was released by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) on 3 March 1988. The report reinforces the continuing magnitude of the problem. The report was critical of most aspects of Worksafe's activities and recommended 34 ways in which the Commission could be improved. Among the most significant criticisms of Worksafe made by the McKay report were as follows: an overall lack of progress in its first two years of operation, requiring immediate structural and organisational changes. Indeed, those structural and organisational changes are the essence of the amending Bill which is before the Senate at the moment.

The second major criticism was that there had been inadequate progress in heightening public awareness of occupational health and safety matters and developing strategies and priorities. The resolution of the dual problems of occupational health and safety lies essentially in the attitude of those in the workplace. The heightening of awareness and the re-structuring of those attitudes are the essence of success. The McKay report suggests that the Commission has fallen well short of heightening public awareness.

Thirdly, the report directs criticism at the inadequate coordination of occupational health and safety, particularly between the States and Commonwealth departments. As legislation comes before this chamber decade after decade we see both the advantages and disadvantages of belonging to a Commonwealth system. The interface between Commonwealth and State departments is a constant source of difficulty, not only in regard to policy but also coordination. It is apparent that the Commission has also fallen victim to those problems.

Fourthly, the report cites inadequate development of standards, information and education programs and research activities under the National Institute of Occupational Health and Safety. This flows from the previous criticism. Uniformity of standards and information across State lines is absolutely essential to any rational addressing of occupational health and safety challenges. The report cites the inadequate representation of women on the Commission and its committees. This observation recurs in a climate which, theoretically at least, is addressing this imbalance, but which seems to be having very little effect. The lack of representation of women on the Commission and its committees occurs at a time when women are being increasingly represented in all aspects of the work force. It is a dimension of the whole question of equality in our community which we are seriously and, to a degree, effectively addressing.

The report cites communication problems between Worksafe and the outgoing Minister and his Department, although some of the blame is levelled at the latter two. The report cites a rigid adherence to tripartite principles at all levels of activity as being a restriction upon the effectiveness of the Commission. The negative impact of a Public Service model organisation on the Commission's activities was also cited as a major inhibitor of the Commission's effectiveness.

The McKay report tabled in March 1988 was very critical of the effectiveness of the Commission. It was essentially saying that the Commission has to get its act together; it has to streamline the processes. That is the essential thrust of the Bill which is before the chamber. The Democrats identify with that process and, of course, we will be supporting the Bill. In doing so, I point out that the essential emphasis of the Democrats is directed towards actual health and safety in the workplace as opposed to the creation of the bureaucratic structures which seem to be preoccupying the Government and have done so now for a period of almost four years.

The Australian Democrats' main cause for concern remains, therefore, the health and welfare of the work force and not the bureaucratic minutia associated with the creation of the Commission. In this regard, our possible criticisms of existing policies, both State and Commonwealth, would concentrate on the following: the inadequacy of resources devoted to inspection services-the main critique of earlier reports-and the laissez-faire approach which has been demonstrated in the lack of resources devoted to inspection; the failure of the Government to enact its oft promised legislation concerning Commonwealth employees and private sector employees working in the Territories; and the need to raise the Commission's funding to levels recommended by the interim Commission. This should be done at once. Presumably the Government is influenced by the recommendations in the McKay report that the funding levels should be raised immediately to the level prescribed for full implementation of the Commission.

Further, our possible criticisms would concentrate on: the desirability of integrating programs covering occupational health and safety into the various workplaces; returns being promoted by the Department of Employment, Education and Training under the general banner of restructuring; and the apparent lack of commitment by governments, both State and Federal, to the occupational health and safety issues peculiar to persons engaged in home duties. Indeed, we have to acknowledge that many people are engaged in home duties. We have to address the fact that those duties, even though they are performed in the home, should be the target of the Government's consideration when it is considering matters of occupational health and safety.

We would also concentrate on the failure of government's to ratify relevant international conventions such as conventions Nos. 155 and 162. Both have been endorsed by the National Labour Consultative Council but they have not been ratified by all governments, State and Federal, in this country. There is an apparent lack of progress in getting workers to sit up and take notice of warnings from health authorities such as Worksafe.

The Democrats are saying that whilst we acknowledge the positive move by the Government to establish a commission, on the other hand, we cite the limited effectiveness of that Commission to date. We support the recommendations of the McKay report which says, `Put the structures right, get the act together, give it the appropriate level of funding and deliver to the community what is the stated intention of the principal Act and, indeed, the inherent intention in this amending Act'.

The Democrats support the Bill. We support the observations in the amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill, as moved by Senator Patterson at the end of her speech. In essence, we are saying that the challenge is enormous, the initiatives of the Government are positive, but, as yet, ineffective. We support this Bill which is designed to render them more effective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment to the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act 1985. Senator McLean, for one, has spelt out very extensively the reason why this amending legislation is being introduced. The Government was certainly concerned that if we have established a national occupational health and safety commission it should function optimally. The review done by Mr Bernie McKay indicated that there was room for improvement. This legislation is one step in the implementation of the recommendations in his report.

SPEECH.PARA: In passing, I pick up the point Senator McLean made about home duties needing to be considered seriously under the heading of occupational health and safety. Some of us who have actually spent extensive hours in home duties were very concerned that this be part of the deliberations of the Commission and the interim Commission when it was initially established. Despite our earnest pleas, let alone evidence that we led in this direction, home duties workers of this country are not at the forefront of the agenda of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (NOHSC). It may be that that is not ultimately the most appropriate place, but certainly a number of hazards of the workplace also occur in the home. One small example would be the use of chemicals. Many of the chemicals manufactured in industry under stringent health requirements are used in the home with nothing like the same regard given to information about proper use, handling and the like.

Two other comments of the McKay review of the NOHSC went to the very poor representation of women on the Commission at all levels. I hope to see that change. Certainly, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Peter Morris, has given a clear indication that that would be his preferred way too. It is also interesting that the original structure of the Commission restricted the opportunity for the appointment of women to the Commission and its boards because of the definition of categories of people who would be eligible to take a place on the Commission or its committees. As much as possible, there will be new flexibility in this area too.

I take the point Senator McLean made about the lack of flexibility of some of the operations and a rigid adherence to a tripartite representation of any committees examining anything. The Commission certainly intends to proceed with more flexibility and with the appropriate people to do the designated tasks, mindful, of course, of all the requirements under the initial Act.

Before I came into the Senate-certainly in the first year or so of my time here-I was aware that the figures cited in the area of occupational health and safety were that something like 300 Australians died at work each year at a cost to the community of $4.5 billion. A year or so later the figure had increased to 400 people dying each year and the cost had gone up to $5.5 billion. We are now talking of 550 deaths per year and the cost is now over $6 billion. Some people, less modest, would put a figure of $9 billion on it. I do not believe this means that in that last six years many more Australian workers have died. What it does mean is that we are now approaching something like accurate statistics. One of the best contributions of the Commission to this point has been the establishment at least of the beginnings of national data collection and standards for adequate collection of data.

Comparing our figures of death and accident in the workplace with other countries is fraught with just the sorts of problems we have had in the past in this country. There is considerable difference between countries as to what is called an accident and what is called an injury. To this point, however, most people do know what is death. In some ways, that is why it has been the easiest to define, though cause of death has been very difficult to define. We have still to practise considerable caution when comparing figures from one country with those from another. Even allowing for considerable caution, Australia can take little comfort in its relativities, compared to similar Western technological countries. For example, in a work force of seven million in Australia the current estimated 555 deaths a year works out to an incident rate of 77 per million. That can be compared with figures produced in the 1984 International Labour Organisation year book of labour statistics, showing comparable rates of 22 in Sweden, 24 in the United Kingdom, 20 in Japan, and 37 in the United States. I urge a caution about comparison of those figures, because we are quite clear that there is not an exact comparison of matching data and descriptions of what is included in those figures. Indeed, of the 550 deaths of workers per year in Australia, about 20 per cent are incurred when travelling to or from work. They are not deaths in the workplace. It may well be that the extent of our coverage of workers for workers' compensation means that we rate higher because of the gains won by the union movement for workers over time. I am not in a position to say whether figures of that sort are included in figures from other countries.

Even so, the number of deaths is far too high and, of course, inordinately costly. The first and worst cost is of human misery and pain, either for those who are injured or for relatives of those who die. To date I do not know anybody in the world who has put a dollar cost on that kind of pain, suffering and loss. We do have a dollar cost, however, on compensation payouts, on sickness benefits, on loss of productivity, and so on. That cost is roughly estimated to be over $6 billion in this country, which is certainly no cause for complacency.

One of the things that the Commission has done is that it has forced Australia to focus nationally on accidents and deaths in the workplace. Although this is largely an area of State legislation and State responsibility, this Government saw the importance of trying, first, to have a national perspective and a national focus for all the States, and, secondly, of doing such things as providing a place to produce the national data collection, advice and outlines for statistical collections. The Commission can also provide a central information pool for research and advice about practices, regulations and any further information which would be very beneficial to those involved in occupational health and safety across the country.

Apart from all of the things which the Commission has achieved and the areas in which it has increased its presence and activity, it has also given a sense in Australia that there is a thing called `occupational health and safety' which has to be taken very seriously. We could not go into the next decade, century, or even millennium with the prospect of another Wittenoom-of people in their workplace being at risk of disease that is denied, avoided and unfairly disregarded for about 40 years, so that when the people responsible and concerned finally have to address the question of compensation, the Bill is inordinately high.

If pain and suffering and reasonable requests do not get onto the minds of people concerned, certainly the hard dollar cost will. It is sad that we have to wait so long until things cost so much that finally people will address it. But at least the economic argument is now helping to focus the minds of many people on occupational health and safety in a way which was not being done before and in a way which is very beneficial, as it occurs in association with the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, and might be, in some ways, consequent on its establishment.

By way of leading some kind of evidence for that perhaps large claim, I would refer honourable senators to an article in the Mining Review in January 1989, headed `Managing occupational health and safety for the future-now'. It is a summary of a paper presented by a Mr N. A. Amos, Deputy General Manager, Australian Mines and Metal Association, at a seminar run by his association and the Tasmanian Chamber of Mines in September 1988. He points out the seriousness of occupational health and safety, the cost to industry and the important ways in which the proper allocation of responsibility can be made for health and safety in the workplace and costs can be reduced. His words are particularly pertinent to this issue. He says:

However, no matter which way you look at it, good occupational health and safety is synonymous with good economic management because accidents at work cost organisations and employees vast sums of money in terms of loss of productivity, waste and quality control.

I can only say hear, hear; we agree with that. It is precisely that point at which we have now arrived-that occupational health and safety is not a tinsel issue, it is not a frill or frippery on the side. Ultimately, it is a very hard and significant part of good economic management. It must be understood, appreciated and absorbed into the practices of the work force and management of any industry.

The article gives one considerable food for thought. What the writer says is consistent with what I said earlier about the difficulty caused by the lack of non-comparative national statistics. He says:
As the compilation of figures are not consistent across the country, I will use the NSW statistics as examples.
He goes on:
The mining industry had by far the highest employment injury rate of any major industry sector, averaging 299.6 injuries per 1,000 workers, almost five times the average for NSW industry.
While only 2 per cent of the work force is employed in mining, the industry accounted for nearly four times that proportion in total accidents and workers' compensation costs.
Coal mining (the major group within the mining sector) has the second highest incidence rate of any individual industry in the State, averaging 291.2 workplace accidents per 1,000 workers.

Miners, quarrymen and related workers had the highest incidence rate of any occupation in the labour force, at 384.0 workplace accidents per 1,000 workers. This group also had the second highest incidence rate of diseases (principally industrial deafness) in the labour force.
The general trend is that the number of compensation cases in the industry appears to be falling while average period off work has increased.
He goes on to talk about the costs and the adjustments as a result of that, the average time off per injury or accident. Finally, he says:
Total workers compensation paid in the coal mining industry averaged $37m a year and in the rest of the mining industry $4.8m.
The average workers' compensation claim in the coal mining industry is for $5,400 and in the rest of the mining industry, $3,900.

In other words, patterns are now emerging of workplaces which have higher levels of accident and injury and therefore clearly generate more costs in terms of compensation, sickness benefits, loss of productivity and so on.

The article goes on to point out the importance of management, as well as workers, taking very seriously the question of occupational health and safety. While I might not agree with the final conclusions of this article about exactly where final responsibility resides for safety in the workplace, I think we can take considerable comfort from the fact that people of this ilk are now producing very thoughtful and informed papers about occupational health and safety. While this matter may not be in the consciousness of the full community, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission is certainly becoming a body of which industry-both management and workers-are more and more aware. Indeed, any understanding of the accord between the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the trade union movement and this Government shows that part of the social wage of that accord includes the appreciation of the costs and benefits of occupational health and safety being properly managed.

I have just a couple of other points that I would like to make in this contribution. The six areas that have been identified by the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission for the development of preventive strategies are occupational back pain, noise induced hearing loss, chemicals in the workplace, occupational skin disorders, mechanical equipment injury and occupational cancer. All of those are well under way and there are special projects and programs associated with them-first of all, of course, the necessary research and particularly ongoing research as to whether any changes in workplace equipment, processes, chemicals, et cetera, contribute to any of those six areas in a particular way. That information is then provided to the relevant workplaces. With that basic data and basic information particular strategies can be put in place to try to reduce any or all of the accidents and injuries occurring in the workplace. But essentially these six targeted programs look at the long term causes of illness and disease in the workplace rather than tackling the other very urgent matter of health and safety. For that reason I did ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in this place representing the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) last year whether or not NOHSC would or is continuing to address questions of safety, accident prevention and first aid in the workplace as well as these preventive strategies. The Minister in reply said that he would be pleased to take that to the meeting of State Ministers to make sure that this matter was looked at. I have not heard yet if there has been a change in program or a report of what is currently in place, but I certainly hope that matters of safety and accident prevention remain very high on the list of occupational health and safety practices in any workplace.

I do not read a broad number of annual general reports but, if honourable senators look at the annual general reports from various large organisations or companies in this country, they will see that the reports have changed somewhat over the last few years and very often they include a section headed `Occupational Health and Safety'. I think that that is a matter of real appreciation of the companies involved that they are addressing this matter very seriously. I might add that I sometimes see reports under the heading `Affirmative Action'. I find it equally pleasing to see that in annual general reports matters such as occupational health and safety and affirmative action are now being addressed in a public way in a report to shareholders of any large company.

I think we have very excellent people in place in the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. They do very excellent work and it is being done, as it has in the past, by all sorts of people who are involved in trying to reduce the numbers of accidents and deaths in the workplace. Our figures show that there is no room for complacency. I do not think that, with the Commission in place, it is operating more and more at its optimal level and contributing to an increased awareness of the importance of all these steps and, in particular, to an increased awareness that taking these things seriously into account can contribute to very excellent economic management. The cost of death and accident is not only to the worker, but also to the whole society. Any company or organisation which loses a qualified person has to replace that person and has to pay compensation, sickness benefits and so on. I would be pleased to see this amendment in place while it is actually a mechanical or implementation change. It will allow the Commission to function more efficiently. I still think that it is part of an ongoing commitment to occupational health and safety and, hopefully, to reducing not only the numbers of deaths and injuries, but also the appalling cost to the individuals and society that the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission is aiming to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

It also deprives the Australian Democrats of the chance of getting their voting record with the Opposition up to scratch too. So I certainly do not see the need for a division and I wish the Bill a speedy passage.

DEBATE.TITLE: OZONE PROTECTION BILL 1988OZONE PROTECTION (LICENCE FEES-IMPORTS) BILL 1988OZONE PROTECTION (LICENCE FEES-MANUFACTURE) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 21 December 1988.
OZONE PROTECTION BILL 1988
Clause 1 (Short title).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to detain the Committee in this area, but since at the second reading stage debate on this piece of legislation certain events have occurred which I think it is important for the Parliament and this Committee to know about. The Swedish Government has legislated for a five-year phase-out of the ozone substances included in Group I of Annex A of the Montreal Protocol of Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer. Legislation has been introduced into the United States House of Representatives and into the Senate also seeking a five-year phase-out. The Canadian Government has recently introduced legislation for a 10-year phase-out and, more recently, we have seen that ICI and Dupont have patented their CFC134A, CFC123 and CFC124, which are the substitutes available for CFC11 and CFC12, and they have officially announced that those materials will be available in commercial quantities in Australia by 1991. Only yesterday the Victorian Government issued a statement prepared by its Environmental Protection Agency calling for a five-year phase-out of the substances in Group I of Annex A of the Montreal protocol. I think it is important to put those matters on the record because they are matters which have become apparent only since that earlier stage in the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 2 agreed to.
Clause 3 (Objectives).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, paragraph 3 (a), line 3, after ``manufacture'', insert ``use,''.

Clause 3 (a) seeks to institute a system of controls on the manufacture, import and export of substances that deplete ozone but it makes no mention of the use of those substances in Australia. Yet the Ozone Protection Bill 1988 quite clearly seeks to control that usage. I suggest, therefore, that as an objective of the Bill it is appropriate that after the word `manufacture' the word `use' be inserted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a couple of comments about clause 3, which is the objectives clause of the Ozone Protection Bill 1988. I indicate that the Opposition currently has an amendment to insert a new subparagraph (c) to clause 3 which is in the process of being circulated. I think everybody agrees that the timetable laid down by the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer and the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer was laid down at the time on the basis of the best available scientific advice and obviously reflected many of the compromises which needed to be made between the desire to eliminate ozone depleting substances as quickly as possible and the practicalities and the timetable to achieve that. What we are discussing, which is raised both by the objectives clause and by Senator Coulter's amendment, is the question of the timetable and the practicality of setting a date which is a date in advance of the timetable set down in the convention and the protocol and expecting legislative adherence and enforcement of a date which is different from that established in the convention and the protocol.

SPEECH.PARA: When my amendment is forthcoming it will be seen that it deals with what I might call an exhortation to industry to proceed further and faster, rather than the approach Senator Coulter has laid down in his amendment, which is to specify compliance with certain requirements by certain dates. I think it is true to say that, in the course of the last couple of months, the amount of public discussion, the amount of information, the amount of public concern about atmospheric questions in general, both in terms of the ozone depletion effects and in terms of the greenhouse effects, have considerably moved up the international and the domestic political and environmental agendas. As honourable senators would know, during the next couple of weeks two major conferences are to take place. One is to take place in London, at which Mrs Thatcher will be indicating the concern of the British Government to bring about progress in this area, and one will take place at the Hague, which will deal with more global environmental and climatic conditions. It will be attended by representatives of a large number of countries at some of the most senior levels. I believe that it will be attended by various Australian Ministers. This is an indication of the extent to which this is now perceived as a major international problem.

At the same time, and despite what Senator Coulter has said, which by and large I accept, nevertheless there are continuing difficulties in establishing precisely what all the facts are at all times. Indeed, there continue to be considerable disagreements in some of the scientific publications one reads and some of the reports of those scientific publications as to precisely what the dimensions of this problem are. For example, an article appeared in the Australian on 14 February headed `Ozone reports are alarmist: scientist'. The article stated:

One of the world's leading atmospheric scientists says the effects of the depletion of the ozone layer to date have been insignificant-so small they cannot even be measured by the most sophisticated equipment available.

Dr Paul Fraser, a member of NASA's Ozone Trends Panel . . . and a senior researcher at the CSIRO's division of atmospheric research last week told The Australian that alarmist reports in the media, such as those claiming there was an increased possibility of contracting skin cancer at Australian beaches, were nonsense.
On the other hand, four days later a report in the Sydney Morning Herald quoted information from Washington. Under the heading `Shock finding on ozone layer', the report stated in part:
A group of scientists just back from the North Pole is expected to announce tomorrow that the ozone layer is deteriorating more quickly than had been believed.

Frankly, one is constantly faced in this place with the dilemma of sorting our responses to conflicting scientific claims. I think the only sensible thing to do is to approach it more inclined to the worst case scenario than to the best case scenario. To that extent one basically has to work on the proposition that even if the problem turns out eventually not to be as bad as we had imagined, nevertheless it is advisable in terms of public policy to put in place all necessary controls and conditions as if it were going to turn out to be as bad as we suspect. Yesterday's Australian newspaper, under the headline ` ``Hole'' theory in skin cancer rise', says in part:
Tasmania's proximity to the so-called Antarctic ozone hole has been suggested as a cause for a significant and unexpected rise in the incidence of malignant melanoma, a potentially fatal skin cancer.

The Menzies Centre for Population Health Research says the incidence of melanoma in Tasmania is far higher than expected and has increased by 90 per cent for men and 106 per cent for women between 1978 and 1987.

The speculation is that this is somehow related to the depletion of the ozone layer, a point which I have made in a number of previous debates in this place. It is true that action is being taken on a worldwide level. As Senator Coulter rightly pointed out, action has been taken in Sweden. However, my understanding is that Swedish legislation has a fairly significant number of exemption provisions, including major exemption provisions for ozone depleting materials used in the dry cleaning process, which use a substantial amount of such substances. Action has been taken in Canada. Announcements were made within the last couple of days in Victoria, and indeed, a call was made in January of this year by the European Commission, which is not a body noted for its adherence or commitment to the protection of the environment, for urgent action. The Commission prepared a report for the European Council of Ministers analysing the problem related to the greenhouse effect and presenting a series of conclusions, one of which is that the emission of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) should be virtually eliminated by the year 2000 through a revision of the Montreal Protocol. I believe that that is a somewhat more realistic date in terms of approach than that put forward in the amendments which Senator Coulter has foreshadowed in terms of dates, but we will come to those specifically. Nevertheless, I think that the year 2000 is a reasonable proposition.

I want to address just two other matters in terms of the objectives clause which is currently before us. First may I say I think that we tend to be somewhat niggardly in giving due regard to the industry for the steps which industry itself has taken to deal with this problem. As we know, there are a number of joint government-industry working parties which have been quite hard at work setting strategic goals and analysing alternatives both in terms of substance alternatives and technology alternatives. By and large the industry gives me the impression that it is working seriously to bring about a major reduction in the amount of ozone depleting substances which are manufactured and used and is seeking to cooperate with government and State authorities to ensure that there is maximum activity on their part to bring about reductions in the problem that we now face. For example, on 24 January the Association of Fluorocarbon Consumers and Manufacturers announced its commitment to a nationwide system for the recycling of CFCs. The Parliament should be aware of and give credence to those important initiatives.

The second point I want to make on this clause relates to the objective dealing with the reduction of exports. This is a vexatious and difficult problem. I will draw attention to one area where Australia is increasing its exports of CFCs-in the pharmaceutical sector. Recently Glaxo Australia Pty Ltd was given an award by the Federal Government for the program which it had undertaken to expand exports. It has received quite substantial financial reward and incentive from the Government because it has managed to boost its exports by about $352m. Of that, approximately $100m is from the export of materials which are major users of ozone depleting substances-namely, the asthma sprays to which I have referred on previous occasions. As a consumer of those products I have declared my self-interest in the matter.

It is quite clear that the amount of CFCs which will be used in pharmaceutical products will continue to increase. It will increase from about 170 tonnes to about 260 tonnes in the course of the next few years. The amount of material which is being exported in terms of the propellant used in asthma products is of significance. I do not in any sense think that there is anything wrong with that. I believe that eventually there may be some way of replacing the current CFCs which are used in pharmaceutical products. At the moment I am persuaded that no viable alternative is available. Under those circumstances it would be an advantage to have the manufacture and export, and, in some cases, the re-export through Australia, of some of these substances as a far better alternative than expecting countries, particularly those in this region, to have to rely upon producing their own CFCs, because that is the only reasonable alternative for them. If they are not able to source them from places such as Australia, they will be forced to start becoming producers. In my view, they will not be able to produce under the same degree of regulation and control and the same sorts of environmental constraints as those which are currently imposed on producers in Australia. We must be aware that from time to time this policy runs in a slightly contrary fashion. The Government, on the one hand, seeks to reduce Australia's export of such substances, and indeed puts it in the objectives clause of a Bill, and, on the other, it pays substantial financial incentives for people who are increasing the volume of export of such substances in a particular item.

I believe that the objectives clause can be strengthened. When we deal with Senator Coulter's amendment to subclause 3 (a) we can discuss that matter further. I simply say in relation to Senator Coulter's precise amendment to subclause 3-adding the use of the term `use' together with `manufacture' and `import'-that that is not the essential purpose of the Bill in terms of controlling internal or end use. I do not think that it sits well with the rest of the provisions of the legislation. I am not altogether sure of its practicality and it is for that reason that the Opposition will not support Senator Coulter's amendment to subclause 3 (a).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too believe that a great deal has happened since the second reading debate on the legislation. As I indicated then, I am not satisfied that the legislation as it stands will achieve what it is intended to do. I believe that what the Government proposes has been largely superseded all over the world. The United States has gone past us and other countries have made more effort. To say that Australia is in the forefront of action is not quite correct. It is claimed that Australia is responsible for 2 per cent or less of the emissions and, as such, there is little we can do. I do not agree. I do not accept that because the figure is only 2 per cent-if, in fact, it is-we should not do what we can to eliminate it. I believe that the figures are not good enough. I believe that the suggestions Senator Coulter brings forward may well be achieved and surpassed long before even the times he has in mind, as pressure from the public generally builds up and as industry's attitude generally begins to take effect.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government should seize the opportunity to do a lot more about coordination of the research. At present many people seem to be racing about doing all sorts of things in a fairly uncoordinated way. Although I personally, over a period of months, have been trying to find lists of the research that is being carried out, who is doing it and what specifically they are doing, as yet I have been unable to obtain such a list. I do not know whether the Government has any idea what is going on either within its ranks or in industry and academia generally.

The Institution of Engineers, as I noted from yesterday's news brief, is calling on the Government to assist in this coordination and to bring the ends together. I realise that it will be attractive to the Government to try to keep this as an election sweetener and before long there will probably be big announcements as to all the things the Government intends to do. But this is not an election matter or a party political issue. It is a matter on which we all have a good and sensible agreement. I would like to see this placed on a much more useful basis than has happened until now.

If the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) is able to give the Senate some assurances on coordination and funding, if we can be given an assurance that Cabinet is likely to reverse the decision in which it refused to allocate $1m for these purposes, we will be much more satisfied. In the meantime, I agree with Senator Puplick that to strengthen the intentions of the Bill is a start. The details in the Bill may all prove to be overtaken by history before very much longer anyway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be accepting Senator Coulter's amendment, largely for the reasons outlined by Senator Puplick. I do not see that the amendment achieves anything. Certainly clause 3 (b) refers to use and that covers part VI of the Bill. In regard to the rest of the Bill we are not looking at regulating use and therefore the Government is opposed to the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to respond to some of the comments which have been made in the last few moments. I understand that Sweden has gone further than we have. In fact, it intends to cut consumption by 50 per cent by December 1990. Sweden will cease using chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) for all new products by 1994, but of course there is a heavy list of exemptions. There are 10 for industrial use and 20 for medical uses. Those exemptions in Sweden will apply for three years. I doubt very much whether the Swedish Government will be able to stick to that timetable.

On the subject of medical exemptions, Senator Puplick referred to the recent announcement by Glaxo Australia Pty Ltd of a considerable increase in its exports, which included exports that contained ozone-depleting substances largely in the medical field. Obviously one has to be careful in examining any exemption. Glaxo takes the view that 7 to 9 years is the likely time frame from when a product is first identified as a possible substitute and as likely to be safe for inhalation. After identification it has to go through a long period of testing. Naturally enough, it has the potential to cause harm if it is not rigorously tested. After that exhaustive testing there is evaluation and approval by government regulatory agencies. Judging by experience in the United States, that is not a quick affair. It can take a long time, and in Australia it can take even longer. Naturally, governments are cautious about approving the use of anything for inhalation for obvious reasons. I do not know whether the Glaxo claim of 7 to 9 years is precisely right. One could perhaps quibble with it, but I doubt very much that one could get it down to three years. For that reason I do not believe the Swedish legislation is workable. I shall be very surprised if there are not some changes to it. If one looks at what the Australian States have done, one sees that Tasmania produced a Bill on this subject. I note Senator Archer's comments about how we should not use these things as election sweeteners. Looking at the Tasmanian experience, one would have to suggest that that legislation might have been exactly that because the list of exemptions is enormous.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no election in Tasmania last year.

—No, but there was a plan to have one in February. That is why that legislation was introduced last year. However, the plan went astray as soon as the question of the mill came up when the Tasmanian Government botched it so badly that it backed off. The list of exemptions in the Tasmanian legislation is much bigger than the Bill. It robs the Bill of all power and potency. The difficulty is that one can either stand up in the chamber here and be hairier-chested than the next on this and related matters, or one can attempt to deliver something which industry believes is workable and with which it will comply. It must be remembered, with everything we debate here today, that the protocol itself will be re-examined next year in 1990. I do not believe that this legislation will be the end of government regulation in this country, but that it will be just the beginning. No doubt after we have had that re-examination of the protocol next year, we will almost certainly be changing legislation here. But with whatever we do I would hope that we can continue to take industry with us.

SPEECH.PARA: Industry has cooperated in this process remarkably well. Industry came together with the Government in three working groups and I think that industry has behaved responsibly. I made a speech in Washington in December, which received a lot of coverage here. It was not mentioned that I praised Australian industry in this respect. I said that in respect of ozone there had been a great deal of cooperation, an obvious acknowledgment that industry was producing a harmful product and a willingness on the part of industry to do something about it. After exhaustive discussions with industry, I believe that this Bill represents a workable option-a way of getting through. But it is a beginning and not the end. If there are to be concerns about whether Cabinet will be dealing with the matter, it will be dealing with it very shortly. I can never pre-empt Cabinet decisions, but I am confident that we will make announcements soon which, I say to Senator Archer, will be a long way in advance of an election. Hopefully, they will ease some of the honourable senator's concerns.

When I spoke previously I should have tabled a revised explanatory memorandum and correction relating to the Bill. The correction largely relates to a renumbering, which caused me some confusion as I read my brief on Senator Coulter's amendment which was actually to the old Bill. I hope that we can sort that out this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was somewhat amused by the remarks of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories a moment ago. The copy of the Bill I picked up this morning was the older version. I had to run out and get a newer version even to read my own amendments in the correct order. I hope that others are not confused. Picking up on what the Minister has just said about industry cooperation, I was surprised to hear such remarks coming from the Minister and also from Senator Puplick. Industry is clearly trying to make a virtue out of being hit over the head by a piece of four by two, because that is what has happened to it. For years people in the environment movement have been pointing to this problem and particularly to the need to remove chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) from aerosol applications. Industry has consistently and vigorously resisted those moves. Now, when the inevitability of the removal of those substances is staring industry in the face, it attempts to make a virtue of it and says, `Are we not good fellows? We have removed these materials from aerosols'.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, industry, unless it is pushed very hard, will resist the removal of chlorofluorocarbons from all other applications until it is pushed. When it is pushed hard enough it will find that alternative technologies and gases are available. Yesterday an Australian Associated Press release stated that Mr Roberts of Afcam had said that Afcam had been working with the Federal Government on the issue and had made significant progress. My goodness, it has certainly made significant progress! It has significant let-out clauses in relation to exports and it has a weaker Bill than it should have got.

Senator Puplick mentioned pharmaceutical applications and pointed to the fact that Glaxo Australia Pty Ltd had been given an award by the Government because it had increased its exports. But I point out that in this Bill we are looking at an increase of exports above the 1986 level of 1,500 tonnes as a starting point and that pharmaceutical uses are expected to plateau at 2,600 tonnes, a minuscule proportion of the total amount which the Federal Government is allowing as an initial increase in exports before it begins to reduce exports.

As on previous occasions, Senator Puplick has attempted to smear the evidence in relation to the need for reducing the release of chlorofluorocarbons and other ozone depleting substances by saying that there is some doubt about the data. I say to him and to other honourable senators that there is no doubt about the data. Very often journalists are unable to understand scientific material and draw wrong conclusions. Let me give an example. Senator Puplick used the example of an increase in skin cancer rates in Tasmania and pointed out that some people have claimed that that increase may be due to decreases in ozone and increases in shortwave ultraviolet light. Those who work in the area know very well that a long latent period separates the mutation which occurs at the single cell level from the appearance of a clinical cancer. No person understanding this could possibly claim that increased cancer rates in Australia observed now are due to decreases in ozone and increases in short wave ultraviolet light which have occurred in recent years.

Probably, if we have an increase in skin cancer, it is due to the fact that recently people have gone around with less clothing. In recent years women, in particular, have uncovered themselves rather more. Consequently, we see an increase in skin cancer. Senator Puplick mentioned malignant melanoma, the third most common cancer in women. He pointed out also that the increase in this disease in women has been greater than the increase in men. The evidence is clear that there may well be an increase in skin cancer but one cannot in any sense tie that to the subject we are discussing this morning.

We are looking at long term consequences. We are looking at scientific data which clearly indicates that, once chlorofluoro- carbons get into the stratosphere, they have very long resonance times, that they are catalytic in their breakdown of stratospheric ozone and that, therefore, the breakdown will occur over a very long period. The observed fact that the breakdown of stratospheric ozone so far has not been very large is no assurance whatsoever that this matter is not urgent. The decrease in stratospheric ozone as a consequence of the effect of CFCs in the Antarctic, recently observed in the Arctic also, is particularly worrying because of another effect. The greenhouse effect, which is a consequence of an increase in a range of gases in the atmosphere, increases the temperature of the lower atmosphere and decreases the temperature of the stratosphere. We do not need a very large decrease in the temperature of the stratosphere before the Antarctic phenomenon could be observed on a much wider scale. There have been substantial decreases in stratospheric temperature as a consequence of greenhouse gases.

One cannot stress too strongly that this is an urgent matter. We need urgent action. I stress that the timetabling foreshadowed in my amendments is achievable. I draw attention to the fact that the first year's reduction, or first two year's reduction, is achievable right now by the removal of ozone depleting substances from aerosol use and other non-essential uses. Several years will pass before a 20 per cent reduction per year will bite at the level where we will need to institute the alternatives, both in terms of gases and technology, in industries such as refrigeration and air-conditioning. By that time I am certain that those technologies will be available and achievable. However, without the passage of strong legislation companies will simply dilly-dally and not get on with the business of developing alternatives. I believe that the alternatives are available and that the technology could be put into place. But that will occur only if we put very strong legislation into place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was heartened after hearing Senator Coulter's comments about the rise in skin cancer in Tasmania. Being a person who lives in southern Tasmania, when I read the article that Senator Puplick referred to which stated that the so-called Antarctic ozone hole had increased cancer rates, I was quite alarmed. Recently, two of my very close friends passed away because of melanomas. Quite a few of us down in Tasmania are rather concerned about the effects the hole in the ozone layer is having. But if, as Senator Coulter has said, there is a long latent period, perhaps we can take heart and consider the research that has been done recently, reported in the Hobart Mercury, regarding the wearing of reflective clothing, and that type of thing. I make the point to the Minister that I hope the Government continues to fund research. We have seen cutbacks in research for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) over a period of time. It has been very vocal in its call for more money for research. The CSIRO has been researching this ozone hole for some 30 years. It was only in 1979 that it discovered the hole over the Antarctic. Some people at our end of the nation thought that it was caused by some of the spy flights that Senator Gareth Evans authorised over southern Tasmania. Of course, we now know that this ozone hole has increased not only over the Antarctic but also the Arctic. A lot of research is being done.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand a submission for special funding for the continued research into the greenhouse effect and all those other climatic changes is before the Government at the moment as well as before Senator Richardson and Mr Barry Jones. As Senator Coulter said it is not just the ozone layer that is causing concern but also the greenhouse effect. I urge the Government to take a much wider view of this situation by providing more money for scientific institutions and universities around the country. I hope that these organisations can put more evidence into the debate. We are well aware that the Bureau of Meteorology has made major contributions. It is important to point out that the five ozone monitoring stations in Australian territory and the work that is performed by the staff at these stations is enabling the scientists around the world to increase their knowledge of the ozone areas.

I urge the Government to increase the funding to the CSIRO for these studies. I commend the great contribution that has been made by Dr Paul Fraser and Willem Bouma at the Division of Atmospheric Research. They are doing great work. As the Minister already indicated the industry itself, the Association of Fluorocarbon Consumers, made a generous donation of $25,000. I hope that government and industry cooperate to continue research and that we can get some more positive action on something that at the moment is only being looked at by scientists and those types of people rather than getting a combined effort from industry and all those other people who are being affected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Coulter's amendment and to make a couple of brief points. It is interesting that this committee stage debate is being quite significantly participated in by a number of our Tasmanian colleagues. The Tasmanian Government has been an initiator in terms of this kind of legislation although it is imperfect. This amendment attempts to strengthen this legislation, as do all of Senator Coulter's amendments, in particular, the question of use and its relationship to the Government's legislation. I draw attention to the fact that it is not just the Australian Democrats, including Senator Coulter, but also our Tasmanian colleagues who are saying somewhat tentatively to the Government that we need to go further by way of this amendment and certainly by way of others to this legislation, as well as the Victorian Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not heard any response from the Minister or from the Government to the Victorian Government's paper which was released the day before yesterday. Certainly as paragraph (7) of the policy statement of the Victorian Environment Protection Authority's (EPA) draft option paper and policy paper on ozone depleting substances says, regulations should be based on end use controls. If it were appropriate in the committee stage, I would ask the Minister if he had a response to that. It is probably not appropriate; I suggest he is here responding to Senator Coulter's amendment. The paper put out by the EPA, which was endorsed by the Victorian Government and specifically by Minister Roper, does most of the things which the Democrat amendment is attempting to do. This amendment and subsequent ones will speed up the phase out process, will make it far more effective and will strongly acknowledge the inadequacies of the Montreal protocols. This is what the whole series of Senator Coulter's amendments is attempting to do.

While the Minister has explained to us that he wants to bring industry with him-there has to be some sympathy for that view-it is interesting that this senior Labor Government is further down the track or would prefer to go further down the track.
