It is important to make that point. This is a process which Senator Coulter's amendment is beginning. It is saying that this legislation that the Government is putting forward is not adequate. I want to inject into the debate that it is not just the Australian Democrats who are saying that but also some colleagues in the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a couple of points on this. I understand that the Victorian Government put a draft paper out yesterday saying what it would like to do. I have had a look at that along with-one has no doubts-a great many other organisations and individuals. I will sit down with the Victorians and give them my views. There seems to be developing here some assumption that the legislation that we have before us today is being surpassed and overrun everywhere. That is just not right. I think Senator Archer said earlier that the United States of America has already gone further than we have. That is not true. All that has happened is that a small group of senators is sponsoring a Bill which may one day get debated. It may one day get passed or amended and they are a long way off doing anything. Honourable senators should not try to adopt a Bill or make the Government adopt a position when we deal with practicalities which requires almost total backdown.

SPEECH.PARA: The Tasmanian legislation was introduced on 8 September last year. On 27 September the first of the backdowns began over the proposal for the labelling of products. That was backed off two weeks after the legislation was introduced. The idea that all aerosols would be banned by 1 October was dropped immediately and extended to 31 December. We then had the list of exemptions which were published in the Government Gazette on 25 January this year.

Let me give honourable senators an idea of how far the Tasmanian Government has backed down. Everything is exempted if it is a control substance; if it is applied in refrigeration and cooling. It includes: furniture and furnishing manufacture; application of packaging material; dry-cleaning products; veterinary treatments; industrial uses; scientific or measuring equipment; or the use of propellants and aerosols. Virtually every single use that we have for chlorofluorocarbons or ozone depleting substances is exempted under the Tasmanian legislation. In other words, there is a piece of legislation which has absolutely no force on anything.

I do not want to be placed in a position-I am sure the Opposition would not want to see us placed in a position-where we have that sort of farce. Rather, we have to go for the art of the possible. I hope that the art of the possible includes a further revision of the protocol next year and no doubt the further revision of our own legislation in the light of whatever happens with the Montreal protocol. That is what we should all be about. I never decry bringing industry along. It will be much easier to implement legislation if we have checked with industry first and we know can be done. Of course, we have given industry a nudge. I doubt very much that it likes everything that is in this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps they have seen what has happened in the timber industry and they are entitled to be a bit shaken.

—Obviously it is making the best of what it might regard as a bad situation. But I would much rather it make the best of it than make life too difficult for itself or for us. There is no question that industry has tried. There is no question that it will try harder. We do not have to believe that this is all a high minded effort on the part of industry. We do not have to believe that its heart or its mind is in the right place when it comes to the principle we are arguing about today, but we must know that there is now a commercial imperative.
—Only the Government's heart and mind is in the right place.

—It is always in the right place. This legislation gives industry that commercial imperative. If for no other reason, it will work flat out not only to have substances patented, as Senator Coulter mentioned, but also, we hope, to get them to Australia and right around the world in the quantities necessary to have substitution throughout these areas. I hope that is what this legislation does. I hope we have the cooperation of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats in achieving that aim.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Coulter's amendment to the Ozone Protection Bill 1988 and the other amendments he will introduce later because I believe that the Government's Bill should go further than the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer in reducing the production, export and consumption of ozone depleting substances, as recommended by numerous Australian experts and community groups, as well as the European Commission in its recent report to the European Council of Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Government's Ozone Protection Bill, as outlined in the explanatory memorandum, is to `provide for additional controls, beyond those required by the Protocol, which will further reduce the usage, and emission to the air, of ozone depleting substances'. The Montreal protocol itself sets maximum limits for production and consumption of ozone depleting substances, presumably to encourage signatory countries to strive for the lowest limits possible of ozone depleting substances. I am concerned that the imperative to achieve this is not embodied in the Government's Bill without the inclusion of the amendment put by the Australian Democrats.

The Montreal protocol of 1987 was an enlightened and commendable achievement for 53 nations to agree upon. However, it was arrived at without the benefit of the surprise observations of the spring of 1987, when ozone levels over Antarctica were reduced by 50 per cent. They also could not know of more recent evidence of ozone thinning over the Northern Hemisphere. As an exercise in international cooperation on the global environment, the Montreal protocol is a milestone. As a target limit for the production and consumption emission of ozone depleting substances, the reduction schedule prescribed by the Montreal protocol is, sadly, obsolete. The implications for human health of such drastic reductions in the ozone layer have been widely discussed. The impending disaster for Antarctic and Arctic ecosystems has received less attention. Massive extinctions can be expected if the trend is not reversed in time.

I have grave concerns about self-regulation and search for chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) substitutes by industries where global climactic patterns and biological food chains are at risk. Some manufacturers, according to the Alliance for a Responsible CFC Policy, reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 26 November last year, regard as the `horrific consequences' of the diminishing ozone layer the impact on the industries themselves-not fear for our children's cancer rates or the global food chain, but fear for their profits. Conventional economic accounting systems, with which companies and governments like to run the country, have set the short term costs of ozone depleting substances, such as those used in refrigerators, air-conditioning and aerosols, much lower than available alternatives and the development of new ones. The long term environmental costs are not included in the corporate reckoning of ICI Australia Ltd, Atochem Australia Pty Ltd or Australian Fluorine Chemicals Pty Ltd, all CFC manufacturers in Australia, until political pressures force them to do so.

In 1986, the United States Environmental Protection Authority concluded that several adequate substitutes for ozone depleting substances were available, but the absence of a market for the higher priced alternatives had slowed their manufacture. We now learn that ICI claims to have acceptable alternatives ready for market by 1991. The level of community concern about the threats to human health and the global environment from ozone layer depletion has been underestimated, as has the community's willingness to switch to higher cost alternatives where necessary. I am not referring to essential medical use of these substances but to such innovations as the CFC-recycling units for refrigerators, which have been developed recently in WA, and to aerosol substitutes.

Further reductions in the essential use categories can be achieved by stringency of essential use criteria, as recommended by the Victorian Government in its recently released draft policy statement. Its suggested mechanism of an independent body to evaluate exemptions from CFC bans, comprising medical representatives from government, consumer and environment groups, should be taken on board by the Government. The Victorian Government's policy document points out other areas where Commonwealth Government initiatives could encourage reductions in ozone depleting substances, including the use of financial incentives and disincentives and public, professional and industry educational programs. We clearly cannot afford to ignore any initiatives which may assist in addressing his threat to life on earth.

In regard to consumer awareness, industry advocates should be heartened by the results of a Frank Small and Associates Pty Ltd survey published in October 1988, which showed the breakdown of the ozone layer was rated the most significant environmental problem for which something had to be done soon in all major cities in Australia. It also showed that 52 per cent of the people surveyed are changing their usage and buying behaviour because of this concern. Unfortunately, the generous export quotas provided for in the Government's Ozone Protection Bill will delay the accounting of environmental costs for the development of alternatives to, and a market for, ozone depleting substances. As Senator Coulter pointed out, this constitutes a major deficiency in the Ozone Protection Bill before us.

Using 1987 as the reference export year, instead of 1986 as prescribed in the Montreal Protocol, allows exports to continue at unacceptably high levels. Australia must set an example or, at the very least, follow the examples already set by Sweden, and now indicated by Canada, the United States, and Senator Coulter's amendments, in curbing this selfish and dangerous global experiment. The suggestion by the office of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) in its reply to the Australian Conservation Foundation's criticisms of the Ozone Protection Bill was that if Australian-based CFC manufacturers were prohibited from supplying CFCs according to `existing legitimate business arrangements', developing nations would build their own. This bears a disturbing resemblance to the argument for supplying uranium to the nuclear market. The bottom line in the rationale of `If we don't do it, someone else will get the profits and, anyway, it provides an avenue of influence over its final use' is sales, not the survival of the planet.

As a developed nation which has enjoyed the luxuries of such inappropriate technology as ozone depleting substances, we have an obligation to develop and share appropriate and sustainable alternatives with the developing nations in our region. I am therefore pleased to be able to endorse the amendment moved by Senator Coulter and those he has foreshadowed, which will have the effect of an annual reduction in the use of ozone depleting substances of 20 per cent per year from 1986, leading to a total phase-out by 1996. That is what we must do if Australia is to act responsibly in a non-partisan way for the benefit not only of the Australian community but also the global community.

Having heard various Liberal senators express dissatisfaction with the Government's Bill, I hope that they and their colleagues will also support Senator Coulter's amendment. It is not good enough for the Minister to say that this will be just the first stage of restricting the use of ozone depleting substances. Why not do the job thoroughly now? Why not lay down the timetable clearly so that industry will be pressured to research and market alternatives right now. Time does not permit the luxury of taking a slow path to progress. This is urgent. I do not want to argue whether other countries have gone further, how many exemptions they allow, or whether their legislation can be effective. That is just an excuse for not doing a thorough job right now. Let us be courageous and a model for other countries. Let us prove that the job can be done. The public has picked up on the urgency of the situation, as the Frank Small and Associates poll shows. The people want alternatives and they are prepared to pay extra for them. The legislation should not fall short of the will of the people to deal with this urgent situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister's objection to the inclusion of the word `use' in clause 3 (a) in any sense relate to his concern over the use of the foreign affairs powers and the Montreal Protocol as something on which he is relying heavily for the passage of this Bill? Does the inclusion of the word `use' worry him on those grounds?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The main ground for my objection is that Senator Coulter's use of the word `use' in clause 3 (a) puts the word in a section of the Bill that cannot, does not, will not regulate use. I therefore do not understand why we should proceed with it. Only part 6 has any relevance to it and that is referred to in clause 3 (b), where the word `use' appears. I find it totally unnecessary and misleading to put the word `use' in 3 (a). That is the essential reason. I have had concerns about a number of amendments on the question of powers and I suppose in some respects I have concerns now with this amendment. However, regardless of whether I had concerns, I would oppose the amendment on the grounds which I have just outlined.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, paragraph 3 (a), line 8, leave out ``and''.
(2) Page 2, after paragraph 3 (b), add the following new paragraph:
``and (c) to use the best endeavours to encourage Australian industry to:
(i) replace ozone depleting substances; and
(ii) achieve a faster and greater reduction in the levels of production and use of ozone depleting substances than are provided for in the Convention and the Protocol,

to the extent that such replacements and achievements are reasonably possible within the limits imposed by the availability of suitable alternate substances, and appropriate technology and devices.''.

As I said in my earlier remarks, the general agreement across all sides of the chamber is that we ought to be moving further and faster than the Convention and the Protocol provide. This, without attempting to specify dates and precise figures and arrangements, is an exhortatory provision to go into the objectives clause of the Ozone Protection Bill which recognises that we ought to take steps to encourage Australian industry to replace ozone depleting substances and, in fact, that we ought to go at a faster and greater pace than is provided for in the convention and the protocol, but also recognises that there are limits and they are the limits of the availability of suitable alternative substances and the availability of appropriate technology and devices. I have already agreed in the earlier debate that in some areas the replacement of existing CFCs by alternative substances is in fact quite practical. We know, for example, that the possible substitution for the use of CFCs 11 and 12 by substances such as HFC-134a and HFC-123 is clearly already on the agenda, but equally, as I said earlier, I am persuaded that the immediate alternatives for things such as the propellants used in asthma sprays and pharmacological products are not at the moment available. Similarly, we know that alternative devices in areas such as refrigeration and dry cleaning are available, but again there are certain limitations in terms of genuine cost and actual efficiency.

I have already made the point about the pharmaceutical industry and about the particular problems which have arisen there. I made the point about Glaxo Aust. Pty Ltd and its export program. I believe that this paragraph, proposed to be inserted in the objectives clause, is simply a clear sign that the Parliament believes that industry should be encouraged to move at a faster and greater pace than the minimum pace provided for in the protocol and in the convention, but recognises that it cannot be done overnight, nor can it, I believe, be done by tying it to specific dates in the way in which Senator Coulter's proposed amendment would have us believe.

It has been raised with me that perhaps there is some problem about going further and going faster. However, I draw attention to two comments on this: The first is, quite clearly, that in the explanatory memorandum under the heading `Outline' the Bill is described in these terms:

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the obligations which will arise when Australia ratifies the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer, and to provide for additional controls, beyond those required by the Protocol, which will further reduce the usage, and emission to the air, of ozone depleting substances.

Similarly, I look at a press statement which was put out on 14 December 1988, on the stationery of the office of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), headed `Ozone Protection Bill 1988. Reply to the Australian Conservation Foundation's criticisms' which says, in part:
However, other constitutional powers are used in the Bill to go further than the Protocol requires.

In fact, the Government makes a virtue in its explanatory memorandum and in its public statements of going further than the protocol requires. Indeed, I have acknowledged that and have congratulated the Government on taking that stand. I therefore believe that some of the ingenious and almost persuasive legal and constitutional arguments that were put to me about this matter are not sufficiently persuasive for the Opposition to fail to pursue this amendment and, therefore, I offer to the Committee this particular amendment, which is certainly exhortatory; it will certainly sit well in the objectives clause of the Bill. It is not intended to specify dates or figures but is simply a statement on the part of the Parliament that industry should be encouraged to move at a faster rate and, indeed, to achieve progress in greater quantum amounts and recognises that limits are imposed by the availability of appropriate alternative substances and appropriate technology and devices.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have no objection to these amendments. They do, in fact, approach the next amendment which is on my circulated list of amendments but, as Senator Puplick has pointed out, they do not mention particular phase-out dates or targets. I foreshadow that if this amendment were to be passed the next amendment on my list, paragraph (a) of proposed new clause 3a, might disappear because it is essentially aiming at the same purpose. That would still leave proposed new paragraph 3a (b) of my amendments to be debated.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking to Senator Puplick's amendment, I again stress that in my view industry will not achieve a faster phase-out, it will not achieve the implementation of the alternative chemistry, or the development of the alternative technology to use the alternative chemicals unless it is put under very strong pressure. I do not see that an exhortatory clause by itself will achieve that objective. I see nothing wrong with putting the clause in if it indicates a direction, but I strongly suggest that my proposed new clause 3a (b) should go on after this.
I think it is worth reading into the record the statement made by Mr Christopher Hartley, the Marketing Manager for ICI Australia Ltd. The other day, he stated:
Samples of ozone-friendly fluorocarbon, HFC-
that is, a substance not containing chlorine in its molecule-
would be available in Australia this year for testing, and commercial quantities would be available from 1991 . . .

So the achievement of the faster phase-down rate is possible and, as I have already indicated, I believe that the first year to a year and a half will be achieved even under the Government's legislation because of the removal of CFCs from non-essential uses such as aerosols. So that one need not have any compunction, at least for several years, before the 20 per cent figure which I would like to see written in here begins to bite into those so-called essential uses. I think it is worth stressing also that we had refrigeration in this country long before the CFCs were developed by General-Motors Holden's Ltd in 1928 and we still have refrigerators in this country which depend upon alternative technologies. The conventional gas and kerosene refrigerators use technology which still uses a solution of ammonia.

In using the word `essential' we need to be aware that we are saying that, in the strict sense of that word, there are no uses of chlorofluorocarbons which are absolutely essential. There is a sliding scale of desirability of use which has to be weighed against the consequences of continuing to use and release these substances into the atmosphere. Clearly, we have made a judgment that the use in aerosols is the least essential. Next after that we have a range of uses as solvents in foam blowing agents and, probably, last, we have the use in refrigeration and air-conditioning. But even there, strictly speaking, the use is not essential. So I support Senator Puplick's amendment and, in doing so, I draw attention to proposed new clause 3a (b) in my circulated amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read Senator Puplick's amendment a couple of times. I should also put on the record that I am very impressed now that I have an expansion of my knowledge of the lexicon by the use of the word `exhortatory' which I had not come across previously and which I am thinking about.
—We are only here to be helpful.

—That is what Rex Mossop says all the time. Looking at this amendment I wonder what it achieves. The Bill is about getting industry to replace ozone depleting substances and to achieve it at a greater rate. Obviously, procedures for achieving it at a greater rate are laid down in the Bill. If it is necessary for the Opposition to be able to say that it did something in this debate and it actually put words into the Bill then I would be the last one to deny it that opportunity and pleasure. Given that, I cannot see that it does any harm. On behalf of the Government I will remain silent when this vote is put.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Proposed new clause 3a.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 2, after clause 3, insert the following new clause:
Additional objectives
``3a. In addition to the objectives specified in section 3, the objectives of this Act are:
(a) to eliminate, not later than 31 December 1995, the manufacture, use, import and export of substances listed in Group 1 of Annex A of the Protocol contained in Schedule 3 of this Act; and
(b) to eliminate, not later than 31 December 1998, the manufacture, use, import and export of substances listed in Group 11 of Annex A of the Protocol contained in Schedule 3 of this Act.''.

It may be that, in rewording this Bill if the amendment is accepted, it can be added on after Senator Puplick's adopted amendment. I am suggesting that, in addition to the objectives which have been specified in clause 3, this further objective be included:
to eliminate, not later than 31 December 1995, the manufacture, use, import and export of substances listed in Group 1 of Annex A of the Protocol contained in Schedule 3 of this Act;

That extends the remarks that I made in response to Senator Puplick's amendment to write very specifically in the objectives what I hope the Bill will set out to achieve; namely, a complete phase-out on the use of these substances in that list by 31 December 1995. I believe that it is appropriate to put that objective right up front in the Bill. I think it sets a target; I think it gives effect to the additional material which Senator Puplick has just had written into the Bill; and I believe that, without such a strong objective and the clauses that would flow from it, industry would not do its job adequately. I have spoken to that at some length already.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept this amendment. Of course, it is dependent upon other amendments which Senator Coulter will move later in the debate and which the Government does not support. In response to these continuing references by Senator Coulter and others to what needs to be done to industry: industry has been conducting the largest toxicity testing program ever on chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs). Industry-and that includes ICI Australia Ltd-is already building plants that will produce the alternatives. Even though the lifetime studies on the toxicity of these alternatives are not yet completed the short term ones have been. I believe that industry is playing its part. I do not believe that, at this point in time, we need to do any more to convince it of the need to go down this path. The Government cannot support this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 4 to 6-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter for clarification by the Minister. It concerns clause 4 of the legislation, which is the clause intended to save the operation of laws of a State or Territory. The Minister will recall that during the second reading debate on this legislation I mentioned the concern that had been expressed by Tim Moore, the New South Wales Minister for Environment, to the extent that his initial reading of the clause was that, instead of striking down any State legislation which might deal with this matter, there was a potential problem in that the legislation might prohibit a State from going further within its own area of jurisdiction than is provided for in the Commonwealth legislation. The Minister will be aware of correspondence which was addressed to him from Mr Moore and the question I raised during the second reading debate. It would be useful, for the record, to allow the Minister the opportunity to respond to the concerns raised at that time and on behalf of the New South Wales Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can recall exchanging some correspondence with Mr Moore, the New South Wales environment Minister. I think we also had a discussion about the matter. I sought advice at the time. I am happy to give the assurance that it is my understanding that clause 4 does nothing to compatible State laws, and that includes those which go further than this legislation. I understand also that Mr Moore has since received advice that concurs with that and that he is satisfied that it would not inhibit the States if they chose to go further than this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 7 (Definitions).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 3, subclause 7 (1), after definition of ``licensee'', insert the following new definition:
`` `ozone depleting effect' means ozone depleting effect as defined in section 11;''.
(4) Page 3, subclause 7 (1), after definition of ``Protocol'', insert the following new definition:

`` `quantity of CFC' means the quantity that is the sum of the amounts arrived at by multiplying the number representing the mass of the amount in kilograms of each CFC by its ozone depleting potential;''.
(5) Page 3, subclause 7 (1), after definition of ``quarter'', insert the following new definition:
`` `quota' means a quantity of CFC;''.

Clause 7 deals with definitions. However, the definitions appeared only through a reading of the later clauses of the Bill. As one read through the Bill, a number of things were unclear. One had to discover them further along, as in the case of the ozone depleting effect, which is defined in clause 11. One came across that almost by accident. Further on there were other definitions which one had to work out for oneself. For instance, `quota' was used but not defined. We find `quota activity' defined in the Bill but not `quota'. I have attempted merely to bring forward those matters which are defined later in the Bill to make the Bill clearer, and also to write into the Bill definitions in those areas where the Bill is deficient. There is, so far as I can see, nothing in these amendments that is in any way inconsistent with the Bill. They simply aid in clarification of the Bill and make it easier to read for people starting at page 1 and working their way through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the definitions to which Senator Coulter has referred, the ozone depleting definition is the same as the existing one in clause 11. In respect of the others, I am at a loss to try to work out what they will contribute. I am not sure I can identify who will find it easier in reading the Bill if we were to include the amendments. I do not think that this is a matter of extreme import, as Senator Coulter has acknowledged. On balance I believe the amendments add nothing and will make the Bill a little untidier. Therefore, the Government rejects them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) that the amendments do not in any way change the Ozone Protection Bill, but where one comes across the term `ozone depleting effect' and has to get on to clause 11 before that term is defined, I believe that that process in itself is messy. Normally when I approach a Bill I go to the definitions and look through them to find out what the various terms mean, and if one has to go to a later part of a Bill to find a definition that in itself is messy. It is far more appropriate to bring that definition forward, even though it occurs later in the Bill. It makes the Bill much easier to read and easier to understand. I believe it adds to the Bill in the sense that it makes it more explicable.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 8 to 17-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 18 (Duration of licence).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 7, subclause 18 (1), line 21, leave out ``10'', insert ``5''.
Clause 18 deals with the duration of a licence and subsection (1) now reads:
A licence remains in force for a period of 10 years.

The amendment seeks to substitute a period of five years. There are two reasons for doing this. First, there is a clear connection between the desirability of having licences running for only five years and the move which the Australian Democrats are attempting to make to phase chlorofluorocarbons out of use entirely over a period of five years. It would make little sense to give a licence which would remain in force beyond that period. That becomes a substantial reason within the context of the amendments which we have attempted to move already and amendments we shall be moving later. Beyond that, even if those amendments are not accepted, we believe that there are substantial reasons why the period of licence should be reduced. It is to give effect to the claims made by both Senator Puplick and the Minister as to keeping the pressure on industry so that alternative technologies and alternative chemicals will be developed and will come into use.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., pursuant to sessional order I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware that on 8 and 15 December 1988 I raised the subject of allegations of corrupt practices among some Commonwealth Bank officers and allegations that the Federal Police had failed in their duties in relation to investigating these matters. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) answered questions on both days and I tabled seven sworn statements and other documents in relation to six cases. Since then my office has received several hundred phone calls alleging malpractice and I have selected in excess of 70 cases which I believe are credible. The number is growing daily. I have interviewed many constituents, a significant number of lawyers, accountants, journalists, bank managers and employees and ex-bank managers. I am convinced that we have a problem of major proportions which I am compelled and duty bound in the public interest to pursue vigorously and determinedly.

SPEECH.PARA: Two things have happened in recent years which have dramatically changed the ethos of banking and given rise to widespread allegations of malpractice and corruption. The deregulation of banking has intensified competition dramatically and triggered a surge in credit promotion. This has been accompanied by an extraordinary increase in indebtedness which has rendered individuals, companies and their businesses highly vulnerable. It is alleged that this has created the opportunity for unscrupulous bankers to engage in malpractice and corruption. The evidence suggests that there has been a serious erosion of the fundamental fiduciary relationship in banking. Allegedly there have been at least three parallel dimensions to this problem: first, that which involves asset stripping of specifically targeted businesses; secondly, inducement of clients into foreign borrowings which have rendered businesses vulnerable because of exchange variations; and, thirdly, premature foreclosure on rural property holdings. The allegations suggest a serious national problem warranting a major and immediate Senate inquiry.

I will briefly address each of these areas of alleged malpractice. First, there is the targeting of certain businesses and asset stripping. I have previously outlined variations on this method. Healthy and prospectively profitable businesses are targeted. By manipulation of cash against debts, businesses or individuals are rendered vulnerable. Takeovers and/or foreclosures occur or bankruptcy is induced. It is alleged that either banks themselves acquire the assets or other prearranged recipients acquire them at ridiculously favourable terms. There are many variations on these techniques and additional opportunities for malpractice occur at the receivership and liquidation stages and among agents who service bank needs in these stages. To date allegations have been directed only at the Commonwealth Bank, but of course the allegations relate to most major banks and other financiers. I now seek leave to table 20 additional cases which typify the alleged malpractices.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The substantiating documents are all signed statements, but they vary in form. These cases include millionaires and battlers and are drawn from several States. In most cases very comprehensive documentation has been provided to substantiate the general allegations made. All signatories are willing to expand upon their statements, and I table the cases of Baines v. State Bank of New South Wales, Baker v. Westpac Banking Corporation, Bourke v. State Bank of New South Wales, Brandon v. Commonwealth Bank, Cheesman v. Elders Rural Finance, National Australia Bank Ltd. and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd., Chick v. Commonwealth Bank, Colchek v. Commonwealth Bank and Delonga v. Commonwealth Bank Finance Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: The list of cases continues: Doughty v. State Bank of New South Wales, Douglas Hill v. the Commonwealth Bank, Frame v. Commonwealth Bank, a series of statements from Galli in relation to various banks, Gardiner v. Commonwealth Bank and the Commonwealth Bank Finance Corporation, Hamod v. Westpac Banking Corporation, O'Connor v. National Australia Bank Ltd, Porter v. Commonwealth Bank, Rigg v. Commonwealth Bank, Salmon v. National Australia Bank Ltd, Smith v. National Australia Bank Ltd, and Somerset v. National Australia Bank Ltd. The cases and statements of Bourke, Rigg, Salmon, O'Connor, Somerset, Smith, Colchek, Chick, Cheesman, Douglas Hill and Hamod are especially relevant.

I turn now to the second aspect of the allegations, namely those commonly referred to as the forex or foreign loans debacle. I seek leave to table statements and a summary of cases provided by a Sydney lawyer, Paul Galli, who has in the past three years handled 300 cases of people who are alleged to have been victimised by banks in what is now referred to as the Swiss loans scam. He cites eight typical cases and provides the relevant statements of claim filed in various supreme courts.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —He describes the forex loans scam of this period as `the darkest chapter in the history of Australian banking'. In essence, Australians, individuals and companies, were enticed into foreign loans quite deliberately and therefore into a situation which was fraught with danger. Many were then left to founder in bankruptcy when fluctuating exchange rates caught them out. His statements are very potent indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the third aspect of these allegations, namely premature rural foreclosures. Rural indebtedness, of course, has historically been a problem requiring special consideration and in the past it has even given rise to the formation of special banks. In an intensely competitive context where the fiduciary duty of banking has been seriously eroded, the difficulty of rural indebtedness has become a disaster. I seek leave to table the Mitchelmore report to the New South Wales Parliament in 1987 which documents the problem.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am led to believe that the legislation which flowed from the Mitchelmore report to the New South Wales Parliament has passed both Houses of the State of New South Wales but has never received royal assent. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that as recently as last week in Port Lincoln, South Australia, a public meeting attracted 1,000 farmers and others and formed the Eyre Peninsula Action Group to save the properties of colleagues whom they allege had been victimised. They have picketed their banks; they are door-knocking their communities and have initiated a process which they call `Bankwatch'. This is a superb example of a community responding to what it sees as a huge and significant problem. We are seeing bank borrowers associations and foreign exchange associations forming to gain mutual support and to fight the causes of those who allege to be victimised.

SPEECH.PARA: The social costs of such malpractices are enormous. These people are not only broken financially but are also often emotionally, physically, maritally and domestically broken. Some of the actions described to me and cited in these statements have been extremely ruthless. Because these people are broken financially, most of them cannot fight in courts, but some can and have. Many of the cases tabled are now before supreme courts and one is before the High Court of Australia.

We are faced with a problem of enormous consequence. I have today given notice of my intention to refer the matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for a major Senate inquiry to be reported to the Senate by the last sitting day of 1989. To facilitate the assembling of prima facie material, the Australian Democrats have today established a Democrat bank hotline through which the public may offer initial support of this process. I will be asking further questions of the Minister for Justice today and I will continue to advise the Senate of the developments on this matter in most weeks.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPOINTEES TO COMMONWEALTH TRIBUNALS: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The President has received the following message from the House of Representatives:

INTERJECT.PARA: The House of Representatives acquaints the Senate of the following resolution which has been agreed to by the House of Representatives:

That the House concurs in the resolution transmitted in Message No. 303 of the Senate relating to the appointment of a joint select committee to inquire into and report on the principles that should govern the tenure of office of quasi-judicial and other appointees to Commonwealth tribunals and, in particular, to inquire whether the provisions of sections 24 and 28 of the Industrial Relations Act provide proper and adequate provision for the tenure of office of presidential members and commissioners of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.
Sitting suspended from 12.56 p.m. to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of the following comments by Professor Brian Johns, head of the Bureau of Industry Economics in the Minister's Department, published in today's Australian Business, which is actually dated 8 March? The article states:

QUESTION.PARA: By and large the increased investment in the manufacturing sector has not been closely associated with import replacement and export growth. A good deal of the new investment seems to be aimed at cost reduction rather than at the expansion of capacity.
Is this statement by Professor Johns correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not familiar with the statement, but I have had discussions with Professor Johns about this issue over a period. Certainly three months ago that was the view Professor Johns was putting to me regarding some sort of analysis of import statistics. I have had discussions with him quite recently and he has not further advanced that view. I am not saying that it is not still his view; maybe it is. I have forgotten the date Senator Lewis gave.
—Today.

—Yes, but the honourable senator referred to it as having been said two or three weeks ago, or something like that. There is insufficient information-this is certainly what Professor Johns was saying to me three months ago-on which to draw hard conclusions. I think that, on balance, that was his view. That view has been supported to some extent by comments made quite recently by Mr Mohl, of the ANZ Bank on the AM program yesterday or the day before. The view has been expressed in part, I think, by Mr Ray Block, the Chairman of Dominguez, in an article I saw in a newspaper the other day. As I said, in previous discussions with Professor Johns his view was that there was insufficient hard data to draw any definite conclusions.

ANSWER.PARA: I have a quite personal view about all this. We have a problem in Australia in relation to market failure in terms of investment in companies and so on, but I think it is inevitable that in a country with an economy such as this, which is in the process of structural change, that will be partly true. But I cannot quantify it. The honourable senator asked me whether it was correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it your view?

—I am not able to say. I do not think anybody is. Some of the various commentators who talk about this issue are advancing this theory to some extent but others are not. I am not an expert. I cannot express a view on it.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. At this stage does the Minister say that the Government does not share the view on this matter which Professor Johns expressed?

—It is not as simple as that. There has been a very significant increase in investment in productive capacity. Some of it will be increased capacity for exports. Some of it will be an increased capacity in respect of import replacement. Some of it, particularly in the services sector, I suspect, will be in terms of cost reduction. To find a balance between all these elements is very difficult. The fact remains that there has been an enormous and significant investment surge. I do not think sufficient information is available to analyse it in great detail and to draw firm conclusions.

—Is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women aware of recent data from the Women's Electoral Lobby on the importance of child-care provision to women in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT)? Can the Minister comment on child-care provision in the Territory and on recent speculation in the community as to the effect of the Senate's motion of December last year concerning the child-care centre in the Parliamentary Triangle?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Giles has had a long-standing interest in child-care provision, particularly child-care provision within the Parliamentary Triangle. She has worked harder than anybody in this Parliament to ensure that child-care is provided within the Parliamentary Triangle. Her views on the importance of government-subsidised child-care have been endorsed by the majority of respondents to the Women's Electoral Lobby questionnaire that has been circulated recently in the run-up to the Australian Capital Territory local government election, or self-government election.
—I don't think they call it a local government election. You had better get the term right.

—Self-government election. Unfortunately, it appears that not all candidates have bothered to respond to the questionnaire. On the information that I have received, among those candidates who have not responded have been members of the Liberal Party and the National Party. I am prepared to stand corrected on this if there has been some misunderstanding. Perhaps an honourable senator opposite would like to put the record straight. But apparently, on the information given to me at lunchtime, no candidate from either of those parties had responded.

ANSWER.PARA: However, of the candidates who had responded-among those was the Australian Labor Party candidate-there was overwhelming support for government subsidised child-care. It is interesting to note that in a paper that has been circulated on this weekend's forthcoming women's tax convention, the Country Women's Association has gone on the record as supporting government subsidised child-care. Over the last six years, because of the Federal Government's strong commitment to child-care, significant awareness has built up in the community as to the importance of government subsidised child-care.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is like motherhood. Everyone wants it.

—Parenthood. I am sure that Government members do not need to be reminded of the Government's record on child-care. Since 1983 we have increased the number of child-care places from 46,000 to 110,000, which I think even Senator Newman will agree is a very good record. Voters in the Australian Capital Territory will be aware that the number of child-care places in the Australian Capital Territory has increased from 445 to 911, more than double.
—Senator Stone says he doesn't want it to be given to anybody.

—It is of concern that Senator Stone, representing the National Party, is not in favour of government subsidised child-care. But I can assure Opposition members that the Labor Party maintains a strong commitment to government subsidised child-care.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Stone interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps, Mr President, it would be an idea to give Senator Stone the opportunity later to put his views on child-care. As Senator Giles has indicated, this Government's efforts in the ACT include a commitment to a child-care centre in the Parliamentary Triangle, comprising 40 long day care places for working parents in the area and 30 occasional care places to cater for the many visitors to the Parliamentary Triangle. I would like to assure a number of citizens in the ACT that the Senate's recent motion about the construction of a child-care centre facility simply reiterated the procedures that the Government has already put in place. I think it was Senator Reid who raised some concern about whether the Parliament would have the opportunity to comment in relation to where the child-care centre was located, its design, et cetera.

ANSWER.PARA: As stated in this place last year by my colleague Graham Richardson, standing procedures were initiated in early December 1988, ensuring that the construction of a centre in the parliamentary zone was considered by the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House within the terms of the Parliament Act 1974.

The need for a centre in the Parliamentary Triangle has been clearly demonstrated and the expert body responsible for identifying long day care needs in the ACT has identified the Parliamentary Triangle as the area of highest need. I understand that an architect is currently drawing up a proposal which will, of course, go to the Committee later this month.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Government decided in recent days to recognise Mr Ali Kazak as the official representative in Australia of the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO)? If so, when did the Cabinet take this decision and was it endorsed by Caucus? What are the Government's reasons for this major shift in Australia's foreign affairs policy? Why has the decision not, as yet, been officially announced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I stated on 15 December that Yasser Arafat's announcements and commitments in Geneva the previous day in which he unambiguously accepted Israel's right to exist within secure and recognised borders, when he renounced all forms of terrorism and accepted resolutions 242 and 338 as the basis for negotiation with Israel, had satisfied the Australian Government's conditions for direct dealings with the PLO. Against that background, the Government has decided-that was communicated the day before yesterday to Mr Ali Kazak-that it has no objection to the Palestine Information Office being designated in future the Palestine Liberation Organisation Information Office.

ANSWER.PARA: We have taken no decision and communicated no decision about the status of Mr Kazak himself. But the situation is as I have just described it. That has been an executive decision taken by me in consultation with the Prime Minister and communicated in the way that I have described. There is no secret about it. In fact, I gave the text of my letter to Mr Kazak to one of the Jewish newspapers yesterday which expressed interest in this matter and was running a story on the basic theme.

I make it absolutely clear, as I did in the letter to Mr Kazak, that this office has no diplomatic status in the eyes of the Australian Government, that the Government does not recognise the so-called state of Palestine and as a result the office would not be accorded diplomatic or consular status nor any privileges and immunities of the kind one associates with diplomatic offices. As I have said repeatedly, the question of Australian recognition of a Palestinian state, and the diplomatic corollaries of that, will arise only in the context of an overall peace settlement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. Will he table the letter to Mr Kazak? Would he not agree that this decision represents a major shift in Australia's foreign affairs policy? Why has it not been publicly announced? Was the Executive decision endorsed by Caucus?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision announced on 15 December represented a major shift in Australian Government policy for reasons that I made perfectly clear at the time in this Parliament and in a series of public statements. This decision made in recent days and communicated a couple of days ago is a mere corollary of that original decision.
—It is a major extension.

—It is not one such as to justify any particular hoopla. Certainly Senator Puplick, for one, in the course of his recent discussions and dealings throughout the Middle East has had no inhibitions about recognising the implications of the shift in attitude by the PLO that occurred last year. He wants to contribute to the process of dialogue in a constructive way, just as does the Australian Government. We applaud him for it. Senator Short should catch up with the pace that exists all the way around the rest of the world and not be mired in a collection of prejudices which are now clearly outdated by current circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: Yes, I am perfectly happy to table and incorporate in Hansard the letter to Mr Ali Kazak. Let me read into the Hansard the last paragraph of that letter because it helps put in context the Government's decision and corollaries to that decision of the kind that I have just referred to. What I said in the last paragraph was this:

The Government has welcomed the positive development in the PLO's approach to the peace process as expressed by Mr Arafat in Geneva and trusts that its commitments are pervasive and permanent. You will appreciate that any retreat from these commitments in the future, however, will necessarily result in a further review of the Australian Government's position. Our willingness to make the kind of gesture embodied in our acceptance of the renaming of your office is very much contingent on both the letter and spirit of those commitments continuing to be observed.
Mr President, I seek leave to have the letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator The Hon. Gareth Evans Q.C.
Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade
Parliament House
Canberra A.C.T. 2600
28 February 1989
Mr Ali Kazak
Director
Palestine Information Office
27 State Circle
Deakin ACT 2600
Dear Mr Kazak,

In my statement of 15 December 1988 I said that PLO Chairman Arafat's unambiguous statement accepting Israel's right to exist within secure and recognised borders, renouncing terrorism and accepting UN Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338 as the basis for negotiations with Israel had cleared the way for direct dealings between the Government and the PLO by meeting the three conditions set down by the Government.

Consistent with this new approach, and in response to your various representations on the subject, I can now advise you that the Government has no objection to the Palestine Information Office being called the Palestine Liberation Organisation Information Office.

Let me make it absolutely clear, however, that since the Government does not recognise the ``state of Palestine'', your office will not be accorded diplomatic or consular status nor any privileges and immunities. As I have said previously, the question of Australian recognition of a ``Palestinian state'' will arise only in the context of an overall peace settlement.

The Government has welcomed the positive development in the PLO's approach to the peace process as expressed by Mr Arafat in Geneva and trusts that its commitments are pervasive and permanent. You will appreciate that any retreat from these commitments in the future, however, will necessarily result in a further review of the Australian Government's position. Our willingness to make the kind of gesture embodied in our acceptance of the renaming of your office is very much contingent on both the letter and spirit of those commitments continuing to be observed.
Yours sincerely,
Gareth Evans

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Consumer Affairs report on progress of government efforts to achieve greater cooperation between the financial counsellors and the finance industry and on possible industry funding of credit education and research?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Devereux raises a question which has been of concern to me over the last 12 months. There has been a recognition in the community that financial counselling groups and facilities are limited by a number of factors. The case workload they carry and the scarce resources they have have led to a basic problem that credit education and research is a function that is often not addressed as highly as it should be. There is also a recognition in industry, as well as in consumer groups, that training for financial counsellors and finance industry staff could be improved to address a basic problem in the community, that is, providing consumers with more information on their credit facilities.

ANSWER.PARA: Basically the underlying acceptance by consumer and industry groups at the consumer forum held in Canberra last year was that a greater degree of credit education and research would be of great assistance to all involved in this field. There was also an acknowledgment by industry that it felt it had a role to play in this area. Since the forum, which I said was held in the middle of last year, there have been a number of talks between my office, the finance industry and consumer groups with a view to setting up some sort of mechanism for the development of credit education and research. In fact, the ultimate goal is to set up a foundation for credit education and research.

I am pleased to say that in recent days we have reached agreement with a number of industry organisations and consumer groups to do a number of things in this area. The industry groups involved are the Australian Bankers Association, the Australian Federation of Credit Unions, the Australian Finance Conference Ltd, the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies and the American Express corporation. They, together with consumer groups, have agreed to form part of a working group to investigate the establishment of such a foundation.

The task force has been given an amount of $40,000 by industry and is expected to report some time in the middle of this year. Basically the task force will be looking at two major factors involved in the establishment of a foundation. One is the preparation of guidelines to cover key areas of training, credit education and research. The task force will also look at the determination of funding targets for the maintenance of the foundation for a minimum of three years.

I take this opportunity to thank those in the industry as well as those in the consumer movement for the cooperative way in which they have approached this matter. A number of key individuals in the industry have very keenly taken on this project and they should be given credit for their cooperation. As a government, we welcome this positive response from all sides of the consumer credit area, particularly industry. Underlying it all is an acknowledgment that by working together the sorts of problems that governments alone would find it almost impossible to address can be addressed with the cooperation of industry and consumer organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Justice, first, whether the Australian Federal Police (AFP) is currently investigating any allegations of improper conduct by officers of Australian banking institutions. Secondly, is the Federal Police investigating any aspects of the alleged corrupt practices by officers of the Commonwealth Bank which allegation was tabled in the Senate last December, particularly, at this stage, in relation to Ms Batiste and Mr Rigg? Thirdly, has the AFP investigated any aspects of the hundreds of cases of bankruptcy resulting from the recent so-called forex or foreign loans scam. Fourthly, in view of the devastating impact upon farming communities of premature foreclosures by banks, illustrated by a recent Eyre Peninsula public meeting which attracted 1,000 locals, and as documented in the rural credit inquiry in New South Wales, does the Government acknowledge the magnitude of the credit problem among farmers and its possible reflection of and/or potential for malpractice? Fifthly, does the Minister's press release of 13 February 1989 indicate a change of attitude since he assured the Senate on 15 December 1988 that he took the allegations extremely seriously and would give them his personal attention? Finally, as the 27 signed statements already tabled are likely soon to become 100 or more, will the Minister assure the Senate that he has not pre-empted his attitude or the attitude of the Federal Police to any cases of alleged corruption in banking practices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with the fourth part of Senator McLean's question first. As honourable senators are aware, the question of regulation of the financial sector is one for my colleague the Treasurer. I suggest that Senator McLean direct this part of his question to the relevant Minister. I turn now to those parts of the six-part question which come within my portfolio responsibilities.

ANSWER.PARA: Firstly, Senator McLean asked a very broad question about whether the Federal Police is currently investigating any allegations of improper conduct by officers of Australian banking institutions. Whilst the answer in a general sense is yes, as all honourable senators are aware, the broad charter of AFP responsibilities means that it is almost impossible to give a detailed and definite response to this question in its widest interpretation. Investigations into breaches of various Commonwealth laws may involve the examination of allegations of improper conduct by officers in banking institutions. For example, drug investigations which include following the money trail quite obviously would require examining banking records. It is a very general question and I do not want Senator McLean to misunderstand my answer yes.

In the second part of his question, Senator McLean specifically referred to alleged corrupt practices detailed in documents tabled by him in the Senate last year. I am advised that the Federal Police is not investigating any aspect of those allegations. The reason will become clear in a moment; it has already done so.

In the third part of his question Senator McLean talks about the so-called forex or foreign loans scam. The AFP has been unable to provide me with information on this matter without specific details identifying to what Senator McLean was referring. For example, I refer to an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald headed `Forex loan bank ``advised sales and patience'' ' which reports on a Federal Court hearing. It apparently relates to a civil action seeking redress on bank advice. If any of the documents tabled earlier today by Senator McLean-which, of course, I will refer to the AFP-relate to this alleged foreign loans scam, I would expect that I would receive advice from the AFP on whether there is evidence that Commonwealth criminal offences are involved, as opposed to the breach of fiduciary relationship and so on which Senator McLean has spoken on in the media.

As to the other parts of Senator McLean's question, I resent the suggestion in the latter part of his question that I have changed my attitude to the matter concerned since I indicated to the Senate on 8 December, not 15 December, that I took these matters seriously and would give them my personal attention. In context, my undertaking there was in response to his assertion that the Australian Federal Police had failed in its duty to investigate certain matters. Of course, I took the matter seriously and as a matter of course referred all the material to the AFP. On the same afternoon of 8 December, I directly raised with Commissioner McAulay personally Senator McLean's allegations that these matters had for several years been known to the Federal Police and that it was claimed that it had failed in its duties. I received briefings as a result, the substance of which I conveyed to Senator McLean privately. He nevertheless asked a series of questions on 15 December, in response to which I was able to refute his allegation that the AFP had perhaps deliberately briefed me in a grossly inadequate way, to use Senator McLean's terms. Indeed, Senator McLean must have been satisfied with my response on that day, because he did not renew the allegations on any of the many remaining sitting days of that session, nor has he since.

There is no evidence in the history of my dealing with this matter, as known to the Senate, and it is not queried by Senator McLean therefore, which should provide any basis for his now more obnoxious imputation that I may have colluded with the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank that the AFP should confine its investigation of the matters raised by Senator McLean last December in order to take the heat out of the issue because I wanted the issue defused. This allegation against me is made in Senator McLean's press release on 13 February after he had received my press release of the same date which quite properly told the public the following:
Australian Federal Police investigators have found no evidence to back up allegations made last year concerning improper activities by employees of the Commonwealth Bank.
I made it clear in that press release that the AFP had reviewed a number of matters raised in the Senate in December, yet Senator McLean chose in his press release to state the following:
The Minister has referred to a single case which is even now the subject of litigation in the New South Wales Courts and was only one among those I raised in the Senate in December.

It will be clear to honourable senators that I did not refer merely to a single case, I was responding to advice to me from the Federal Police that it was currently unaware of any evidence which would support charges relating to improper activities of employees of the bank. The conclusion reached by the AFP came after examination of all the documentation tabled and the allegations made by Senator McLean.

The Managing Director of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, Mr Sanders, wrote to me on 22 December 1988 making the obvious point that Senator McLean's references had been most damaging to the reputation of the bank and its officers. He asked that in the interests of justice and the bank I resolve matters and make a statement as quickly as possible. Of course I was happy to make such a statement as soon as possible, but only in the light of a fully considered examination by the AFP of the matters raised by Senator McLean. I was informed of the result of that examination six weeks later and had no hesitation in informing the public, including Commonwealth Bank customers, that there was no evidence to support Senator McLean's allegations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. It relates to the Government's partnership for development program. Given the importance of that program for the information industries sector, which promises to add over $4 billion to Australia's trading account by the mid-1990s, does the Minister consider that serious doubts have been raised about the partnership's program by media commentators, including last Monday week's Four Corners program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not consider that serious doubts have been raised in anybody's mind as a result of the Four Corners program. Unfortunately, some of the criticism of the partnership concept, particularly as expressed on the Four Corners program, was founded on a farrago of factual errors and misconceptions. The factual errors have been pointed out to the producers of the program in writing.

ANSWER.PARA: I was, however, disturbed by one aspect of the Four Corners program which singled out Wang, one of the partnership companies. I just make the point that Wang has a very sound record in discharging it obligations under the partnership program and commenced in the partnership with a very substantial offsets credit. Wang is working with some two dozen local companies in Australia to achieve its partnership targets. The recent first annual audit or review showed it had over achieved in both exports and research and development investment. Therefore, the Government is very pleased with Wang's performance and believes that it is fully committed to the partnership program.

Since the Four Corners program, my Department has received reaffirmations of commitment to the partnership program from most of the partners. Some of the local beneficiary companies have also expressed concern about the way in which their activities were presented on the program. Last Friday, at a meeting of State and Federal industry Ministers, the program also received the support of all Ministers. I am pleased to say that in the past week, following the Four Corners program, two further partnership agreements have been signed with Pyramid Technology (Australia) Pty Ltd and GEC-Plessey Telecommunications. There will be more signatories in the coming months.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION: WODEN TOWN CLUB LIABILITIES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports in the Australian of 18 and 19 February and the Canberra Times of 21 February purporting to set out the liabilities the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) has assumed, or agreed to assume, on behalf of the Woden Town Club? What commitments has the ADC, in fact, entered into? What is the total indebtedness of the Woden Town Club to the ADC and to all other creditors? What guarantees has the ADC currently in effect in respect of the Woden Town Club?
—I shall refer that question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Finance. Has the Government received any information at an official level from Queensland in relation to the administration of natural disaster assistance in that State following yesterday's allegations of misuse of this funding? If so, what is that information?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not received any information at an official level, although officials from the Department of Finance did contact the Queensland Treasury this morning requesting information about the allegations which have been made in Queensland in the last couple of days. However, I have received from the Queensland Department of Primary Industries a copy of a report which is presumably leaked from the drought secretariat and is addressed to inspectors of stock. That report does tend to confirm some of the worst fears and suspicions I have had for some time about the administration of drought relief in Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: Notwithstanding Mr Ahern's comments on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation this morning that this is just a political stunt, there is very clearly recognition among those people who are actually administering the scheme that there are some very serious problems. First, the document notes that drought assistance is available only to properties affected by an extreme lack of rain. It states:
Properties exhibiting drought symptoms due to mismanagement are not experiencing a natural disaster.

He then goes on to describe some things which are neither natural disasters nor mismanagement. They are clear rorts of the system. I table the document, but I do draw attention to a number of highlights within it. Pressure is exerted for early isolated drought proclamation declarations for mismanagers, `get-in-for-your-cut' people, and 36aaa tax users. IDPs are given earlier, increasing the frequency of drought declarations and the provision of assistance for non-disaster periods. There is no check on the stock carried and some IDPs have been issued when it is subsequently found that properties are stocked at twice the normal stocking rate.

Once one of a number of properties under the same ownership is drought declared, it provides a means for laundering stock between properties to maximise subsidy payments. Once a number of IDPs have been issued, pressure develops to have the whole shire drought declared. People get kudos by pushing for an area declaration and drought assistance is thereby extended to non-droughted properties. Since 1964, when existing drought declaration procedures were adopted, many areas have been drought declared on an average of once every three years and have remained drought declared for 50 per cent of the time. In other words, normality is defined as drought, which is standing truth on its head.

Agistment movements are subsidised for trips of 1,500 to 2,000 kilometres when alternative reasonable agistment is available within 500 kilometres. A so-called agistment movement from a droughted to a non-droughted property under the same ownership can trigger a whole series of reagistment movements to other properties under the same ownership. The physical identity of stock can change along the way. Some properties return twice the number of stock that went to agistment on the transport subsidy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you reading from?

—I am reading highlights from a report from the Queensland Department of Primary Industries drought office, addressed to stock inspectors in Queensland. It is headed, `Subject: Drought Assistance Anomalies'. I have already tabled this document, so the honourable senator will be able to read it. I would be surprised if there were much revealed in there which Senator Boswell did not already know. Normal sales are disguised as drought sales and restocking subsidies are paid for normal restocking movements. That provides a double dip on the subsidy. And so it goes on.

ANSWER.PARA: In conclusion, I want to read a quote about the select few who have been receiving the benefits of the bulk of these rorts:
It can be seen that the pickings are worthwhile for those prepared to have a go. Indications are that most people are honest . . .
I interpolate, even in Queensland most people remain honest. It is those who operate the system who seem to be under suspicion. To continue the quote:

. . . and many do not make subsidy claims for all eligible movements. In a drought when $15m was paid out in subsidies, 84% of subsidy users received subsidies of $5,000 or less and the remaining 16% of users received 76% of all subsidy payments. The 16% tended to be larger properties who have more opportunities to work deficiencies in the system.

If I may add to that, these people probably have better contacts in the National Party. Not surprisingly, since it was prepared within the Queensland bureaucracy, this report does not address the question of the occasions on which the administering committee has properly applied the rules and guidelines and then subsequently had those decisions overturned by ministerial directive.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I refer the Minister to the Women's Electoral Lobby (WEL) paper `A fair go in the tax system' for Saturday's Women's Tax Convention, which points out that the paper was prepared under the assumption that tax cuts were intended in 1989, but which explicitly states:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . we should prefer to see taxation increased rather than decreased overall in order to fund more programs which result in socially just outcomes.

I further refer the Minister to the Government's National Agenda for Women released last year, which points out that a government's economic policies are the best way to ensure a bright and secure future for all Australians. Given the difference between the tax more, spend more, program-oriented view of the Women's Electoral Lobby and the Government's macro-economic approach, will the Minister explain the reasoning behind those elements of the Government's economic strategy which lead her to conclude that WEL is wrong and Keating is right?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that Senator Vanstone is monitoring the views of the Women's Electoral Lobby and I hope that she and other members of the Opposition will be attending the Women's Tax Convention on Saturday.
—We got a notice last week.

—Good. I think Senator Vanstone would agree that, given that the Women's Tax Convention has been called specifically to enable women in the community to express their views, and quite specifically for politicians to keep out of the actual forum, it will be inappropriate for me to comment and create a great deal of speculation in the run-up to the convention on Saturday. It is a forum for women from a wide range of community organisations to express their views. If I tried to come down here today on one side or the other, that would be particularly unhelpful to the debate that will occur within that forum. The point of the forum that is being hosted jointly by the National Women's Consultative Council and Women's Electoral Lobby is so that a wide range of women's organisations representatives representing over 250,000 women throughout Australia can express their views. This is not the first time that such an occasion has been held. It will not be the first time that the Government has listened to the views being expressed by women in the community.
—Then ignored them.
—If Senator Newman had been around in Canberra in 1985, she would know that on that occasion at the women's tax summit--
—I was there and I didn't see you.

—I was there, Senator. You and I must have missed each other. I am sorry about that. I was reminding Senator Newman and members of the Opposition that in 1985 women came together in relation to their complete opposition to the consumption tax, for which Senator Vanstone has subsequently indicated some support. I know that she has muddied the waters in that regard, but in 1985 women at the women's tax summit, as it was called in 1985, came together on that particular issue.
