What the Women's Tax Convention will determine in terms of its recommendations on Saturday is not for me to say; it is not for Senator Vanstone to say; it is certainly not for members of the Opposition to say; and it certainly is not for Paul Keating or the Prime Minister to say. It is an opportunity for women to express their views about the current wage tax debate. We know that men in the community have many forums in which to express their views. In the business community, which is predominantly comprised of men and very much male dominated, men are expressing their views all the time. While there are some women expressing their views in the trade union movement, again it is dominated by men.

ANSWER.PARA: This is an important occasion-an artificial occasion, if you like, as was said today on the Ray Martin program-until we get more women speaking out in the forums of the business community, the trade union community and, indeed, in this Parliament. So I am afraid Senator Vanstone will have to wait for some considerable time for my direct response to that question for the simple reason that the Women's Tax Convention will, firstly, make recommendations on Saturday.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have waited a long time already.

—Those recommendations will be presented to the Prime Minister on Wednesday, International Women's Day. How those views are integrated into the eventual Government response will be something that we will all know in the future. I will be part of that response, but I am certainly not going to be canvassing my views or the Government's views in the lead-up to a forum that is for women to put their views.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of her response, I ask the Minister: Does she appreciate how tokenistic it is to suggest that women should come and be given the opportunity to have their say but, according to the Minister, only in a vacuum because the one person who could put the Government's view with respect to economic policy, or who is in the position to put it and ought to be able to put it, is herself, and she could give them the opportunity to discuss these matters and give an informed view, not in a vacuum, but in light of the Government's views? Does the Minister appreciate that point? Secondly, does she appreciate that whatever Keating is pulling, it is not the right levers on the economy? Does she realise how depressing it is to have in Cabinet a woman who, when given the opportunity to address some of the hard issues facing women-namely, the economy-simply refuses to answer?
—Order! Senator Vanstone, that is not a question. You are making a statement.

—Mr President, I have asked two questions thus far and I have one more question to ask. Finally, having asked those two questions, which I would appreciate a response to, I ask: Whilst she need not delude herself by overestimating her capacity to drive the economy like Keating does, will she at least demonstrate that she has a licence to comment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really would recommend that Senator Vanstone talk to the organisers of this conference, because they will tell her--

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Vanstone interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously Senator Vanstone does not appreciate the role of the National Women's Consultative Council.
—Yes, we do.

—Senator Chaney accused me of taking too long a little while ago and I am afraid I will have to take a little longer. This particular Tax Convention is not the Government's tax convention, it is not my tax convention or Paul Keating's tax convention. It is a tax convention that is being hosted by the National Women's Consultative Council, which I have said is a Government appointed body to reflect the views of the women of Australia. It is appointed; it is funded. But I have been at pains to state to it and to Senator Vanstone that it is an independent body that is organising this forum, in conjunction with the Women's Electoral Lobby, and it is up to that convention to determine who it invites. It did not ask me to present a paper on government policy. It did not ask me to set the Government's position. It asked me to attend and listen to what women are saying about a whole range of issues. It will make the recommendations which will be heard by the Prime Minister and will be incorporated in the lead-up to decisions relating to the wage/tax debate. What more could we have?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade reconcile Australia's vote in favour of agenda item 64 on international arms transfers in the First Committee Meeting of the United Nations (UN) General Assembly in November last year with moves announced by the Minister for Defence to promote the export of arms and defence equipment and with forthcoming government legislation designed to relax defence export controls? I further ask the Minister how the Government can reconcile these moves to promote defence exports with the statement made by his predecessor, Mr Hayden, at the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament in June 1988, when he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: It is also clear that arms exports should not be turned to as a way of solving domestic economic problems. Arms transfers must not become a new cash crop.

I also ask whether he agrees with the article on the front page of the Australian Financial Review of 14 June 1988 which stated that the only major dissent to the fundamental changes in our attitude to defence exports came from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and that exports of anything, including so-called defence material, are now regarded as in the national interest? Finally, I ask the Minister: In light of these contradictions, is the Government still planning to go ahead with legislation designed to promote the doubling of defence exports in the next three to five years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no contradictions. The defence export policy announced by my colleague the Minister for Defence last June is entirely consistent with Australia's vote at the 1988 United Nations General Assembly. The UN resolution calls on countries to control the production and transport of defence exports and to refrain from acquiring arms additional to those legitimately required for national security. The resolution advocates greater openness about international arms transfers and asks the Secretary-General to report on such aspects as the illicit arms trade.

ANSWER.PARA: The policy announced by Mr Beazley on 14 June last year streamlines administrative arrangements for requests for approval to export. The defence exports remain subject, however, to rigorous controls in accordance with existing legislation and in accordance with new Customs legislation which will enhance the powers of the Minister for Defence to control defence exports. That legislation was introduced late last year and I believe that it will be debated in the next week or so in the House of Representatives.

The new policy places controls on exports of those goods specifically designed or adapted for military purposes which are inherently lethal, incapacitating, destructive or of major military significance. It tightly defines a whole series of circumstances precluding defence exports, such as mandatory arms embargoes, international sanctions and violations of human rights. The details of those criteria were spelt out at great length in the attachment to Mr Beazley's press release of last June, to which I refer the honourable senator. The policy provides for full consultation between the Ministers for Defence, Foreign Affairs and Trade, Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Attorney-General. The policy also provides for the publication of export guidelines, which will occur some time in the near future, while allowing for commercial confidentiality, greater transparency and openness.

Under these conditions and circumstances defence exports do not conflict with the Government's firm commitment to protecting and enhancing national, regional and international security through arms control and disarmament measures-a commitment to which Senator Vallentine referred and which she has acknowledged. One of the underlying justifications for defence exports is that, until there is an alternative to the current international security situation, all national governments have the right-indeed the obligation-to defend their peoples and territories. Legitimate self-defence is embodied in the United Nations charter. International peace and security can most effectively be advanced-another point of view-if nations are confident about their security. To the extent that Australian defence exports contribute to all those objectives they are defensible in accordance with principles which I believe we would accept.

From a more narrow commercial perspective, the encouragement of defence exports can contribute to the development of our domestic industrial base, which enhances Australia's overall defence self-reliance as well as our economic position. Finally, defence exports will continue to be strictly controlled and will reflect a balanced assessment of Australia's economic, strategic, defence and foreign policy interests.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications aware that the Wilshire program on Sydney radio station 2GB has used commentators on current affairs who include the former Deputy Director of the League of Rights, which has been widely criticised for its anti-semitic and racist comments? Peter Sawyer has also made the most outrageous and false allegations: an imminent one-world government with its headquarters in Parliament House; a violent uprising and civil unrest in Australia, which would require a civilian militia; unfounded criticism and defamation of many leading figures in Australian politics and business; and the allegation that the Deakin Centre was the site of a national surveillance network. Lately he has been promoting Mr Wilshire as a potential independent Senate candidate in New South Wales. Peter Sawyer has also been linked with the League of Rights and has heavily promoted the Citizens Electoral Council movement. Bob Clarke, the former President of the New South Wales Immigration Control Association and current head of New South Wales Greypower has recently been reported as having links with extreme racist groups and activities. Is the Minister further aware that pirate tapes of the Wilshire program are being circulated by League of Rights supporters with Mr Wilshire's knowledge? I ask the Minister to examine whether commentary from these sources constitutes a breach of radio program standards which state in part that a licensee may not transmit a program which:

QUESTION.PARA: (a) is likely to incite or perpetuate hatred against; or
(b) gratuitously vilifies; any person or group on the basis of ethnic origin, nationality, race or religion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was aware of the generally poor reputation of the Wilshire radio program on 2GB, although I must confess that I was not aware, until Senator Boswell listed them, that he had such a formidable collection of ratbags giving commentaries on that program. I will refer the specific question of the program and whether it breaches Australian Broadcasting Tribunal standards to the Minister for Transport and Communications and give Senator Boswell a response as soon as possible. His particular reference to the program is worth picking up. The program advancing the potential Senate candidacy of Mr Wilshire raises a larger question of political wolves in sheep's clothing which I think is useful for us to be alerted to, not least in the context of the present Australian Capital Territory election campaign. I am led to believe that, among the collection of anti-self-government candidates in this election campaign, there is a number of people with quite significant League of Rights connections which have so far been unacknowledged in the public arena. I think it would be a tragedy if voters were inadvertently to support such persons in ignorance of their true positions-people masquerading under a different guise. But, as I have said, it raises larger questions. I will refer to the Minister the specific issues that have been put to me by Senator Boswell and seek an early response.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Has a decision been made to lease the Bruce Stadium to the Canberra Raiders Rugby League Club? What costs were involved in developing the main track at the Bruce Stadium for athletics and in overcoming problems with wind effects on the performance of athletes? What source of funds was used to develop the Bruce Stadium for athletics? If a decision has been made, or is expected to be made, to lease the Bruce Stadium to the Canberra Raiders what costs will be involved in ripping up the athletics track and making the stadium a suitable venue for rugby league matches? What source of funds will be needed to redevelop the stadium for this purpose? Will athletics activities be transferred to the warm-up track at the Bruce Stadium if the main track is ripped up to make the stadium a suitable venue for rugby league matches? Is it true that the warm-up track has deteriorated because of the high level of use and is not suitably wind protected for significant athletic competition? Finally, what costs would be involved if the warm-up track were to be repaired, upgraded and made suitable for significant athletic competition? If such action is proposed, what will be the source of funds to make this redevelopment possible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Along with a few other senators, I will be glad when the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) election is out of the road and we do not have to have campaign points taken up in the Senate by some people who will find that their party is doing extremely poorly once the election results are announced.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am trying to give a serious answer to this question. I was asked whether a decision had been made to lease Bruce Stadium to the Canberra Raiders. The answer is no. The decision was taken by the Government to lease Bruce Stadium to the ACT Administration. That is the extent, thus far, of what the Government has done. Obviously, I would expect a decision to be made at some time in the near future by the ACT Administration to lease the facility to the Canberra Raiders.

ANSWER.PARA: I was then asked what costs were involved in developing the main track at Bruce Stadium for athletics. The first stage of Bruce Stadium was completed in June 1977 at a cost of $6.5m and an upgrade of that facility was completed in September 1985 at a cost of $8.4m. All these funds were supplied by the National Capital Development Commission. At the time no special consideration was given to wind factors.

I was asked whether a decision was expected to be made to lease the grounds and what costs would be involved in ripping up the athletics track and making the stadium suitable for rugby league. The estimated cost for modifying the stadium is $3 1/2m-a not inconsiderable sum. Of course, this would cover not simply making the ground suitable for rugby league but also the construction of facilities for spectators and appropriate dressing rooms for the players. The situation is not yet entirely clear because the brief on costs is not totally finished. When it is and I have some more final and definite figures I will give them to the honourable senator and to the Senate. But that is all the information I have at the moment.

Senator Jenkins asked whether athletic activities will be transferred to the warm-up track at Bruce Stadium. The answer is yes. She also asked whether it is true that the warm-up track has deteriorated because of the high level of use and is not suitably wind protected for significant athletic competition. That is not true. The warm-up track is in good condition and it is adequately protected from the wind. That is not to say that we can ever protect athletes from the wind in an outdoor facility. That is why there are rules in athletics about wind assistance for when records can and cannot be set. Clearly, while they are not totally protected from the wind--

TALK.START.PARA: —The same rules apply for longwinded answers.

DEBATE.TITLE: CHICKEN MEAT RESEARCH COUNCILTOBACCO RESEARCH COUNCILCOTTON RESEARCH COUNCILGRAPE AND WINE RESEARCH COUNCILDAIRY RESEARCH COUNCILGRAIN LEGUMES RESEARCH COUNCILPIG RESEARCH COUNCILHONEY RESEARCH COUNCILSUGAR RESEARCH COUNCILOILSEEDS RESEARCH COUNCIL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

Dealing with the reports together gives us an opportunity to contemplate the research councils generally and the work they do. Reading all the reports on one day certainly shows the differences that exist between the various organisations. I believe that, if we can see those differences and learn from them, some of the councils can probably do likewise. I note that some councils are running administration costs from as little as about 5 per cent of their turnover and that for others the figure is 12 per cent or more. It is noticeable that the goals of the various groups vary quite widely. Surely, the aims of the various councils should be similar. I would have thought that they would include matters such as improving the product, ensuring the health of the animals or plants involved, combating disease, improving returns to producers, adding to the presentation, securing better markets and so on.

The quality of the presentation and the amount of information that is given by the various groups varies considerably. I believe that the Parliament-as well as the people who actually pay their contributions as producers-is entitled to a lot better information than that which is coming through universally. The expectations and operations are not covered adequately. I was disappointed most of all with the Sugar Research Council's report. It provided virtually no information on what the Council is doing in any way, shape or form. It gave the titles under which the objectives of the various projects are operated, but no more. I would suggest to that organisation that it give more information. The aims are stated but the results are not. Many of the others have shortcomings to some extent in the same area.

I notice that the rural industry research councils hold an annual meeting to which the chairmen go. It is very interesting that they should go. I hope that they are able to discuss their own operations in a group and can learn from one another. I would like to know whether that group of chairmen produce an annual report. If so, it would be highly desirable for us to get a copy. In the overview of the report of the Chicken Meat Research Council I found this extraordinary comment:

In line with the basic philosophy of the Plan, research in marketing, new product development and transportation were considered to be the responsibility of individual particpants in the industry. Accordingly, research has not been sponsored by the Council in these areas.

If the development of new products, transportation and research in marketing were not included by the Research Council, I would find it quite extraordinary. Surely in this important industry the participants could benefit considerably if these vital ingredients were included.

The grain legumes industry and the pig industry have both done very well in recent years because their research and presentation have been well above average. The nature and extent of their research has always been well organised, and this has been shown to be the case. The Oilseeds Council probably has provided the best information of all, and the follow-up remarks in relation to its investigations are very worthwhile. I believe that we are entitled to know how well these research operations have gone and what the results have been. The participants in the industry need to be told which ones have been successful and which have not. I believe that it is possible to reflect in these summaries the amount of cash by which the industry can benefit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments on the Grape and Wine Research Council's annual report 1987-88. I see from the early part of the report that Mr Brian Croser, the Managing Director of Petaluma Pty Ltd, a winery in my State, is a member of the Council. I know him to be a gentleman who contributes tirelessly to his industry; it is an industry in which most of the contributors are prepared to work together for the betterment of the industry. This can be seen from the Chairman's summary, which points out that the three main wine industry organisations involved, namely, the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association, the Australian Wine Makers Forum Inc. and the Wine and Brandy Cooperative Producers, have all agreed that the operative rate of the research component of the wine grapes levy should be increased to $1.50 per tonne. The report contains some reasonable detail on the work to be undertaken by the Council and the work it has undertaken thus far.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of problems face the wine industry-five in particular-not all of which can be addressed by the Council. One relates to raw material supply, which is a constant problem because of the changing tastes of Australian and overseas wine drinkers. The problems of technical and labelling integrity are, in my view, yet to be properly addressed by the Australian wine industry. A third issue is that of health. Certain bureaucrats and lobby groups have decided to target the wine industry as being a very significant cause of ill health in the country. Sometimes one can get the view, if one is in the wine industry or is a supporter of it, that the wine industry is targeted vis-a-vis alcohol whereas those who make and sell spirits and beer seem to get off rather lightly.

The fourth issue is that of taxation, on which I wish to make a few remarks, particularly as to the case for having section 31a reassessed. There has been a campaign in my State to have something done about this matter. The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has taken the opportunity on a number of occasions to put this view with respect to the valuation of wine stocks. It is a pity that the Grape and Wine Council cannot with the resources at hand-perhaps it has not given the matter high enough priority-carry out some research on how to influence politicians from States which are not big wine producers to understand the extent of the problem.

Senator Walsh could well do with some education in this respect. He believes that the wine industry should be treated no differently from the building industry. His view is that the value of building stocks has to appear in reports in the building industry and that the wine industry should adopt a similar course. However, he needs to understand that for quality wine to be sold it has to be aged. Although Senator Walsh obviously believes that this is not a matter that needs to be addressed, he might like to concern himself with the activities of the Premier of South Australia, Mr Bannon, who has sought to discuss this matter with the wine industry. I hope that Mr Bannon decides to make a protest to the Federal Government aimed at persuading it to reconsider its attitude. I further hope that the Grape and Wine Research Council will be able to do some concrete research to show the Government what has been the impact of the changed tax structures on the wine industry and to stress how much better off the wine industry will be if the Government realises the error of its ways.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I wish to comment on the report of the Research Council's Selection Committee. I have found a paragraph which I believe should appear in Hansard. Mr Kevin J. Foley, Chairman of the Research Councils Selection Committee, in his letter to the Minister, the Hon. John Kerin, says very touchingly:

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, at the risk of embarrassing both of us, I should say that the vast bulk of the extraordinary commitment made by Selection Committee members and staff was driven by a personal commitment to yourself. Suffice it to say that I regard it as a privilege to have worked for you and to work on a project which will have such a lasting and profound effect on Australia's capacity to survive the rigours of the highly competitive international marketplace in which we now find ourselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on the annual report of the Australian Postal Commission for 1987-88. The report is most important at this time because, as honourable senators will be well aware, the form of management of the Australian Postal Commission is undergoing some very radical changes. Those changes, naturally, are brought about by the policies of the Government, which has now required there to be a considerable reform relating to the area of management. The Government has now imposed excise, payroll tax and customs duty and sales tax on the Australian postal system. This, of course, will force up the cost of postal services over the next few years. Unfortunately any increase in charges in the postal area has a negative effect in remote areas of Australia, particularly in the Northern Territory, which I represent, where people naturally rely more on postal services for their communications.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that we look at the needs of the Australian Postal Commission. This matter was alluded to recently in some quite controversial media coverage. The implication was made that Australia Post might be looking to close down a number of remote postal offices around Australia. I am pleased to have received some very high level briefings from Australia Post which have largely allayed my fears in that regard. I am now convinced that the long term services of Australia Post will be maintained and improved wherever possible. In the Northern Territory Australia Post is already proposing to upgrade its equipment and mail processing systems. I certainly support the changes, such as the use of post office box systems in agency arrangements, particularly in very remote communities, where they could enhance a number of services to remote communities. In a place such as the Northern Territory where the impact of tourism makes extra demands on the poste restante services at an extremely high cost to Australia Post, it is interesting that Australia Post is introducing specific electronic services tailored to meet the needs of poste restante and, of course, the mail distribution systems for the business community.

Australia Post is having to undergo these reviews as a result of the financial imposts that have been put on it-such as the very significant staff changes. I commend both the management and the people who serve remote areas of Australia. The postie and, of course, all of the associated staff bring very welcome intimate services that are so very needed in so many areas.

I would challenge Australia Post in a couple of areas. The first challenge is to improve its communication systems with industry, particularly small business, in Australia. When changes of this nature are imposed or otherwise brought about it is necessary that there be a lead time and that advance notice is given in respect of matters relating to the communications systems that are undergoing change. There needs to be a very detailed and comprehensive review.

The second matter I ask Australia Post to consider right around Australia is the tailoring of its trading hours to meet local demand, even if this means opening some post offices or post office agencies in the evenings and, in some places, possibly Saturday mornings. I appreciate that economic considerations have to be borne in mind in considering these matters. In particular, there would need to be extensive union consultation. We do not live in a time when 9 to 5 from Monday to Friday is always the appropriate way of doing business. The private sector has recognised this. If Australia Post is to be forced into dealing more like a private institution, it should be open to the need for very dramatic change that often exists. One way Australia Post could enhance the services it gives to Australia is a comprehensive review and extension of its trading hours.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND COMMISSIONER JAWOYN (KATHERINE AREA) LAND CLAIM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

We have recently seen a negotiated agreement package in the Northern Territory which brings together the interests of government, of Northern Territory people-expressed through their properly constituted government, the Northern Territory Government-and of the Aboriginal community largely in the Katherine area known colloquially as the Jawoyn. These issues are raised in this very important report on the Jawoyn (Katherine area) land claim. I applaud the fact that the parties have been able to react to the Commissioner's findings, which were very extensive; a number of very important comments were picked up. In fact, I commend Justice Kearney's report for the consideration of all honourable senators. The Katherine Gorge is included in the area covered and, as most people would be aware, this is one of the most significant national parks in the Northern Territory, if not in Australia.

The importance of the national park cannot be overstated. It currently enjoys visits from about 75,000 people each year. About 20,000 of those people camp overnight at the gorge or at Edith Falls. There are over 250 kilometres of walking trails which are used extensively by hikers and day trippers. So the park is used extensively by Territorians, interstate visitors and overseas tourists. Commissioner Kearney commented on a whole range of areas of possible detriment if the park was not properly managed, and these matters have now been picked up. I refer to the issue of its proximity to Katherine, a quite significant urban town, and in particular that town's future water resources. Both these matters were commented on.

The parties have been able to come together and negotiate a form of management that is now satisfactory to all of those parties. In fact, at a recent and quite public press event, members of the Jawoyan working party and the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Mr Marshall Perron, announced the successful conclusion of the 18 months of negotiation with regard to this national park. As a result, the Northern Territory Government will legislate for a joint management arrangement which will secure access to the park for all people and guarantee the future water supply needs of Katherine. The Aboriginal people of the Jawoyn working party also commented at that press conference that they were happy with their negotiations with the Northern Territory Government, the Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory and the Northern Land Council on behalf of Aboriginal people. So this has been an example of appropriate local decision making and of negotiations resulting in arrangements which are very satisfactory to all people. Of course, the history of Katherine Gorge and this particular land claim was fraught with a lot of difficulty, frustration and very serious and at times controversial media and community comment. I certainly commend the report and the arrangements that have fallen into place between all the parties.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: FUTURE DIRECTIONS FOR PAY TELEVISION IN AUSTRALIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 March, on motion by Senator Lewis:
That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak on this report, entitled Future Directions for Pay Television in Australia. There is a great deal of commercial interest in the introduction of pay television in Australia. The Federal Government will be allowing certain groups and companies to operate pay television. We must be very careful as to who those groups are and what services they provide. We must consider how those services will impact on the community in general. Page xvii of the executive summary states:

SPEECH.PARA: There are, however, likely to be some significant community concerns about the introduction of pay television. These concerns could include a belief that we do not need, or there is no demand for, more television services, or that the introduction of new services is an inappropriate use of community resources. Some may consider that pay television will reduce the time available for more rewarding activities such as family interaction, recreation and homework. A further source of concern may be fears associated with declining community moral standards through access to a greater range of pornographic material.

The summary then goes on to indicate the possible impact on commercial broadcasters, et cetera. In these economic times we have to have regard to whether this service has a high priority as a demand on our resources. That matter must be considered very seriously indeed. As is indicated by this report, there is concern amongst the community. Page 128 talks about options regarding program standards. These options are in need of serious consideration. One of the options that is talked about is that there be no program standards, that they be left to the viewer, the recipient of pay television. It is noted that there is a capacity to have control systems and lock-out devices on television sets.

The Joint Select Committee on Video Material received evidence relating to this. Such systems are not foolproof. Before we go too much further on this matter, it is important that those responsible consider the problems that have emerged in the United States as a result of the introduction of pay television in that country. Concerns are now being expressed by a large and broadly representative group of parents as well as community groups in the United States about the effect of pay television on children's viewing, in particular, together with its effect on the general community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report we have before us, entitled Future Directions for Pay Television in Australia, was prepared by the Department of Transport and Communications as a discussion paper regarding the way in which pay television could be introduced into Australia. What I have to say is somewhat akin to one of the comments Senator Harradine made. The approach in this report is that pay television is a fait accompli. The Department's report accepts that pay television is to be introduced into Australia and discusses how that will happen. There is no discussion about what the cost will be to the nation. This should be addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: The introduction of pay television into Australia will cost many billions of dollars. Figures in the report outlined how much the various options which might be used will cost. As a nation we should be asking, before the introduction of pay television, how much material would have to be purchased overseas and what that would do to our present balance of payments problem. Would it make it even worse? If it would, I suppose that the question, then, is whether Australia can afford to introduce pay television. I am not saying that we should not, but it seems that in this respect the report by the Department of Transport and Communications is deficient. We have a significant problem with our balance of payments. If we are to introduce something new which requires a great deal of material to be brought from overseas it is possible that we will damage our country by spending more than we should, increasing our overseas debt problem.

I am not sure at this stage whether there is a great demand in Australia for pay television. I am prepared to be convinced otherwise. Many people whom I represent however, would not be concerned about using pay television or paying for an extra service. They would like to use television and the broadcast facilities that are free to them at present; they are paid for by another means, for example, by government or by advertising. But I am not too sure whether there is a great demand for pay television.

The point we should be considering is what this means to the country's finances and resources that we will use to introduce pay television. If we are to provide many billions of dollars for its introduction, we should be asking, `If those billions of dollars are available, should they be used for this new service or should they be used for some other service in Australia, indeed some other area where we need funds, for instance, in the housing area?'.

I urge the Government to look at pay television again particularly and at the financial implications that could result for Australia from its introduction. I do not consider that the Department of Transport and Communications is the correct department to do that. It is not surprising that the Department of Transport and Communications would accept the introduction of this new service as a fait accompli. After all, that Department would be the department which would be responsible for it once it was introduced to Australia. Perhaps the departments to have a good look at it are either Treasury or the Department of Finance so that they can determine whether pay television is something that should be introduced to Australia at present.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY GAMING AND LIQUOR AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report is quite comprehensive and deals with the activities of the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority. It indicates the highlights of the year, the income and distribution of the moneys which it has received from gambling and from liquor licensing. It is particularly the section relating to liquor licensing to which I wish to refer and specifically the matter of under age drinking with which it deals.

I recall speaking on a report from the Authority a year or two ago. I am pleased to note the reference to what we know occurred, that is, an amendment to the law on 22 December 1987 when new provisions came into the Liquor Ordinance 1975 relating to under-age drinking and the responsibility of partners who hold a licence. Specifically, in relation to under-age drinking, the term `liquor' was defined and new proposals for checking on under-age drinking, of course, were brought in. There is in the report also a reference to under-age drinking and what has occurred since that time. It refers to the fact that the Australian Federal Police had for a number of years been seeking this amendment to the ordinance. It deals with the number of young people who were spoken to in the then six-month period and who had been cautioned. The issuing of caution was a new development in the matter of under-age drinking.

The report refers to the fact that there are a number who are cautioned and encountered on more than one occasion. It gives the numbers of those who were cautioned by inspectors of the Authority and the police. Quite a story is told. Specifically, the report refers to the difficulty that police and inspectors were having as a consequence of the changes to the Childrens Service Ordinance 1986, specifically, section 30 sub-paragraph 1 of that Ordinance which came into effect early in 1988. It has been the subject of discussion. It has been a matter that has caused some problems in relation to having people present when young people are spoken to, the length of time they can be held and matters of that nature. This particular clause of the Childrens Service Ordinance is creating difficulties for inspectors and police to caution young people about drinking matters as provided for now in the Liquor Ordinance. It is an aspect of the Childrens Service Ordinance that needs to be modified so that the cautioning procedures of the Liquor Ordinance can operate properly and more efficiently, as I believe they are a very good idea.

I hope that those who have encountered the problem and who are thus aware of it will be diligent in pressing for a review of this matter so that the quite valuable procedure of cautioning under-age drinkers can be used in the way it was intended. The report also refers to the fact that two licensed premises have had their licences cancelled in the period covered by this annual report. At that time, another prosecution was pending. I think I am right in saying that all of those related to under-age drinking. It certainly is a problem in most parts of Australia. It is in Canberra. If one talks to the police who are on duty in Civic, on weekends and late at night, one gets some comprehension of the extent to which under-age drinking is a problem. Any matters which impede dealing with it need to be resolved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In looking at the list of papers before us, I find that there are some 97, of which 16 are predicated on issues arising totally out of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). Senator Reid and I were just commenting a few moments ago, privately, that this is probably, and hopefully, one of the last times when, in consideration of Government papers, we will have to give detailed consideration in this Parliament to issues such as health, housing, parole boards, surveyors' boards, fire brigades and electricity authorities, which will very probably pass with self-government to the ACT at the election this coming Saturday to the people of Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand a lot of of the apprehension in the community at the very significant change that will take place this weekend with regard to self-government. Indeed, I was a member of the Legislative Assembly in the Northern Territory when we negotiated the self-government package for the Northern Territory. As deputy leader of the majority party at that time, with Dr Goff Letts as the majority leader, he and I negotiated with the Fraser Government the basic principles for the financial arrangements that came into being for Northern Territory self-government.

Of course, there were many other people involved in that entire process. What I can attest to is the success of self-government for 10 years in the Northern Territory. I am very hopeful that we will see a similar form of success emerge in the Australian Capital Territory community. It is very important that people take as much responsibility locally as they possibly can. Indeed, my Senate colleague from the Northern Territory, Bob Collins, of the Australian Labor Party was quoted in the Northern Territory press recently as saying, also in support of self-government as a success story and as a way of running the Northern Territory, that he would far rather have a Country-Liberal Party government in Darwin running the Northern Territory than have the Northern Territory administered from Canberra, even by Labor.

There is certainly a lesson that we can follow in that local government of that nature and self-government are the right way to go. It is my earnest wish that the elections on Saturday will produce a very stable, strong and responsible government for this Territory. There is a plethora of candidates standing. The range of choices available to the Canberra people, of course, crosses so many different interests and sectors. I hope that the Canberra residents are able to see through those groups and individuals who are not really dedicated to the principles of what parliaments and good government are all about and are able to choose teams that will make for a very good government and very good opposition.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I take the opportunity to associate myself with the comments just made by my colleague, Senator Tambling, with respect to the forthcoming Australian Capital Territory election. For the last 7 1/2 years, I have also almost daily heard expressed by Canberra residents concerns on matters such as health, education, transport and criminal justice. However, the people of the Australian Capital Territory have unfortunately had no direct means by which to influence legislative or governmental changes or behaviour. On Saturday they will have the opportunity to put into being a government which will be responsible directly to them. I believe that they will act wisely. Apart from anything else, they will probably vote Liberal, in view of their experience of the Federal Labor Government as it relates to Canberra over the last six years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Want to bet?
—I was not going to get political, but if we take the health portfolio we see that nearly 100 industrial disputes have occurred in the last couple of years.
—Order! I point out that the honourable senator is speaking to the annual report of the Apprenticeship Board.

—Responsibility for apprentices will also pass to this new government. With your gracious liberty, Mr Deputy President, I make the quasi-political point that there is concern in the Australian Capital Territory that self-government will cost residents more. It is my view that now the Grants Commission makes specific references calculating the cost of the Australian Capital Territory to the Commonwealth there is a process of accountability that will require for the people of the Australian Capital Territory their own government to argue their case. As honourable senators know, the Grants Commission indicated that in its belief the Australian Capital Territory had a shortfall of some $60m, as compared to the States, in the year 1986-87. All the States have governments to argue their cases; the Territory has not. It will need that government in future or the result will be that the cost to the people of the Australian Capital Territory will be greater. Self-government will cost the residents less.

SPEECH.PARA: Getting back to the Apprenticeship Board, I point out to Senator Reynolds, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, and Senator Crowley, who participated in a debate in the area of the status of women two nights ago, that we had put on our desks yesterday evidence of their failure in a critical area of the status of women. Two nights ago, we debated in part whether girls and young women were being attracted into areas of skilled employment in order that they might improve their financial security and independence. This report gives figures as to the position in the Australian Capital Territory. Those figures should be highly illuminating to Senator Reynolds because they are inconsistent with the attitude that she expressed the other night. There are 1,769 apprentices in the Australian Capital Territory, of which only 282 are women. However, if we take out the number of those involved in ladies hairdressing, we find that the number of apprentices is reduced to 1,509, while the number of women is reduced to only 62. Thus, if we take out the number of those involved in ladies hairdressing, 62 of 1,509 apprentices are women.

If we consider achievements in the last year, taking out the numbers in hairdressing and cooking, we find that of 537 apprentices only 16 are girls or young women. The proof that their policies have been unsuccessful in attracting women into these other areas of employment and into apprenticeships is in the document before Senator Reynolds and Senator Crowley. They ought to face up to their responsibilities in this area rather than gloss over it by seeking commendation for their wonderful successes.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 December 1988, on motion by Senator Walters:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Regulation of Video Material Bill 1988, introduced by Senator Walters. I am the third speaker in the debate which was commenced last year. It was commenced with the introduction by Senator Walters of her private member's Bill. On 15 December 1988, Senator Tate, the Minister for Justice, responded to the second reading with the Government's position. He did so in a brief speech that at best could be described as disappointing. He did not address or seek to address in any way the content of Senator Walters's Bill. He spoke about a subject that is strictly irrelevant to the Bill, namely, the matter of violence on videos. He told us that the Caucus of the Australian Labor Party was addressing the subject of R-rated films and videos with the establishment of a committee to see whether there was confusion between X-rated and R-rated films and videos.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of the matter is that late last year Caucus determined that it would not support its Attorney-General in taking action to ban R-rated videos in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). The ACT is the headquarters for the pornographic video industry in Australia. Such videos are mail ordered from the ACT throughout Australia. It is part of a highly lucrative business in pornography. To reflect on history again for a moment, I point out that the trade has been banned in all States of Australia. It was the unanimous recommendation of the Attorneys-General of this country that it be banned in the Australian Capital Territory; in other words, that the loophole be closed. The Hawke Labor Government was not prepared to so act and its Attorney-General late last year took his recommendation to Caucus for further consideration. It was rejected. In other words, the Labor Party and the Hawke Labor Government indicated that they intended to maintain the legislative structure by which the R-rated video industry in the Australian Capital Territory can be conducted.

However, we read at the time that the Caucus committee decided that the subject of violent videos required further consideration and would be referred to a subcommittee of the Caucus. As I indicated a moment or so ago, when we read Senator Tate's response to Senator Walters's Bill, we find that the Caucus subcommittee will see whether there is confusion between violent videos and pornographic videos and make recommendations. It is a development of what Caucus decided, recognising that there is a community concern. Not wanting to face up to that concern, the government has tried to camouflage the fact that it is not prepared to act in the area. In an indirect way it will now bring consideration of this matter within its Caucus committee structure. That response is totally unsatisfactory. We have been disappointed, as you would know from previous debates in the Senate, Mr Deputy President, that the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Reynolds) has not been prepared to participate in these debates. She has not been prepared to put to this Senate her position on the subject of pornographic videos. We are aware, of course, that the reason for this is that she would be obviously aware that the vast majority of Australian women are totally opposed to this trade, which demeans women in such an improper way. However, she has not been prepared to front and contribute to these debates and I will be very surprised if she contributes today.

The position she has put to the Senate before is that she is not prepared to act because women's organisations have not expressed a view to her. We are well aware of the practice of this Government, and particularly of Senator Reynolds, to respond to representations of women's organisations. In fact, she conducts surveys and calls conferences-we have another conference being held this weekend-in which she says she seeks to ascertain the views of women's organisations, to which she will respond. With regard to pornographic videos, she says that these women's groups have not approached her. She does not know their views and therefore there is no need to act. Of course, she has not sought the opinions of women's organisations in this regard. She has not conducted surveys on this subject. She has not called conferences to see whether women are seriously of the view that we have put to her and that they oppose this trade in the strongest possible terms. In other words, her practice in this instance has been to close her eyes and her ears, otherwise she would receive evidence that would put her in an embarrassing position vis-a-vis that adopted by her Caucus and her Prime Minister. She has therefore not been prepared to front up to the attitudes of Australian women.

In a previous debate on this subject in this chamber we in the Opposition said that we would do her work for her; that we would write to women's organisations seeking their views; and that we would come back to the Senate and put those views on the public record, whether they came out in favour of Senator Walters's Bill to ban X-rated videos in the ACT or otherwise. We did this in order that Senator Reynolds could have the picture before her and, we believe, so that she would have one less reason not to respond to this public concern.

Pursuant to those undertakings, I wrote to women's organisations. I acknowledge the support of the Office of the Status of Women, which at my request provided me with a list of appropriate organisations to whom I could write. I want now briefly to take the Senate through the responses I received. The first response I have on this list is from the Women's Electoral Lobby (ACT) Inc. (WEL), which was mentioned at Question Time as one of those organisations which Senator Reynolds particularly takes note of in relation to taxation matters. It is a sponsor of the Women's Tax Convention that is being held in Canberra this weekend. On this particular subject, Joy Taylor for WEL ACT wrote in response to my letter:
I am writing in response to your letter regarding X-rated videos and the Oppositions intention to introduce a Private Members Bill on the matter.
WEL is totally opposed to any portrayal of women that exploits or degrades them in any way, or any portrayal of women that reinforces the unequal power relationships that exist in society.

WEL ACT endorses the intent of your Bill to ban X-rated videos in the ACT. We believe that it is inappropriate for the ACT to continue to distribute X-rated videos in the face of the contrary decisions of the Attorneys-General in all States.
We would be interested to see a copy of the Bill . . .

Senator Reynolds will now be aware of the attitude of the Women's Electoral Lobby to this particular matter. The second response I want to bring to the attention of the Senate is from the Catholic Women's League, Australia. Mrs E. Doyle, AM, the national President, wrote to me on 24 November stating:
Members of the Catholic Women's League Australia (app. 20,000 in number)-
that is something Senator Reynolds should take note of-
. . . are angered at the lack of action on the part of the Federal ALP Caucus in the matter of X rated videos.

Pornography degrades women, particularly in the minds of the young and the easily manipulated. We are convinced that constant exposure to violence/sex through the media, particularly the electronic media, can lead those of immature and/or warped mentality to commit crimes of sex and/or violence.
We are insistent that the Government should implement the unanimous recommendation of the State Attorneys General that X rated videos be banned in the ACT, as in all the States.
Also, we are against the introduction of the proposed NVE category and we feel that the existing `R' and `M' classifications should be tightened.
We would appreciate your making our views known to the Parliament.
Now Senator Reynolds knows the views of the Catholic Women's League, Australia.

The third response which I bring to the attention of the parliament is that of the Country Women's Association (CWA) of New South Wales. Mrs Patricia Keill, the General Secretary, wrote on behalf of Mrs Gedling, the National Secretary of the CWA, Australia, on 24 November 1988. I will not read the whole letter as it is rather long, but it is available for anyone who has an interest in the subject. Mrs Keill reminded me of a resolution of her organisation, stating:
That C.W.A. of Australia urgently requests the Federal Government to ban importation, production, sale and hire of X/ER rated video tapes within Australia.
She went on to say:

This Association was dismayed when, after the Attorneys General Conference in Darwin, it had been decided to have the matter discussed again in Caucus. We also took exception at the cavalier manner in which our Prime Minister treated the subject at the Press Conference on the steps of Parliament House.

We had experience earlier this week of this Government apparently becoming aware-or so it claimed-of the effect on women of the foul language of its Treasurer. On a number of occasions we have brought to its attention the effect on women of the patronising attitude of the Prime Minister of Australia. It is interesting that this has been picked up by the Country Women's Association, a very large organisation. Patricia Keill continues:

Women are degraded when portrayed as sexual playthings and prolonged exposure to pornography can lead to a lack of respect by men. Although we cannot substantiate this statement, we feel that there is a higher likelihood of rape or to force unwanted sexual acts on women. Men who do not respect women think nothing of violent acts against them.

She goes on to reinforce the fact that the State Attorneys-General were unanimously of the view that action should be taken to close the loophole in the ACT. She expresses disappointment that this Government has not been prepared to act accordingly. In fact, it is her view that the political pressure which has been brought to bear by a lobby which has a $25m industry is related to the fact that this Government has not been prepared to take action. She states:
Our priority should be the care of men, women and children and not money.
That is a message which perhaps Senator Reynolds should take note of.
The next organisation was the National Association of Community Based Children's Services, which wrote to me on 23 November 1988. The Convener, Dawn Plested, stated:
Thank you for your letter regarding the decision to continue to allow the sale of X-rated videos in the ACT.
This was the Government's decision. I continue:

The National Association of Community Based Childrens Services supports your efforts to obtain the implementation of the recommendations of the State Attorneys-General and the Joint Parliamentary Select Committee on Video Material to ban X-rated videos in the ACT.

The National Status of Women Committee also wrote to me. That, of course, is the Peak Council of National Women's Non Government Organisations, formed in 1975 at the commencement of the United Nations Decade for Women and concerned with the elevation of the status of women. What did it say? It stated:

Your letter . . . was considered yesterday at a meeting of my Committee. The Committee unanimously resolved to inform you that it supports your belief that the unanimous recommendation of all State Attorneys General that X-rated videos be banned in all states and the ACT should be implemented. The Committee commends your commitment to the status of women in this matter.
I hope that Senator Reynolds will at least do us the courtesy of reading this list and reading the views of these independent women's organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a shame she's not here.

—No, she will not be here today. I will be very surprised if she participates in the debate. Women's Action Alliance (Australia) is a very responsible group. Mrs Pauline Smit, the National President, wrote to us on 23 November. She stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Women's Action Alliance is pleased to hear that the Opposition is taking this action, as we were most disappointed that the Labor caucus saw fit to vote as it did.
We are enclosing some material that may be of use to you-and would be interested to obtain a copy of the proposed Bill when it is available.
Part of the material that she enclosed was a press release that followed a conference that it had in Queensland in which it quoted the Labor member for Forde (Ms Crawford), who stated:
Children's innocence is to be prized and their introduction to sex should not be through a fifth rate pornographic video. . .

Perhaps if Senator Reynolds listened to some of her Labor colleagues from the States she might respond in a way consistent with the views of the community rather than the views of her colleague the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Caucus.

One can continue with this list of women's organisations. The Mothers Union in Australia, Social Responsibility Department, wrote to us reminding us of its 14,000 members in 24 dioceses of the Anglican Church-throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —They lack an understanding of the issue.
—Senator Zakharov ought to listen to this. It said to us:

SPEECH.PARA: Along with many other people in the community we have been campaigning for the ban on X-rated Videos in the A.C.T. and the N.T. and the consequent end of the mail order trade which now flows into the States, where a ban already exists.

Our reasons are that X-rated Videos contain depictions of behaviour which, if imitated, may lead to the spread of Sexually Transmitted Diseases, including A.I.D.S. It is our contention that it is illogical for the Government to be spending millions of dollars on the education of the public about the dangers of certain sexual practices while at the same time condoning the sale and hire of videos which are sending the message that these very practices are normal, acceptable and presumably risk free.
This is particularly interesting and ought to be noted by Senator Zakharov. It states:

We also believe that it is illogical for the Government to support such projects as `Fair Go for Women' and `Affirmative Action' which seek to improve the status of women in the community while allowing the free availability of material which depict women as mere objects for male sexual gratification.

That is the sort of advice that Senator Zakharov, Senator Reynolds and Senator Crowley ought to listen to from such responsible groups as the Anglican Church's Mothers Union. But of course, they will not be listened to.
I move on to the response from Australian Church Women, who wrote to us on 28 November 1988 expressing a similar sentiment. They stated:
This subject has been a real concern of our members and was brought forward by the Tasmanian unit-
Senator Walters will be pleased to hear that-
and discussed at some length at our National Conference in Adelaide in September 1987.

We believe it is ludicrous that the Federal Government can make a decision such as this against the recommendations of all State Governments to allow X-rated videos to be available by mail order from the A.C.T. There has been a great deal of opposition expressed by many responsible groups and people in the community against this, and though the States have heeded and listened to their concerns, it seems the Federal Government is completely unconcerned about their responsibility to the community to endeavour to maintain a responsible moral standard that will benefit all people.

That pretty clearly expresses the attitude of Australian Church Women as written by Mrs Napier, the National Secretary. The Society of Women Writers Australia also wrote to us. This perhaps may be of greater interest to Senator Zakharov if she is not prepared to listen to the women's organisations from the churches. It wrote on 28 November 1988, and stated:

The Society of Women Writers Australia gives its wholehearted support to ban this destructive force within our Nation. Please do all you can to beat greedy vendors who are prepared to grow rich on moral poverty.
Over the years we have tried to guide our writers, steering them away from using gutter language so that our heritage of National pride is retained to be handed down to succeeding generations.

That letter was written by Marjorie Wilke, the Federal President of the Society of Women Writers Australia. I hope that perhaps some of these Labor senators will listen to that organisation. Some 700 members, I understand, exist in the Society of Women Writers Australia. I will move on to the War Widow's Guild of Australia. It wrote on 6 December 1988. Referring to our letter, it stated:

At the Bicentennial National Conference of the War Widows' Guild of Australia held in October the matter of video pornography was discussed. As a result it was agreed that the Government should be asked to take steps to eliminate video pornography particularly in its demeaning portrayal of women.
The Guild therefore supports the Private Members Bill on X-rated videos as mentioned in your letter.

The Australian Federation of Business and Professional Women Inc., a highly respected body, wrote to us. I note from the speech I read given by Senator Reynolds in December last year that it is a body that she has specifically referred to as one which she listens to and from which she takes advice. Robyn Duncan, the Vice-President of External Policy, stated:

The Australian Federation of Business and Professional Women Inc. is concerned that the Government has failed to implement the unanimous recommendations of the State Attorneys-General to ban X-rated videos in the ACT. We are concerned that by declining to introduce legislative measures to eliminate the exploitation of women the Government is not showing that it has a commitment to improving the status of women.
We welcome the introduction of a Private Members Bill on this subject.

Apart from the women's organisations that I have mentioned, not surprisingly church organisations have also been writing to us expressing similar views. The Australian Catholic Bishops Conference wrote to me earlier-it was not in response to my letter; it presumably wrote to all senators-on 27 September 1988, a letter signed by Monsignor Manning, who stated:

There has been much misunderstanding of what the majority of the Committee recommended with respect to the treatment of video pornography. The position of the majority is currently set out in a letter that the Australian Catholic Bishops Conference addressed to the Attorney-General on 8 June 1988. A copy of that letter is enclosed.
So Labor members must have it. I continue:

The majority of the Committee recommended that `the Commonwealth Government introduce substantive legislation to ensure that this material (i.e. almost all of the current X-rated video pornography and their R equivalents) is refused classification for the purposes of Commonwealth laws' . . .

I would have thought that that makes adequately clear the attitude of the Australian Catholic Bishops Conference. And so I can go on. Particular members of the clergy have written to us. Don Barter, the Dean of Townsville, writes:
Please do all you can to reverse the recent decision to make our National Capital the Porn Centre of Australia.
It is totally unacceptable to myself and many other Australians. Any Government which countenances such a degradation for our National Capital does not deserve to remain in power.

I said that I would report to the Senate not only on those who wrote to the Opposition in supporting the banning X-rated videos but also on those who wrote expressing a contrary view. Only one women's organisation has written to me believing that action should not be taken in this regard. That organisation is the Women in Science Enquiry Network Incorporated. On 24 November 1988 Dr Merrelyn Emery wrote:

WISENET is not against non-violent erotica as there are other issues such as freedom of choice in a democracy which must be considered. Some of this material portrays men and women as equal partners and it may be wiser to use other means of education to remove the need for that which does degrade women, rather than impose bans which have a very poor track record.

So one women's organisation has written expressing the contrary view or, in other words, supporting the Government's position. A vast number of women's organisations have written to us saying that women should not be demeaned in this way; that this Government should not condone the demeaning of women in this way; and that this Government should take action to support Senator Walters's private member's Bill. One organisation, the Federal Government's principal mechanism for consulting with women in the community, the National Women's Consultative Council, has responded in the last couple of days after many requests from us. It says that its members have varied views on the subject. In the cause of fair play I quote from that letter written by Anne O'Byrne, the Convener. It states:

After substantial debate it emerged that some members were opposed to X-rated videos, others were more concerned about the matter of censorship, and all were concerned about the effect of violence in videos.

I respect the National Women's Consultative Council but I suggest to the convener of that body that, if she takes an expression of views of women's organisations, it will be as these women's organisations have advised us and as we have put down in the Senate today-that is, very strong opposition to the Government's stand in this area.

The letters and the representations that I have referred to relate to correspondence that has been written directly to us. Mr Acting Deputy President, you would be aware of many other organisations in the community, through letters to the editor pages of newspapers and other forums, that have expressed similar views in opposition to the X-rated video trade out of the Australian Capital Territory. I simply remind you of a list of these. References are also available for those honourable senators who might wish to pursue the matter further. There has been opposition from the National Council of Independent Schools; the Federation of Catholic Parents and Friends Associations; the Anglican Youth Synod; the Australian Parents Council, the Australian Council for Children's Films and Television; Dr Jocelynne Scutt, the former deputy chairperson of the Law Reform Commission; the National Council of Women of New South Wales; the New South Wales Women's Advisory Council; the Anglican Dean of Sydney, the very Reverend Lance Shilton; Cardinal Clancy, President of the Australian Catholic Bishops Conference; the Labor President of the upper House in New South Wales, Mr John Johnson; the Archbishop of Melbourne, the most Reverend David Penman; and Australia's largest union, which has expressed its opposition to the Government's policy and practice in this area, the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I remind you that the people of Australia have used the process available to them to express their views to the Parliament in the form of petitions. I am advised that, as of today, 16,854 members of the Australian community have petitioned the Senate to oppose X-rated pornographic materials being distributed from the Australian Capital Territory and 30,504 Australians have similarly petitioned the House of Representatives. I am advised that there has been no petition in favour of the Government's position of supporting the X-rated pornography industry in the Australian Capital Territory. So I respectfully hope that the Government and, in particular, Senator Reynolds, with her special responsibility in relation to women, will take note of the material that I have put before the Senate today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill has just delivered a very revealing speech on exactly why a huge cross-section of Australian citizens believe that pornographic videos are a highly undesirable commodity in this country. The many letters and petitions to which Senator Hill referred are certainly not just some phantom. I am absolutely amazed that the Minister for Local Government and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Reynolds, has not even bothered to enter the chamber to listen to this debate. That, too, is quite revealing about what the Government is thinking. I am glad to rise in support of the Regulation of Video Material Bill 1988, whose purpose is to prevent the continued use of the Australian Capital Territory as the Australian centre for mail order hard core pornography. I do so as a Liberal. I am also a federalist who does not believe that the inaction of this Federal Parliament or this Government should allow the subversion of the declared policies of elected State governments.
—Oh!

—Senator Zakharov, with any degree of luck, will hyperventilate over there. She has been sitting through this whole debate huffing and puffing, yet at the same time she is a senator from the Australian Labor Party (ALP), which purports to support women. She cannot even be bothered in this instance to help protect women. I think it an utter disgrace that she is huffing and puffing over there. As I have said, with any degree of luck she might hyperventilate. Equally, as a Liberal, I am concerned at the effects this material is having on Australian society. That is why I am surprised that people such as Senator Zakharov, who spruik off from the hilltops, are not concerned about Australian society. As a representative of the people of Western Australia I am conscious of their wishes for some broad basic controls over videos.

SPEECH.PARA: The other person sitting in this chamber who has been flapping his gums all day on this Bill, in a very derisive way, is Senator Cook, who is also from Western Australia. One does not need to be too bright to realise how many people have written to Senator Cook asking that these videos be banned. He, too, chooses to ignore them. Quite frankly, it is a pity that this Bill cannot proceed as a bipartisan measure and it is a greater shame that it needs to be introduced at all. However, it is the inevitable response to the continued inaction by this Hawke Labor Government right through its term of office. Until we had a change of Attorney-General after the 1984 election the Labor Party refused even to hold an inquiry. That says something in itself. It refused to use Federal Government power over Customs to take action at the importation of pornographic material. It is weak-kneed and lily-livered on this subject and this is proved time and again. When a vote is taken on this Bill it will prove it yet again.

This Hawke Labor Government ignored the 1985 Senate committee that reported strong public opposition to X-rated videos and exposed the inadequacy of regulations that did nothing to prevent the distribution of these videos by post. When the Joint Select Committee on Video Material finally reported last year the ALP seized on every excuse to do nothing. It has sought to fudge the fact that a majority of the Committee-let us not forget that it was a majority of the Committee-was opposed to an X-rated video classification. It is part of the role of government to take action to maintain an accepted level of social decorum and to inhibit personal activity that is likely to cause distress and harm to others. By tradition it has been the State governments in Australia that have legislated for or against such controls. In this field State parliaments have sought to reflect the wishes of their electors.

It is not by accident that State governments of both political persuasions have imposed greater restrictions on video materials and have moved towards the prohibition of the sale and hire of hard core pornography whether depicting violence or perversion. That just happens to be fact. Yet earlier Senator Zakharov sat there huffing and puffing in her usual way and poured scorn on the fact that the State governments had made their decision. The State governments have made their decision and that is something that is totally and utterly undeniable. Significantly, the State Attorneys-General, meeting in Darwin last July, recommended the banning of X-rated videos, which is another thing that honourable senators opposite choose to ignore. I wonder whether Labor senators will claim that their State colleagues from Western Australia, South Australia or Victoria are what one could call, I suppose, right wing wowsers because they oppose these videos. They oppose these videos but those opposite do not. It is amazing to see that they cannot even justify why they disagree with their State colleagues.

At the time, the Federal Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) was quoted as saying that only 7 per cent of video users hired or bought X-rated videos. However, since then this Government has bent over backwards to keep that 7 per cent happily watching their porn. Seven per cent is important, is it? To me, 7 per cent is a fairly insignificant lot. We all know that until this Parliament takes action to prevent the dissemination of video pornography by mail order from Canberra, the intentions of the elected representatives of the remainder of Australia will be diligently undermined by this Government. Unless the Hawke Labor Government is prepared to explain why the actions of the State governments in controlling pornography are wrong and harmful, it should act to close off the loophole that makes their policy ineffective. The present cynical inaction by this Government, paying lip service to family values while appeasing the pornography lobby, is treating the State governments and the Federal system with absolute and utter contempt.

When Senator Walters or anyone else stands up to demand action against X-rated material we can expect the shopworn allegations that we are trying to foist a minority moral standard onto the community, that we are threatening free expression, and that we are hung up on the evil that we are trying to control. It was interesting to watch the reaction of honourable senators opposite while Senator Hill read out a very extensive list of letters asking that the Bill be supported. Senator Zakharov murmured and mumbled and carried on with disgust at every letter that was read out supporting the Bill. Senator Hill had one letter opposing the Bill and she sat there and nodded so vigorously that her head nearly fell off. That was for one letter opposing the Bill. Where are the standards of honourable senators opposite?

It is time to ask whether those who take what I would describe as an extreme libertarian position in respect of hard core pornography are not the true unthinking conservatives. Too many Australians in public life are still trapped in the attitudes of the late 1960s and probably early 1970s when the sexual revolution was seen to be good clean fun and the destruction of all censorship was a great way of shocking the Establishment.
