It certainly shocked enough people. Certainly, Australia had to remove the types of controls that prevented us from reading books and seeing films that were accepted in other Western societies. I think that honourable senators ignore a deep-seated change in public attitudes that does not equate X-rated videos with something like Lady Chatterley's Lover-that is a very different scenario altogether-and people do not necessarily believe that freedom is threatened because governments take action against gross depiction of warped sexual behaviour. I have always suspected that some Government senators would have had enough morality, decency and concern in them about the general standards of behaviour in our society to vote for this Bill, but obviously my assessment of things in that respect is far off the beam.

I support the Bill because I believe there is too much evidence to ignore. As I have said before, if one wanted evidence, extensive evidence was given by Senator Hill. That evidence points to the fact that exposure to X-rated videos has a damaging effect on many individuals and, therefore, harms society as a whole. I do not believe that it is the right of any government to intentionally, willingly and knowingly harm society in the way this Government is going about it. This is not a matter that can be proved with the finality of a scientific equation because enough qualified behaviour experts who reported to the Joint Select Committee have pointed to the fact that exposure to pornography, whether explicitly violent or not, caused viewers to accept the values implicit in this material. Such values, so-called, teach the viewer that we are all something akin to two-legged animals and nothing more and that women especially are dehumanised sex objects, playthings for men and proper targets for their sexual aggression. Once again, I am absolutely staggered that this Government is prepared to accept that-not only accept it but allow it to continue.

Research by Zillman and Bryant, described in chapter 13 of the report, cites the facts that prolonged exposure to pornography promotes insensitivity towards the victims of sexual violence, distorts usual perceptions of sexuality, and results in a preference for less common forms of sexuality that are forced on reluctant female partners. Yet again, the Government chooses to ignore that evidence. If the overwhelmingly male audience of hard core pornography were simply harming itself there might not be a case for any form of government control. However, we must not forget that the final victims of pornography are usually women. There are cases where men are involved but generally they are women. Even if only a small number of pornography users commit sexual assaults, if is an evil that society cannot afford to condone. We cannot afford to sit back any longer and condone that evil.

It has been said that over the last two decades when hard core pornography became easily obtainable in Australia there has been a tendency for rapists to force their victims into acts that have been learnt from pornography. I might say that in Western Australia we have had some very grim reminders of that in the not too distant past. Bearing in mind what two people did to a number of girls after watching videos-the two people happen to be in prison now-this Government is prepared to sit back and accept that young girls and women can be subjected to such violence. I quote from paragraph 13.131 of the report:

It cannot logically be argued that the effects of pornography can safely be ignored because, supposedly, only deviants would respond to pornographic influences. While behavioural science studies in this area do not provide certainly they do establish theories which make reliable predictions about human behaviour. It would therefore be unenlightened for Parliament to ignore them.

The Government chooses to ignore that report. Surely no honourable senator would argue against the proposition that X-rated videos would have a damaging effect on children and adolescents, poisoning their sexuality and self-image and, in many cases, possibly poisoning their lives in the future. But no, it does not matter. I hope that members of this Parliament would accept that as fact. It is not some airy-fairy fiction. It is in the very nature of video material that it enters the home and that some adult users will lack the responsibility to keep it from children. There are instances of that happening every day of the week. It is, therefore, proper to ask whether the protection of young Australians, who are subjected to enough other confusing and disturbing social trends, should override the rights of those supposedly mature adults who can watch X-rated material without ill-effect.

As an aside, it is ironic to note that to many observant young people the availability of pornography has made the word `adult' into a euphemism for a mindless obsession with sex. It is some adult world that we are giving them, by courtesy of this Government. I would warn the Australian Labor Party that it is kidding itself if it thinks that opposition to the Australian Capital Territory mail order pornography industry is confined to the conservative side of politics and to lobby groups that the ALP dismisses as religious fundamentalists. That is certainly not the case, it has never been the case, and is never likely to be the case. Many concerned citizens, out of the blue, have rung me and written to me on this subject-and I would not call them cranks in any meaning of the word. Those people are concerned. Some ladies from a pensioners group visited me in my office yesterday. They asked the same question: `What are you doing about pornographic videos? What is your opinion on the subject?'. They were extremely concerned at the effect of pornographic videos on young children; they were seeing the effect in the community. Yet this Government chooses to think that it is only radicals who can have a view contrary to the Government's.

A great deal of concern has been expressed by all the churches, including those whose attitudes to social questions cannot generally be described as right wing. The majority of Australians still adhere to Christian denominations, even if two certain people in high office in Australia do not. Concern at the social effects of X-rated videos extends way beyond the churches. Is anyone prepared to argue that the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association is an extreme conservative body? Senator Hill read out excerpts from the Association's letter, and its views would not generally be described as conservative. Rather, I might hazard a guess that a majority of its active members are Labor voters. Significantly, it is a union with a majority female membership, a membership concerned with the effect pornography has in shaping male attitudes towards women; but once again the Government chooses not to listen even to the people who vote for it. Many of the other people who have expressed concern would be people who vote for it. Try as we might, I do not think we could get 93 per cent of the vote-and about 93 per cent of the community are opposed to this.

The letter from the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association to members of parliament last year also made the point that the bulk of pornographic videos originate in the United States, where their production is substantially in the hands of organised crime. If women are the end victims, of hard core porn, one could say that `the mob' is the end beneficiary. Labor senators should not ignore the telling comments of a New South Wales Legislative Council member-I refer not to Reverend Fred Nile but to the Labor President of the Council, Mr John Johnson. On 9 November Mr Johnson accused his Federal colleagues of a `political cop-out' over their policy of inaction, and stated that they had lost touch with the electorate. He made this commonsense statement:
We're there for the good government of the nation and if we're not doing that we shouldn't be there.

That was a comment by yet another member of the Labor Party-indeed, not just a member of the Party but a member of parliament in that Party. Yet the Government also chooses to ignore him. I believe that the sentiments of Mr Johnson, noting that the Federal Labor Party has `squibbed the issue', speak for a vast number of Australians from both sides of politics, who do not wish to force their values on others but who simply believe that the dissemination of hard core video pornography is harming society and threatens the well-being of our children. Mr Johnson also mentioned the insensitive campaign of the pornography lobby to protect its lucrative investment. Spokesmen for this lobby are now claiming that the defeat of the coalition in the Western Australian elections was due to their advertising that equated our stand against X-rated videos with Hitler and Stalin. How outrageous can they get.

What makes this argument look thin is the fact that the State Labor Government had legislated against the possession as well as the hiring and sale of this material. Again I must stress that at State government level, with the agreement of the Attorneys-General that X-rated videos must go and that no non-violent erotica be considered to replace them, we do have a bipartisan view on this matter. I would add that while many might support the concept of some explicit material being used in bona fide sex education or of erotic material of genuinely artistic nature, we are all too aware that the NVE classification would be a means of circulating hard care pornography that merely avoids explicit violence.

It is not good enough for us, or for the people for whom we speak. I thought we were in this place to represent our constituents. No matter on what side of Parliament we sit, we should be representing our constituents. I would have hoped that on this occasion the Labor Party would represent its constituents and join with us in voting for this Bill. The Bill is a serious and honest attempt to rectify a social evil that makes our national capital the sleaze capital of Australia. That is very sad, and I commend the Bill's support to all honourable senators who can bring themselves to consider that pornography is not good for this country.

This Hawke Labor Government constantly sings a song about its care for women. We heard a convoluted answer from Senator Reynolds today about women-women this, women that. It was not too easy to understand because on this occasion no-one had written the answer and she was not able to read one out. She and many other senators continually sing about the problems associated with women, yet not one of them is prepared to be in this chamber to listen to this debate. Indeed, not one of those Labor senators is prepared to vote for this Bill. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) believes that he and the Government generally can appeal to women simply by Government members cleaning up their language. They have a long way to go on that issue. If anyone wants to check Hansard last night to see how Senator Collins performed, or check Hansard ever since Senator Collins came into this place, they will agree that, if anyone needs to have his language cleaned up and his mouth washed out, it is probably Senator Collins. However, he would probably be second only to the Treasurer (Mr Keating).

For the Prime Minister to say that the Labor Government can appeal to women by Labor members cleaning up their language is the most patronising thing I have ever heard. We have before us in the Parliament today a Bill that would give the Government an opportunity to say, `Yes, we are legitimately concerned about women and we will vote for this Bill'. Women want delivery by governments of realities and not the platitudes that the Prime Minister and people like Senator Reynolds and others are offering at the moment. This Labor Federal Government has an opportunity right here and now to support this Bill, but at this stage the Minister has not been into the chamber. It is a great tragedy that we have not got bipartisan support for this Bill. It is a very important Bill, not just for women and for children but for society in general. That is why it should be commended to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to have the opportunity to talk out these matters yet again, because I agree with Senator Knowles and other speakers in this debate that these matters concern the community very much. Certainly we are all here to represent our constituents and, as such, we should look at matters which are debated out in the community. It is my opinion and my assessment that opinion in the community is divided on erotica and pornography but not so divided on violence. I am surprised that Senator Hill and Senator Knowles have addressed their remarks to X-rated videos and not to R-rated videos. If we are to have this debate yet again in the Senate, it is very pertinent that we get our facts straight in respect of these videos. I noticed that both Senator Hill and Senator Knowles mentioned pornographic violence and violent sex in the same breath. In fact, Senator Hill, in talking about one of the responses he had received, said that particular constituents objected to depictions on video of violent sex. Violent sex is found only in R-rated videos and not in X-rated videos, according to the definitions. I will go into more detail about that later.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to look also at the legislation. The aim of this legislation is succinctly described in clause 5 (3) of the legislation, which states:

. . . video materials shall be refused classification . . . if the material includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults, whether or not the material includes any depiction suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind.
Further, clause 5 (4) states:
. . . video material shall not be classified . . . if the material depicts detailed, relished or gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty.

Of course, the words `refused classification' and `shall not be classified' actually mean `shall be banned'. Clause 5 (5) describes exceptions to the banning of explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults and to `detailed, relished or gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty'. That subsection states:

. . . video material which, in the opinion of the Censorship Board, depicts matters of such educational, cultural, scientific, historical or cinematographic significance that it is in the public interest for it to be classified.
That means that materials will not be banned if they fulfil those particular classifications.

Turning to the section of the Bill headed `Importation of video material', we find, if I am not mistaken, that this relates only to explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults and not to acts of considerable violence or cruelty. Perhaps this matter can be brought forward if this Bill comes to the committee stage-unless there is a misprint in the version of the Bill which I have here. This matter does give rise to concern and, as I said before, I hope that if we reach the committee stage we can talk further about that, in the time available.

The components of Senator Walters's Bill are to some extent complementary to the Government's response to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. As we heard previously-last year-the Government Caucus committee is to review the current X classification and also depictions of violence in the various classifications of violence in present video and film materials. This makes some sense. I would like to refer to the video classifications as defined in the report on page 802. At present the definition for classification X, extra restricted, for 18 years and over, is:
Material which includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults, but does not include any depiction suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind . . .
In other words, no violence of any kind. Senator Walters has in fact expanded on the definition. In her Bill, she states:
``explicit depictions of sexual acts'' means depictions of:
(a) sexual penetration;
(b) oral contact with genitals between consenting adults; or
(c) sexual manipulation alone or between consenting adults.

In other words, Senator Walters has taken the bold move, I might say, of actually defining `explicit depictions of sexual acts'-a term which was not defined by the Film Censorship Board. I do not propose to debate this matter any further at present because I do not think it will add any great perspective to the essence of the Bill. But I do draw it to the attention of the Senate because I think it is pertinent to the matter in hand. Certainly the video materials Committee recommended a review of the levels of violence throughout videos, and I believe that was one very important recommendation which it made. Senator Walters's Bill goes further in her classification of violence than the present classification, which I will read out. In present R-rated videos, the provision concerning violence is as follows:
Explicit depictions of violence, but not detailed and gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty.

In other words, in the clause of Senator Walters's Bill I previously read out, we have an additional word, and that is the word `relished'. Examples are found of inappropriate language and depictions of violence not only at the R-rated level but also, I am afraid, at M, G and even PG ratings, and most people are amazed to learn that the Rambo movies are in fact M-rated.

Censorship is both a fascinating and a dangerous concept. To those of us who are ideologically opposed to censorship the concept of someone else, or, even worse, an institution, telling us to which information we shall have access or be denied access can be both offensive and sinister. Support for censorship can be popular. I do not want to go into any great detail here, but I remind the Senate that the Nazis' burning of books was opposed by the minority at the time, not the majority. Also, the path of making exceptions can be a murky one, fraught with individual and institutional prejudice.

I would like to refer at this stage to Attachment E of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, Volume 2. This discusses the findings of the study on video viewing behaviour and attitudes towards explicit material in video movies. It was intended as a preliminary investigation. It is a study which provides some valuable data and raises a number of issues which have direct policy relevance. A questionnaire was sent to a sample of video hirers in Canberra and the surrounding district, and 175 people returned completed questionnaires. I think the Senate will find some of the results interesting. They appear on page 812, if anybody wishes to read them all. Attachment E states:
Nineteen per cent of respondents fell within the category of regular X-rated movie viewers. . . A much larger number fell within the category of regular R viewers . . .
That is, 59.4 per cent. It states further:
Regular X viewers did not differ markedly from video viewers in general in terms of a series of characteristics including age, marital status, church attendance, education and work situation.

Only five per cent of respondents thought that X-rated videos should be banned. Over 60.0 per cent said that there should be no public display of such videos, while 30.0 per cent said there should be no restriction for adult audiences.
Attitudes to materials containing sexual violence were far more conservative. Over 60.0 per cent of respondents said that such material should be banned.

A large proportion of respondents agreed with the present restrictions on the availability of X-rated videos. Over 85.0 per cent thought that X-rated videos should be kept in a restricted area of the video store. . .

I have read out just a few of the remarks with regard to that survey. I would like to point out that the results of that survey are very much in keeping with the recommendations which were made by the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. In recommendation 1 the Committee recommended that a new category, NVE, non-violent erotica, be instituted. That was a majority recommendation. Word seems to have got around that it was not, but it was. It was recommendation 2, which recommended that the new NVE category contained that material as defined in the current classification of X, that was a non-majority decision.

I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the rest of the Committee's recommendations; there were 29 in all. For the most part they concerned the availability of video materials. The Committee recommended that both X-rated and R-rated video materials-I agree with this recommendation wholeheartedly-should not be readily available. It recommended that promotional material for these videos should not be blatantly displayed so that people are blatantly exposed to it in a way which they might find offensive.

Other recommendations have regard to video materials being labelled in such a way that people are well aware of their content with regard to language and depictions of sex and violence. The subject of language has come up in this chamber. A lot of undesirable language is used in the Parliament. My experience is that the most unexpected people use the most unexpected language when they are not aware that others are listening.

There is confusion over the present classifications. This is to be regretted, because it means that debates of this sort are often carried on without people being aware of what the classifications mean. I hope that my remarks have helped to clear up this matter. One of the problems is that X-rated videos in the United States of America and the United Kingdom can contain explicit depictions of sexual material and violence. That is a problem for us in Australia with our X classification. Therefore, it is a logical step for our X classification to be changed to NVE-non-violent erotica. The difference in the X classification between countries has given rise to unfortunate misunderstandings. For example, great play was made of the fact that Bundy, who was recently executed in the United States of America, watched X-rated videos. Those X-rated videos would have contained violence because, as I said before, the classifications are different.

There has been some open discussion in the community on this topic. In January it was a very popular topic on open line radio talkback shows in Western Australia. I listened to as much of those talkback shows as I was able. I believe that public debate is healthy. It is up to members of parliament to listen as much as possible to what our constituents have to say on matters. It certainly came out on the talkback shows in Perth that violence worries people in the community a great deal but that explicit depictions of non-violent sex are not of great concern. Many letters have been written on the subject. Perhaps we should have a referendum on the topic. It is a great shame that when we had the opportunity to put as a fifth referendum question that people in Australia should have the opportunity to initiate a referendum-a referendum could have been initiated by those citizens who wrote the letters-because of a decision by the majority of senators that opportunity was denied to them. I regret that very much.
I refer to some comments made by Beatrice Faust and reported in the National Bulletin of the Women's Electoral Lobby, the September-October issue of 1988. Beatrice Faust said:

. . . there is more in pornography that is offensive than bad language and explicit sex and violence. We could include a machismo meter to identify stereotyped characters and situations, or excessively unrealistic sexual portrayals with general ratings going to those films that included plain, middle-aged or pregnant and menstruating women and x-ratings for those that were patently sexist. In terms of realpolitick, this is unlikely to succeed where the NVE classification failed.
She went on to say:

But in the current economic climate, there are more urgent priorities. Pornography is an effect, not a cause. To solve the problems of rape and domestic violence, we need to look beyond it to other causes such as the feminisation of poverty, alcohol, junk food, food additives, and the pollution of the environment.

I put it to the Senate that it is right that we consider these matters. I agree with the sentiments expressed by Senator Walters at the conclusion of her second reading speech when she said that, as legislators, it is our responsibility to do everything in our power to make Australia a safer and happier place in which to bring up our families. To do that, we must put an end to the scandalous situation of our homeless youth, to child prostitution, to child abuse and to domestic violence in general. It should be of interest to the Senate to note that the most frequent single category for both the perpetrators and victims of murder is the unemployed. Most murders and serious assaults occur in a domestic situation, where people know each other. The present taxation system favours high income earners and those without children. So there are many matters to be addressed. As I said before, I look forward to the committee stage of the Bill. I will examine the details of Senator Walters's Bill because I think the Bill canvasses issues that we should be addressing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy this afternoon to support Senator Walters's Bill, the Regulation of Video Material Bill. As a mother and a grandmother, any issues which affect women and families rate the highest priority with me. This issue should be of the highest concern to all women and families throughout Australia. The decision by the Labor Caucus last year to defeat the proposal by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to ban X-rated videos was a blow for women and families, not only in Canberra but throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has made a sham of looking after families. It has given in to yet another minority-the pedlars of pornography-an industry which makes money out of exploiting women and which caters to the more perverse elements in society. Honourable senators opposite talk about civil liberties, the rights of people to do what they wish and to pursue a normal, successful life to the best of their ability. I ask honourable senators: What could be a greater infringement on the rights of the majority of average Australians than the sort of dangerous material we are talking about today? What could be more harmful to the pursuit of those aims?

What we need is control over the distribution of X-rated videos and R-rated videos. We are discussing in Senator Walters's Bill the prohibition of the importation, sale or hire of X-rated videos and the reduction of violence in R-rated videos. Decent families, church groups, women's groups and many other organisations have been crying out for firm action to be taken to stamp out this smut.

The largest union in Australia, the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association (SDA), has called for a ban on X-rated material and its equivalents. It has urged the Government to ban the sort of material which honourable senators opposite find to be not harmful. I applaud the stance that has been taken by the SDA. The Trades and Labour Council of New South Wales has also expressed support for this action. The Caucus decision to set up a working party to resolve the confusion about the content of X-rated and R-rated videos is a weak excuse. I listed to Senator Hill's speech in this chamber this afternoon. He listed some of the organisations which have written to him and other Opposition members complaining about the Government's inaction in regard to banning X-rated and R-rated videos. Organisations such as the Women's Action Alliance and the Country Women's Association (CWA) have called for these videos to be banned. All honourable senators would know the tremendous influence the CWA has throughout Australia. The Catholic Women's League and the Mothers Union of Australia, with 14,000 members, are very upset about the Government's decision. The Australian Church Women, the War Widows Guild, the Business and Professional Women's Association-all of these organisations-feel very concerned indeed that action has not been taken to stop the X-rated video industry, with Canberra the porn capital of Australia.

We all know too that the Attorneys-General from all States recommended the banning of X- and R-rated videos. Indeed, the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, recommended the same course. That decision, of course, was overturned by Caucus. These videos are still available for distribution and sale in Canberra. The figures on the number of people who have signed petitions were very interesting. Petitions from 16,854 people against X- and R-rated videos were presented to the Senate, and petitions from 30,504 people against pornography were presented to the House of Representatives. These are very important figures and prove that people generally do not want these types of videos in Australia.

There is evidence readily available to show that these types of videos have a detrimental effect on our society. We are here for the good government of the nation and, if we are not doing that, we should not be here. I dispute the spurious arguments put by this Government that a ban on X-rated videos will drive them underground. That is a hoary argument put up by people who deliberately do not want the best for the community. We should remember that murder is done in private. Does that mean that we should legalise it so that it can be brought into the open? As a society, we closely follow what we legally permit to be viewed on television and videos. There is concern amongst many people that what is privately viewed by adults in their own homes today will ultimately be shown in public.

Many of us here today are parents. We realise that as parents it is difficult to control what our children watch and see during their daily activities. I am very concerned that many young people watching explicit sexual material, as well as violent material, may come to believe that such behaviour is acceptable. They might think that because they have seen it on a video it cannot be all bad. I sometimes wonder whether so much violence in our society today is due in no small measure to the R-rated videos and even the violent films shown on television. Sometimes even when we watch the news at night time we find that the first three or four items on the television contain violence. I sometimes feel this is, of course, a real problem as well.

While one can have some form of control in cinemas, control of access to television and video viewing is impossible. Governments have a responsibility to protect minors and others in the community from seeing material of a violent or sexual nature that would disturb them. I accept that parents have a responsibility as well. But parents, regrettably, are not always there to exercise control over television or video viewing and we cannot be too sure that those people over 18 years of age who see these videos are not adversely affected by them.

The best way to control these videos is to stop them altogether. It is time the Government realised its responsibilities. It is up to the Government to exercise control to protect children and all other members of the community from the psychological dangers of this type of video material. The only way this can be done is to prohibit the importation, sale or hire of them and to reduce access to them. I suggest to honourable senators that if they defeat this Bill they will be effectively pushing the pornographic industry onto 99 per cent of Australians who do not view these films.

I conclude my contribution by saying that I am concerned at the proliferation of what could only be described as anti-family behaviour and material in today's society. I have stood up for the family many times in this chamber. But I do not think that I have ever been more worried about the future of families in Australia than I am today. Families are the cornerstone of society. They form the basic structure on which we build our lives. In order to maintain our way of life, health, safety and order we must protect the interests of the family.

The Government can only stand condemned for its weak-kneed decision last year not to ban X-rated videos, which is no good for women, no good for families, no good for children and no good for Australia. The Government has abrogated its responsibilities to the community when it relies on Senator Walters to introduce this Bill instead of taking action when it could. If we truly support the concept of families as the basis of society, we will protect and preserve them by voting for Senator Walters's Bill. I must say I commend her sincerely for bringing this Bill into the Senate. We will vote to ban X-rated videos and to reduce the violence in R-rated videos. I commend the Bill to all honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been said before that wherever there is a problem there is always a simple answer and it is always wrong. This is one of those areas. In listening to the debate, both now and previously, I have been struck by the incredible frequency with which honourable senators impute bad motives to anybody who happens to disagree with them. It is a pity that this chamber cannot take cognisance of what people outside say about us and raise the level of debate so that we actually talk about the issue rather than always seek to denigrate our opponents.

SPEECH.PARA: There was an example this afternoon. Almost every speaker who has spoken in support of this legislation has attacked Government members who have not contributed today, by saying that, as they did not agree to ban it, they are in fact in support of it. That is a patently absurd proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think so.

—If Senator Boswell would not mind sitting and listening for a while, instead of just wandering in to the chamber, he might actually learn something. One can totally disagree with the content of pornographic videos and still not suggest that they be banned. I want to use as an example something that I have been concerned with in the last five or six weeks as a member of the Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority, which is inquiring into the drug trade in Australia. I want to give an example because there are a lot of connections that when one wants to wave one's arms about and take the simplistic approach one tends to miss.

SPEECH.PARA: If honourable senators have the time, I recommend that they go through some of the transcripts of that inquiry. Time and time again in public meetings people who were totally, adamantly and violently opposed to the drug culture in this country reluctantly told us that they believed we needed a different method of banning drugs. They did not appear before the Committee because, as has been suggested here this afternoon, they support drugs and therefore want them decriminalised. They appeared because they are opposed to drugs and they know that the method we have used to date is failing. I hope that the imputation of bad motives might not have to be such a continual and pervasive part of the debate in this place. I hope that these issues, which Senator Walters recognises in bringing on the Regulation of Video Material Bill as being serious for the community, are not dealt with in a trivial, demeaning and politicised way to score points for Saturday's election. I presume that the Bill brought before us this afternoon was not for that purpose. I could throw around such accusations, but I do not think they help the debate or this chamber's purpose. I hope that further contributors to the debate get themselves out of the gutter and stop imputing bad motives to others.

I return to the example I gave of the drug trade. The Committee to which I referred heard in evidence that last year 17,000 Australians died as a result of tobacco related illness; 3,000 died from alcohol related diseases and 300 died from illness associated with all other drugs. When we attempted one and a half years ago to have smoking in aircraft banned-something which has now occurred, thank goodness-everybody else in this chamber voted against our measure. When we attempted to ban advertising of the lethal drug that killed 17,000 Australians last year, everybody else in the chamber-Liberal, Australian Labor Party and National Party-voted against us. We are not talking about `sociological connections', to use Senator Walters's term; we are talking about 17,000 Australians dying. Despite that, honourable senators in this place would not vote to ban the advertising of tobacco. We should put into perspective the attitude of people who have been holier-than-thou on these issues.

Advertising of tobacco and alcohol will not be banned because interested companies provide large amounts into the pockets of political parties. That is why such advertising will not be banned in legislation in this place, even though we know it should be.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a scurrilous accusation.
—Order! If Senator Boswell wants to interject, he should do so from his own place.

—The advertising of alcohol will not be banned for exactly the same reason and another 3,000 Australians will die each year, making a total of 20,000 Australians if we include those who die from tobacco related diseases. I point out to Senator Bjelke-Petersen that quite openly and happily we allow the advertising of drugs that kill 20,000 Australians a year. That advertising does not take place in a separate room in our homes. The drugs are advertised on the television for children to see. I have not seen Senator Bjelke-Petersen vote against it or speak against it in this chamber, yet she made a sanctimonious speech with respect to the subject of the Bill before us. I would find myself much more in accord with what she said had she done that. Holier-than-thou speeches are great, but one must be careful to keep a proper perspective. People will not address such issues as the advertising of alcohol and drugs because of the vast amounts of funds which float around in tobacco and liquor company coffers and which become available at election time. That is the first issue that I am concerned about and it relates directly to Senator Walters's Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The second issue that I am concerned about also relates directly to Senator Walters's Bill. Senator Bjelke-Petersen called the issue a hoary old argument. I will trot it out again because, unlike her, for the last six weeks I have sat on a committee hearing of the problems we have with crime in this country. For years, I have sat on the National Crime Authority and I know what crime is doing. I come from Queensland and I know what crime has done there, even if she does not. It has perverted the judiciary, the political system, the police force and politicians. The money comes from crime and drugs and has been developed by a black market. Senator Bjelke-Petersen can say as much as she likes about hoary old arguments. There is nothing hoary about the crime taking place at the moment, as the Minister at the table, the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), well knows, being the Minister with some responsibility for this area.

Crime is rampant. It is almost out of control. Sitting on that Committee one is confronted with the terrifying spectacle of the crime in this country. I know from sitting on that Committee, as I am sure would every senator who bothers to read the annual reports of the National Crime Authority, where the funds come from. The funds that float around to corrupt and pervert the institutions of this society come almost exclusively from the drug trade. We banned that trade with the best of intentions because everybody in the chamber knows that it kills people; it destroys their bodies and their minds. A week ago we had evidence from the Australian Federal Police that 70 per cent of property crime is connected to drugs because the drug habit needs to be fed by further drugs. Hence, people have to break into homes, cars, and shops to feed a habit that can cost from $300 to $500 a day. Having seen the devastating effect of drugs on individuals, with the best of intentions we banned them. I do not know whether there are any other methods of dealing with the problem. I am unsure. I find it one of the most horrifying things that I have had to confront in the time that I have been in this place. However, I do know that our current methods are not working.

I hope Senator Walters listens to my remarks on the market for and supply of drugs, because those areas seem to be central to the issue and should not be ignored and tossed aside in the flippant way in which Senator Bjelke-Petersen tossed them aside. We know that the drug market in Australia is growing. We also know about the other side of the equation, that is, supply. We know that it is also growing. We spend untold millions of dollars in this country, although the figure is not yet available. I hope that the joint committee will be able to quantify the figure we spend. We spend almost totally and completely on the element of supply. The little that is done to educate people about drugs is done by voluntary groups, with some help from government. These include such marvellous groups as Life Education, Ted Noffs's organisation, and a number of others; I cannot mention them all here. There is splendid work being done in the area, but basically by voluntary groups, with some government support. Belatedly, education departments around the country are trying some reasonable drug education, unlike what was served up in years gone by. Some public money is being spent in that direction, but the amount of money allocated to trying to control the market is infinitesimal compared to the money being spent on trying to control supply.

Senator Walters has seen something she does not like and most honourable senators would probably agree with her on that issue. In our community when one meets something one does not like, there are a number of approaches available. Probably the easiest and simplest approach, as I said at the beginning, is to ban it. Unfortunately, in a pluralistic society such as ours that simplistic approach, I believe, is not only illusory in terms of controlling the market but it is also illusory in terms of controlling the supply. In fact, worse than that, it can do positive harm to the institutions of our community. I point that out in the analogy I have used with regard to drugs.

The market seems to be relatively well differentiated in Australia. Various studies that have been conducted, various questionnaires and so forth, seem to suggest that approximately 40 per cent of Australians at some time have viewed the non-violent erotica material that is available from the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). My own State of Queensland is the largest purchaser of that material through the post.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know that? Have you some figures?
—If Senator Boswell had taken any interest in this matter and had done his own research--
—I am. I am asking you a civil question. I am asking you where you obtained your information.

—It is quite easily ascertained. All Senator Boswell has to do is ask and he can find out the number of people in Queensland who actually buy it through the post, compared to the number of people who buy it from other States. People selling it from here are quite happy to give the figures. All Senator Boswell has to do is ask. About 40 per cent of Australians may have viewed one of these videos. Indeed, at one time in my own State of Queensland-Mr Acting Deputy President, you would probably remember the time because you operated at that very time in the police force-one of our censors was the main source of pornographic material in Queensland. He reproduced this material and sold it through the police stations to football clubs who held blue movie nights for fund-raising. You probably know the person I am speaking of, Mr Acting Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to see, from the figures provided in the ACT, that the return rate is about 4 per cent. There are a number of reasons for that, one of which is cost. My understanding is that hiring one of these videos costs around $25 whereas buying one costs about $50. If there were any grounds for banning the videos, it would be on the basis of complete lack of artistic merit. In that type of exercise, once bitten is twice shy. I think most Australians are sensible enough not to part with another $25 of their hard-earned money for that type of material, which is of such appalling quality.

What we know about the market is that there are people-male and female-relatively young, generally single but often married, who want this material for a range of reasons, obviously sexual. Sex is not a crime in Australia; it never has been and, hopefully, it never will be. It is a healthy human activity. The depiction of sexual activities occurs in an enormous range of movies, some of which are even classified for general exhibition. An example of this is kissing.

In terms of the classifications under the current regime the various depictions become more and more explicit to include the things Senator Walters has been open enough to put down in her Bill, unlike the rather coy way in which they are currently defined in the main Act, as suggested before by Senator Jenkins. In the classification of the market, we have people who are seeking these materials for a variety of sexual reasons. As I say, this does not constitute a crime; it never has and never will.

The market, I suggest, is unlikely to move. I have not heard any argument that the market is likely to diminish. As with drugs, the only way in which that market is likely to diminish is through reasonable educational programs and a change in values within our community. These factors have nothing to do with banning or not banning. As we have seen with the drug exercise, from the moment it was banned until now the industry has grown in leaps and bounds; the market has grown every year; the supply has grown every year. The only movement in the drug area, in terms of meeting and trying to wind back that market, has been through reasonable education programs directed towards the values of people within our community. I am not arguing about what people like or dislike; I am arguing about the efficacy of this particular exercise, whether people like to watch these videos or not. It is only by directing one's attention to the market that one will have any hope of success. I can assure Senator Walters that in directing her attention to supply she will have no effect whatsoever.

There is an added reason for this. To take my own example, I own a video camera. Quite a few people in this country own video cameras, if the figures are anything to go by. If that is not the case, somebody is actually hoarding them. Videos are widespread within the community. As a community, we have a larger penetration of videos than anywhere else in the world, even in excess of the United States. We have a larger number of videos per household than anywhere else in the world. My video camera also has the capacity to be a video machine. I therefore have two videos and a camera in my home. I have all the equipment necessary to establish an industry to produce these movies. I do not need any more equipment. That equipment is easily purchasable in any store anywhere in Australia, at a relatively low cost. Technology is such that the reproduction from one video to another is of such high quality that it is the method used to produce videos for the industry here in the ACT. One simply dubs from one machine to 25 others and gets a copy. It is a simple, technical process.

To return to the drug analogy, even if we interdicted supply coming from overseas-which we do not do in this area because of the enormous number of ways in which drugs can come into this country-does Senator Walters really think, in terms of a clause in a Bill relating to the importation of video material, that we would interdict the supplies of videos? We would not. I can assure her of that. If she wants to know what methods will be used for getting them in, I can tell her that also. I do not want to put that on the public record because they are methods that are used by the drug industry as well for bringing drugs into this country. We do not interdict the supply there. Where untold billions of dollars are available we will not do it in Australia. If we do it here, it will be at the expense of pulling away police and community resources directed at the heinous drug trade. Alternatively we will have to expend much larger amounts of money to do that interdiction. I do not know whether members of the community are all that interested in spending their dollars and in paying higher taxes to undertake that particular activity. They were never asked that, by the way. On all the polls that have been quoted in these debates members of the community have never been asked the question: `Are you interested in paying out millions of dollars to interdict this trade?'. If we put a ban on, let us make it very clear that we will have to spend public funds to enforce it, otherwise it will be a stupid law. A ban on this type of material is not enforced cheaply, because of the easy way in which it can be reproduced by simple technology available to every citizen in the country.

Apart from the terms of the drug analogy I was using on the importation of drugs, one of the other things which is exercising the minds of the people who are concerned about the drug trade in this country is in fact the home grown variety, the stuff that is done in the kitchen, the stuff that is done by chemists in their basement or by chemistry graduates who know about the operation of various chemical formulae and are easily able to concoct many of these substances once they know the correct amounts. I refer to the design of drugs-for example, taking a small amount of cocaine and then operating on that cocaine by splitting it up and creating from one small dose 100 doses of crack. We know what crack has done particularly to the youth in the United States. Thank God it is not here to a great extent within our community at the moment. That is an example of what can happen indigenously, without imports.

In the area of sexual depiction, one does not even need other chemicals, of which there may be a trace; all one needs is two people, three people or four people, whatever the particular film is that one is trying to produce. I do not know whether Senator Walters believes that somehow or other all these videos have to be produced in a major film studio. I do not know whether she has looked at them. I believe that she has seen some of them because she has been on the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. Their quality is so trashy that fairly obviously they could be produced in anybody's bedroom. The video makers do not need actors. Most of them do not employ actors already. They do not need a scriptwriter-because if there was a scriptwriter scripting the things that I have seen, he should be sacked. They do not need people who have any attributes other than sexual ones. These videos can be produced in Australia and then they can be reproduced in Australia. So the market will stay the same because nothing in Senator Walters's Bill actually tries to address the market. So we are not addressing the market; we are trying to address the supply, and yet it is impossible to address that supply.

The last point I want to make-I urge Senator Walters to take it seriously because it is a matter that I take very seriously indeed, having sat on a committee on drugs-is that this is a multimillion dollar industry and I do not want another dollar going to criminal tsars in this country. That is what will happen if we ban X-rated videos. They will simply wallow in that exercise and they will be happy with that exercise. It will be another lot of money into their pockets to corrupt institutions, to corrupt politicians and to corrupt judges. I have had enough of that in this country. I have had enough of it from our drug trade not to want to add to it by this. That is what I believe is the serious problem in this country-the corruption of our institutions. That is what will destroy our community. That is what is destroying our community at the moment. Unless we take that seriously, we are not taking anything seriously. I say to honourable senators with regard to this particular Bill: `Please address the serious issues which are affecting our community. Do not believe that because you do not like something there is a quick fix and it is just banning it and that that will solve the problem'. In our type of pluralist high technology community, banning videos will put $25m into the hands of criminals, and that is the last thing that I want.

If honourable senators want to stand up in this debate and carry on with the absurd imputations that we have had, I am going to take points of order on them in future, because it is disorderly. In closing, I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to call to order all senators who impute improper motives to senators in this debate as they have done in almost every speech that has been made to date without let or hindrance from the Chair.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
