DEBATE.TITLE: OZONE PROTECTION BILL 1988OZONE PROTECTION (LICENCE FEES-IMPORTS) BILL 1988OZONE PROTECTION (LICENCE FEES-MANUFACTURE) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: (Quorum formed)
Consideration resumed.
OZONE PROTECTION BILL 1988
Clause 18 (Duration of licence).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was explaining before the suspension of the sitting for lunch, the amendment is to remove the figure `10' and replace it with the figure `5' so that a licence would remain in force for a period of five years and not a period of 10 years. I was explaining that the two reasons for that were that if my subsequent amendments are accepted-in other words, we are looking at a five-year phase-out-it would be appropriate then that the licence remain in force for only five years. I was explaining that, going beyond that, even if my later amendments are not accepted and one relies merely on the arguments which the Government earlier put down-namely, that although it was looking to implement the Montreal Protocol only at this stage, nonetheless it was anticipating that in the next few years as technology developed it would be possible to achieve a much faster phase-down-it is appropriate to limit the period of the licence to only five years. It would be clearly undesirable to have somebody with a licence which extended over 10 years and then find that two years in the future, which I believe is a reasonable period to anticipate, alternatives will be available and that those alternatives could be slotted in and for us to be locked in to a situation in which a licensee might claim that he had a licence to continue to use the existing chlorofluorocarbons because he had been granted a licence for 10 years. For those reasons, I believe that it is appropriate that the period of 10 years for a licence be reduced to a period of five years only.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 19 to 29-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of questions which require certain clarification by the Minister. Senator Cook, ably assisted as he is at the moment, will undoubtedly be able to give this clarification because his advisers know all about these clauses at this stage. The passage of these clauses might not be as easy as the passage of clause 18.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the position of what one might call late entrants into the market-that is to say, people who had a quota. This matter is dealt with in part IV of the Bill, starting at clause 23. Part IV deals with people who might be described as late entrants into the market, who started their operations in 1986, the calendar year upon which the figures for the allocation of quotas are based and who, in recent years since 1986, have grown in terms of their market share. As the Minister would know-the Minister has had discussions on this matter-I refer particularly by way of example to a company called Casnik Pty Ltd which operates in the electorate of Macquarie in New South Wales where my colleague Mr Alasdair Webster has been assiduous in looking after its interests. This company is concerned that it will be put in a disadvantaged position because it came late into the market. It has built up its market share over the last couple of years and it is concerned that it will be particularly disadvantaged by the operation of the quota provisions of this legislation.

I believe that that is not necessarily the case because there are areas where exemptions might be provided for companies such as Casnik, which has a substantial business in the defence industry and, therefore, would be able to get certain exemptions, under various provisions of the legislation dealing with the national interest, for its supplies of cleaning material for the defence industry. It is primarily involved, for example, in the cleaning of circuit boards for the Royal Australian Air Force. I believe that that is part of the electronic operations for which some chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) are still used, particularly CFC113. I simply want from the Minister, if the Minister is ready-I will not keep talking until Senator Richardson gets here-some sort of indication that companies that are late entrants into the market will not be specifically disadvantaged by the passage of this legislation. Other companies may not take up their full quota entitlements-I am leading the Minister somewhat-and, therefore, quota entitlements say be taken up by people who did not necessarily have them in 1986. Can these sorts of reassurances be given to operators in that area? Will the Government always be giving sympathetic consideration to small businesses which it would not want to pick on and disadvantage simply by the passage of this legislation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the point that has been raised by Senator Puplick. Let me quickly exploit my new-found knowledge on this subject before the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) arrives. The Minister, who has just arrived, may wish to gather his papers because I think I can answer the question that Senator Puplick has raised. If I cannot the Minister can supplement it. Of course, we would not comment on any company; nor is the honourable senator, I note, inviting us to do that. If companies came in to the market in 1986 they can seek licences in their own right. If the market share has increased they can seek some discretion on defence force commitments and, when they do, that issue will be considered on its merits.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the Bill is designed to ensure that there is no destruction of any new industries. That is not the intention of the Bill. But we are not encouraging any new industries to establish in this field. Where a market share increase can be demonstrated that will be considered, appropriately, on its merits. I do not know whether that is a sufficient guarantee for Senator Puplick. If it is not I will ask the Minister to supplement that point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very disturbed to hear Senator Puplick speak so eloquently in defence of industry. When my own Bill was being debated, he similarly eloquently supported the case for industry. I wish he were as eloquent in defending the rights of the environment and the rights of ordinary people to an environment less polluted by short wave ultraviolet radiation. I point out that the matter of solvent use can be adequately addressed by the use of alternative solvents. Moreover, solvents in the electronics industry, to which he specifically referred, can be handled in closed systems so that one can achieve almost a 100 per cent recycling of the material which would evaporate from those circuit boards.

SPEECH.PARA: As I pointed out earlier, that process was aimed at in my private member's Bill, against which Senator Puplick spoke very strongly. I am disturbed to hear him argue so strongly in favour of industry where industry needs no protection, where alternative mechanisms are available to allow people to use alternative solvents or, if using CFC113, to recycle it to a very high level so that very small amounts are lost to the atmosphere.
Clauses agreed to.
Clause 30 (Ascertainment of size of quota-initial allocation in respect of export of CFCs).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Page 13, subclause 30 (1), line 41, leave out ``3,800,000'', insert ``2,300,000''.

The clause which is before us is the most pernicious within the Government's Bill and I hope that the Opposition will support my amendment. The Government has made a great deal about this Bill giving effect to the Montreal Protocol and going beyond it. The Montreal Protocol takes 1986 as the reference year. It seeks initially to freeze the production, importation and export of ozone depleting substances at the 1986 level; to move to a 20 per cent reduction of the 1986 level by 1993; and to a 50 per cent reduction by the end of 1999. With respect to exports, this clause in the Government's Bill does not take 1986 as the reference year-it takes a figure which is very close to the 1987 export year. The effect of that is that in 1986 we exported 2,300 tonnes of these substances and in 1987 we exported 3,800 tonnes. The Government, quite deliberately, is moving away from both the intention and the purpose of the Montreal Protocol to establish a much higher initial level for the export from Australia of ozone depleting substances.

It is worth mentioning that it goes on and compounds the error of this clause by not seeking to reduce exports by a fixed absolute amount in 1993 and 1999; rather, it sets annual quotas and reduces those quotas by 5 per cent per year. Again, it is not an absolute reduction of 5 per cent each year based on the initial figure of 3,800 tonnes, but 5 per cent per year with respect to the previous year's quota; in other words, an exponential decay in exports in which the reduction each year is less than the reduction achieved the year before. The effect is that Australia will not achieve a 50 per cent reduction in exports until the year 2013 instead of, as under the Protocol, the year 1999. As a result, manufacturers are allowed an enormous loophole in exporting ozone depleting substances, which would not be the case if the full application of the Montreal Protocol applied. It is perhaps the worst example of the consultation which has gone on between government and industry and which has been made a great deal of by both the Minister and industry. Clearly, this consultation has led to the Government placing a very convenient loophole in the legislation through which companies can continue to manufacture and export ozone depleting substances.

The effects are quite disastrous with respect to the alternative approach which we might take to the control of these substances. Honourable senators will recall that the legislation which I introduced into this place took an alternative line. Rather than seeking control of manufacture, import and exports, it sought to control by way of recycling and emission controls. If that legislation, which is still on the Notice Paper, were debated to its completion and passed, I believe that we could achieve about a 95 per cent reduction in the emissions of ozone depleting substances from Australia very quickly. Under those conditions we would not need to manufacture nearly as much of these materials. What would happen to the excess manufacture? The companies, according to the clause which the Government has put in the Bill-the loophole which the Government has written in-could merely export their excess production. The loophole would completely circumvent any later efficacy which the passage of my Bill would have.

The Australian Democrats will seek to divide on this matter if it does not receive the support of either the Government or the Opposition. I make a very strong plea that the amendment be accepted and that we replace the 3,800,000 units expressed in the Bill, in terms of ozone depleting units, with the figure of 2,300,000, which would bring the figure into line with the 1986 level of exports and into line with the terms of the Montreal Protocol, as it should be-according to what the Government claims it is doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not support Senator Coulter's amendment. It is correct to say that his proposal winds back the permitted quantity of exports of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) to the 1986 base year. The Government Bill before us in effect deals with an export quota which is to be based, roughly, on the 1987 level. Perhaps it would be better to say that it is the current contractual level. I think that that is a more accurate way of putting it as far as permissible quantities are concerned. The principle of retrospective operation, particularly of legislation which in that sense imposes penalty, has been the subject of considerable debate on a number of occasions. We on this side of the chamber have made it quite clear that the imposition of retrospective arrangements such as that which would flow as a consequence of Senator Coulter's amendment is not something that we are prepared to endorse.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to return to a point I made earlier in our consideration of the legislation. It deals with two matters relating to export and is worth repeating. Firstly, a genuine choice arises concerning the extent to which simply withdrawing Australia from an exporting role will achieve an overall global reduction of the problem as it is at the moment, or whether it will simply encourage other people to become manufacturers or to take up the slack which Australia's withdrawal from the field may have occasioned. I would not under any circumstances want to provoke Senator Vallentine to come back into the debate, but it is precisely the same argument as one has about the export of uranium.

I invite Senator Richardson to comment on the parallel in that respect in order to give him the opportunity to draw the fine distinction, which he may wish to do, between the Government's position and those strands of the argument pursued from a consistent point of view on this side of the chamber in part as to whether if we are to have a situation in which there will be an inevitable use of certain products-in this case an inevitable use of CFCs-simply walking back from the position as far as Australia is concerned, claiming the moral high ground on the matter but making no realistic contribution to the overall global problem, will achieve anything. In terms of Australia's exports-previously I mentioned the export of pharmaceutical products and discussed at some length the position in which Glaxo Australia Pty Ltd finds itself with the expansion of its program of exports-simply viewing that as something that should be walked back from because it will make a contribution to the global solution to the problem is quite unrealistic.

If the countries in our region are unable to obtain the product from Australia, they will be forced either to obtain it from other sources-and there are plenty of other sources around-or they will be pressured into getting into their own domestic manufacture. I put it to the Committee that the way in which they will go about manufacturing will not be as environmentally secure, safe, controlled, regulated or as much within the ambit of the Protocol and the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer as is the case with manufacture in Australia. If I believed that by Australia taking this step there would be a significant global reduction in the amount of CFCs with which we are dealing, I would find the proposition attractive. It is simply not attractive. It is simply a piece of window-dressing in that sense and I do not believe that it ought to be supported.

The addition the Opposition has already made to this legislation with the insertion of the exhortatory clause 3 (c) is designed to indicate what the Parliament's attitude on the overall question really is. As I said when discussing that matter, I do not believe advantage is gained by putting in specific dates or specific figures in the way Senator Coulter has argued. Undoubtedly Senator Coulter will say that the fact that I have at least been honest enough to draw the parallel with uranium indicates the degree of moral corruption that he believes pervades the whole of the Opposition's position. Having now been, for the first time in my political life, accused of being soft on industry and a rabid spokesman for the developers and industrialists and undoubtedly for the wicked capitalists of this world, as I was a few minutes ago-something that I wish a few more people on this side of the chamber believed-I do not believe that the proposition put forward by Senator Coulter is reasonable.

I believe this for three reasons, which I shall restate briefly. First, I do not believe in the legislation being passed in a way which has retrospective operation, going back to the 2.3 million figure rather than the 3.8 million figure which is in the legislation. Secondly, I believe that the initiatives which have been taken in areas such as the expansion of our pharmaceutical exports are important in Australia's national interest as much as anybody else's. Thirdly, the reduction from Australia will not constitute anything of a global reduction but will simply invite domestic manufacture in other places or replacement of Australian sourced material by material from other sources. For those three reasons Senator Coulter's amendment will not be supported by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish Senator Puplick's eloquence were matched by his logic, but in this case I am afraid that, woefully, it is not. He himself drew attention this morning to the figures relating to the pharmaceutical uses of the chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and pointed out that Australia currently consumes some 170 tonnes of CFCs in this use and that the industry itself has indicated it expects that figure eventually to plateau at about 260 tonnes a year. Yet here we are looking at the Government marking up the allowable exports beyond 1986 and the Montreal Protocol year by a matter of 1,500 tonnes. Certainly Senator Puplick cannot claim that the difference between 170 tonnes and 260 tonnes-which in my arithmetic is 90 tonnes-expansion is any justification for pushing up the allowable exports by as much as 1,500 tonnes. The figures simply do not match.
—We are not talking about tonnes, but about units.

—If Senator Puplick multiplies those figures by 1000, the figures come into line. The second point that showed a considerable flaw in Senator Puplick's argument was when he spoke about the current contractual level. He indicated that he placed a higher priority on commercial contracts than on the moral contract, and the legal contract which is implicit in our entering into the Montreal Protocol and on which this legislation is heavily based. In discussions with the Minister's Department, great emphasis was placed on the fact that most of this legislation relies on the external affairs powers. It relies on the fact that we are a signatory to the Montreal Protocol. Under that protocol we are obliged to take 1986 as the reference year. I would place a great deal more emphasis on that contract, which is both a legal and a moral contract, to take that lower level and to reduce from it, than on the argument raised by Senator Puplick, which places much greater emphasis on commercial contracts.

SPEECH.PARA: Even if one were to accept what Senator Puplick said on that matter, he is implying that the only way to fulfil those contracts is through the continual export of the substances listed in group 1 of Annex A of the Montreal Protocol. He totally ignores the fact that, as indicated earlier, alternatives-which are already available and which we believe will be available in commercial quantities by 1991-could adequately fulfil those contracts. They are substitutes which can be immediately slotted into existing uses in refrigeration and air-conditioning. The present Government makes a great deal of the need to develop up to date new technology to put Australian industry in a competitive position with respect to industries overseas and, if possible, to take a lead. Yet here Senator Puplick defends a continuation of a technology which, by its very definition and by the fact that this legislation is before us, is rapidly passing out of favour, which is out of date and which we know will not persist for very long. For those reasons I believe there is no substance whatever in any of the arguments put up by Senator Puplick. It is desirable for those commercial reasons that we restrict the export and quickly develop in Australia industries which make the alternative materials, the substitutes. Those are the things we will export to other countries rather than continuing to attempt to export particularly CFC11 and CFC12.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some dreadful distortions in some of the things that Senator Coulter has been saying. I hate to be cast in the role of the defender of Senator Puplick, but I am sure he can manage that if he thinks it necessary. I have been criticised a little by industry in recent times, and I have criticised industry when necessary. However, one cannot adopt the pose, as Senator Coulter has been doing for some time, that at all times industry must be under suspicion and must be criticised. The posing from Senator Coulter that has gone on in the last few minutes is quite extraordinary. One wonders what we will achieve if we decide to ban exports. I remember the 1982 Australian Labor Party conference-I have been trying to forget it for a while, but it is hard-where two things happened that were of note. The first was the now famous, or infamous, uranium debate which took a long time to get through and was all about, in the end, existing contracts. That started the Labor Party on the first of its long and tortuous examinations of the nuclear question.
—Tell us about the debate at the last conference.

—Which one? We have had quite a few. Let me deal with the Bill, if Senator Crichton-Browne does not mind. The other thing that happened at the 1982 conference was that Bob Hawke announced his first challenge, as I recall. That seemed to be buzzing around the floor at the time.
—I suppose you said, `Don't worry about it, mate'.

—In fact, I said that he would not win, and I was right again. The debate at the time centred on existing contracts and how any government could or would upon election move in and force companies to cancel contracts which had been running for some time. Obviously compensation was a question, but it was not only a question of compensation; it was the legitimate question of how reasonable it was to do that. In my view, and in the view of the majority, it was preposterous. I say the same thing here.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats continually say that we have to take this matter back to the Protocol and the Convention. The fact is that the Protocol and the Convention do not provide for export control. We do not have an argument about exports in that regard, and the Democrats know that. So they should not keep saying that we have to go back to the Protocol to find out what we should do about exports. This is the only country, I might add for Senator Coulter's benefit, that is talking about exports at all. For all the talk about how we have been passed by other countries-which is a nonsense-no one else is even worried about exports. But we are signalling to the industry-and the industry is prepared to accept the signal-that the exports have to be wound back. If we set 5 per cent as the quota for that winding back, it will be possible for the companies to manage that without causing too much disruption, not just to themselves-this is not an argument about just the companies-but to the customers.

Let us turn to the question of the customers. Already China has entered into the production cycle of ozone depleting substances, and, we are led to believe, is greatly increasing that production to meet the requirements of the number of its citizens who are now acquiring refrigerators. Throughout the developing world, or the Third World, it simply will not be possible to have all new technologies implemented immediately. Given that not every citizen in the Third World has an air conditioner or refrigeration-perhaps only a few-the reality is that it will be some time before that situation will be able to be changed. It will not change as quickly as that of a country such as Australia, and obviously it cannot. Clearly we use far more of these substances than anybody else. But all we can do by opting out and saying we will no longer export is make certain that either China steps up its production and takes up the slack-which it can quite easily do; with no reduction whatsoever-or, alternatively, that another country enters the production cycle. That is a certainty, because the need certainly will not disappear. If I can stand up at an Australian Labor Party conference-and, God knows, this may well get Senator Vallentine and Senator Dunn in here-and say that I have never believed that Australia had the right to say to the citizens of Japan or anywhere else, `You are no longer to have electric light or heat because we have determined unilaterally that we will no longer export uranium to you', then I must apply the same argument here. I cannot very well say that we will deny the countries of the Pacific and Asia the right to refrigeration and air-conditioning in the short term-and we are, of course, speaking only of the short term.

Of course, the 3,800 tonnes that has been referred to was chosen as the base line figure for existing contracts. There is no great secret about that. It has naught to do with 1986 levels. As I said, this proposal is not covered at all by the Protocol, which obviously recognised that exports would continue. Given that throughout the Third World CFCs are being looked at for relatively simple low technology refrigeration, and given that there will not be scope for huge reductions overnight in that consumption, any suggestion that we will dramatically reduce the quota here is not only wrong in principle but also it will achieve nothing at the end of the day. If we really believe that the 20 per cent reductions annually to which Senator Coulter refers would in some way be matched by a 20 per cent reduction in end use, then we are really deluding ourselves. I would hope that we are not all about the politics of delusion or about posing. I would hope just occasionally we could address what is actually happening. I believe that that is what this clause does, and, at the risk of a division, the Government indicates that it cannot accept Senator Coulter's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Senator Richardson what contracts have been entered into by Australia which underlie the figure which he has adopted. In asking that question I merely make the comment that if companies have indeed entered into those contracts, they have done so in the knowledge that Australia was a signatory to the Montreal Protocol and have proceeded to increase their exports in the light if the imminent signing and ratification by Australia of it. I have been trying to find the sections in the Convention and the Protocol which deal with exports. They are mentioned, but I just cannot put my hand on it. Certainly it seems to me that there is an implied responsibility with respect to exports, as there is with respect to production. So I would like to know from the Minister what contracts have been entered into, by which companies, for what amounts and with which countries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in a position to provide Senator Coulter with that answer. Were I in the situation of having the list in front of me, I would not provide him with it. Clearly there would be commercial in confidence implications with respect to such a list, and if one were here I would be more than reluctant to hand it over. So I cannot comply with Senator Coulter's request.

—In conclusion, I merely point out that the first 20 per cent reduction is easily achievable. I think the Minister himself is on record as saying there will be a rapid reduction by more than 20 per cent. So certainly we are looking at a situation in which any acute embarrassment which might arise because of the cutbacks anticipated in my later amendments and foreshadowed here would occur well down the track and, I believe, at a time when the alternatives are available. I point out again that the Minister seems to be saying that only those substances listed in group 1 of Annex A can fulfil those contracts. I would claim that if we were to take a different approach to this matter and move very quickly into the production of the alternatives, we would be able to fulfil those contracts with substances which would be less damaging to the environment.

—I ask the Minister to clarify a point. I understand the answer he gave with regard to confidential material that the Government would have. But I ask whether he will simply clarify what I took to be the import of a previous statement; that is, that the figure was arrived at by compiling the current forward contracts held by Australian companies. If that is not the case, how much short of that amount-I am not asking for individual companies or amounts-were forward contracts held by Australian companies?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —We derived the figure from the information which was provided to us by the Association, and it represents exactly what I said it did before-existing contracts. I thought I said it fairly plainly before. I did not think it was open to any other interpretation. I did not use that set of words to be clever. I can only repeat what I have said before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In furtherance of that matter, I ask whether the Minister has any information on the period for which those contracts will run and on whether the further figure of 5 per cent reduction per year relates to information which he has on those contracts or whether it is a somewhat arbitrary figure. Would a greater speed of reduction be achievable, given his knowledge of what those contracts are and the time terms of those contacts?

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner we were considering in the broad the figure of 3,800 tonnes which both Senator Macklin and Senator Coulter had been querying. That figure is lower than that for existing contracts and was arrived at by averaging the 1987 and 1988 levels of exports. That is to put the matter precisely; I had not made it clear. I was saying before the break that, obviously, Australia has gone further than the Protocol on the question of exports. As a developed nation we have a responsibility to provide less developed countries, particularly those in our region, which do not produce chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) with supplies of substances so that they are able to meet their needs for products which we might consider basic necessities. I referred to refrigeration and air-conditioning in that respect.

SPEECH.PARA: It is impossible to believe that low consuming, very poor nations can pare down consumption to the same extent as Australia can. Senator Coulter distorted statements that I had made. When I claimed that larger reductions were achievable, I was referring to developed nations such as our own rather than to countries that are still developing. Obviously, in the developing countries there is not the use of products that may be considered trivial by our standards, such as the use of personal care products or consumer packaging. Our actions will enable us to fulfil existing export contracts while at the same time signal to industry and to its consumers here and overseas that the Australian Government considers the issue important, that we expect industry to address it, that we expect reductions to occur and that we expect the consumers, the end users, even in developing countries, to acknowledge that there will be some small reduction over time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two interesting things arise from the Minister's reply. He still seems to be saying that the only chlorofluorocarbons which even people in under developed countries can use are chlorofluorocarbons 11 and 12. The whole point about the development of new substances is that they have properties very similar to chlorofluorocarbons 11 and 12 in terms of their boiling points and their expansion coefficients and, therefore, they can be substituted directly into equipment which would normally use 11 and 12. So the Minister's argument regarding under developed countries can be turned back. As I have indicated, we can develop these alternative substances here. We can make them in our factories and send them overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: I was also interested in the Minister's comments with respect to the 3,800 tonne level being between the 1987 and 1988 export levels and lower than the level for existing contracts, which seems to me to undercut totally the whole basis of Senator Puplick's argument as to why we should support that figure. Clearly, if it is less than that for existing contractual arrangements the Government is already coming in with a figure that is less. I wonder whether Senator Puplick, in view of his support for industry, would like to push the figure even higher.

The Minister has not answered the second part of my question, relating to the rate of reduction of 5 per cent which flows from this figure and whether it in any way accords with the nature of these contracts over succeeding years or whether it is an arbitrary figure that has been dreamt up by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry. I had neglected to answer that question. It was an oversight, it was not intentional. The 5 per cent reduction is not calculated to match the length of term of the contracts to which we were referring. It is, as I have just said, a signal to industry and consumers that we expect reductions. We have, therefore, set down a figure which we believe to be practical and able to be met, not just by industry but by end users in the Third World.

SPEECH.PARA: As a general point, which I have made a number of times, I do not believe that the debate on this legislation tonight is the end of this discussion. We will be back next year. No doubt as a result of the renegotiation and revision of the Protocol we will have the pleasure of doing this again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of us will not be back next year.
—It will not, in all probability, be me; it will be another Minister in the next Hawke Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 31 agreed to.
Clause 32 (Ascertainment of size of quota on renewal).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Page 15, subclause 32 (1), line 24, at end of subclause, add ``and reducing the figure thereby arrived at by the figure that is 20 per cent of the quota that applied in the first quota period''.

This amendment is aimed, as I have already indicated several times in this debate, at achieving a five-year complete phase out or, in other words, a twenty per cent absolute reduction each year. That was why the figure is tied back to the first quota period. I will have more to say about the tying of the reductions to the immediately previous quota period when we get on with the next clause.

In relation to this reduction, I ask the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) about the use of corporation powers. In discussing this matter with members of his staff, I had been led to believe that the Minister's concern over accepting figures different from the Montreal Protocol related more to concern over the use of corporation powers and mixing those powers with the external affairs powers under the Constitution than to the practicability of achieving faster reductions. I am a little puzzled that, this evening in debating the suggested amendments so far, the Minister has relied entirely on arguments based on the notion that to attempt to achieve faster reductions would be practically impossible. I wish to know to what extent the Minister's arguments, both on this clause and on my other amendments disputing the thrust of my contentions, are based on a concern which he has over the possible dependence upon powers other than the external affairs powers. I ask further whether he has any doubts about relying on the corporation powers in section 51 (xx) of the Australian Constitution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about the difference between a constitutional preference and a practical imperative on this occasion. It is not exhortatory. If one looks at what we are examining now, we are being asked to amend the Bill to incorporate a total phase out of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and halons by 1995. One would have to query on what basis this date was chosen. Is it because of some evidence which has come to hand which indicates that this will be the practical time? Is it because substitutes for all the current uses will be found by that particular year? If the answers to those questions are yes, I would be fascinated to hear the details. I would like to know just how Senator Coulter came by that date because all of the information that I have suggests that that just is not possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some examples. At present, there are no known substitutes for the halons. As we have all agreed, the first priority is to limit the usage of ozone depleting substances. I think that that is at least a common ground around the chamber and I have no doubt that there will be considerable success in reducing usage over the next few years. Substitutes for essential uses in respect of halons, nonetheless, will not be available in commercial quantities by 1995.

Earlier, I referred to toxicity testing for the CFCs. I think I mentioned that the lifetime testing in that respect has some years to go before completion. It is hoped that the testing of those substitutes might be completed by 1993. If that is the case, one wonders just how much of those substitutes will be available in commercial quantities just two years later. I suspect that there will not be enough to go around and we would have to ask whether a total phase-out was possible.

Some essential uses of CFCs in aerosols will not have substitutes available in that time scale. Obviously, Senator Puplick's vested interest would be one of those areas in which that would be highly unlikely. It is even more than highly unlikely; it is just not on. I have also used asthma sprays, although fortunately not for some years now. I do not suppose the chamber is terribly interested, but I have not had to use a spray for nearly 10 years. Nonetheless, I know how important they are to so many people. With respect to refrigeration and air-conditioning units, even if there were a 100 per cent recycling, there would still be unavoidable losses. There would be leaks and accidents that would require some topping up with existing ozone-depleting substances. I do not understand how Senator Coulter can pretend that this date has any practical application.

In the coming years, this Government and, on the indications of Senator Puplick tonight, the Opposition, will be united in the desire to phase out ozone-depleting substances as soon as practicable, but we will not nominate arbitrary dates that at the moment are not technically feasible. Therefore, the Government rejects the amendment. From my comments I would have thought that Senator Coulter might have got the drift about the importance of the corporations power as against the foreign affairs powers as against the practical application.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to hear that reply and place on the record that my understanding in relation to corporations power is that within six weeks a committee will report on the corporations power. A large amount of legislation which is not to be proclaimed deals with the corporations power. The Government expects that power to be tested in the High Court this year and a judgment is to be given within about six months. My information is that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) gave evidence before that committee to the effect that the corporations power will hold and that the Commonwealth had the power to legislate in this area. I am pleased at least to the extent that the Minister says he is not now relying on the information which was given to me in relation to the corporations power in opposing the figure I have cited.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Puplick did earlier, the Minister used some quite misleading figures. He went back over the pharmaceutical figures, although the Bill clearly sets out exclusion clauses which would allow the continuation of those uses which both he and Senator Puplick on previous occasions have defended. Therefore, it appears to me that the argument regarding those essential uses does not hold any water whatsoever.

More importantly, the Minister questions why I have attempted to achieve a much faster rate of phasing out chlorofluorocarbons. I hope that the Minister looked at the graphs which I incorporated in Hansard when I spoke during the second reading debate. It is quite clear from what we know about the long residence times of chlorofluorocarbons in the stratosphere that once they get to the stratosphere the two chlorofluorocarbons concerned, Nos. 11 and 12, have very long residence times indeed. They are estimated to be in the order of 75 to 150 years. Those graphs were predicated on a very conservative estimate of residence times, namely, a half life of 30 years in the stratosphere. Nonetheless, the graph showed that under the Government's Bill as it stands the concentration of those chlorofluorocarbons, put there by Australia, would be greater 100 years from now than it was in 1986. In other words, the Government's Bill will do nothing effectively to reduce the concentration of chlorofluorocarbons in the stratosphere for which Australia is responsible. The effect of the Government's measure will be simply to flatten the curve. There would be a very slow decay after an initial rise. Eventually the 1986 level would be reached, but the level would not go down to that low level until well over a century hence. When the Minister questions why I chose such a short period, I point out that I chose it quite deliberately as being an achievable time frame in which to achieve the most rapid cutback in the level of CFCs in the stratosphere in the future. If honourable senators look at the curves on the graphs, they will see that even with a 5-year phase-out there would still be substantial amounts of CFCs in the stratosphere, put there by Australia, even under those stringent cutback terms.

For the first time, the Minister also brought into the debate the matter of halons. He indicated that there are essential uses for halons. I would like to know what those essential uses are, because it is my understanding that even some computer companies are now going back to the use of water in computer installations, finding that the halons are not as effective as earlier claimed. I refer to their use as fire extinguishants, a horrible term but one which one finds in the literature. Indeed, many computer components can be washed down and the computers can be returned into use. In the past, many people argued that halons had a unique and irreplaceable property. My understanding is that several of the major computer manufacturers now prefer to use water instead of halons. I find it very difficult to imagine other uses which could be properly classified as essential. For those reasons, I again stress my belief that a faster phase-out period is achievable. My reasons for choosing the shortest practicable time is that it will achieve a reduction in stratospheric ozone-depleting substances which the Government's Bill simply will not achieve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am always mindful of what my leader tells me. This week I and other Ministers have certainly been told to watch our language. Our demeanour has to be spot on. We are not to offend delicate sensibilities. However, I am straining at the bit when it comes to the comments Senator Coulter has just made.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing the honourable senator did was refer to the graph he put into Hansard. Really, I do not know how many honourable senators have had a look at that graph, but it is a joke. Senator Coulter must be dealing with a different Bill. The only other explanation is that he deliberately refused to read part VI. He cannot have taken that into consideration at all, because his graph equates the Montreal protocol with the Government Ozone Protection Bill 1988. Despite the fact that we are going at twice the pace, his graph depicts us as exactly the same. That is rot. It is either a deliberate distortion or it is ignorance. There is simply no other alternative. I cannot believe that Senator Coulter would not have read part VI. I am not going to read that section now. I am sure there is no need for me to read it now. But if after any reading of that section he can say that this is the same as the Montreal protocol, then I have serious doubts about him and the Australian Democrats. Mind, I have pretty serious doubts after this election anyway. I am more than concerned that he would even say something like that.

Senator Coulter then compounded that by the reference he made to, I think he said, several major computer companies which were doing away with the use of halons and using water. I do not know how many ships sail the ocean. I do not know how many planes fly through the skies. I do not know how many tanks roll around the Middle East or around Afghanistan or around a whole lot of other countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?
—I have no answer to that.
—You represent the Minister for Defence. Why don't you know these things?

—I do not know the answers to those questions, but I do know that the millions of computers in those planes, in those ships, and in those tanks to which I have just referred are all using halons. I know they are. The honourable senator knows they are. He cannot tell me that one fraction of one per cent equals a hundred. It never can, it does not, and it will not. I have tried in all of this debate to be reasonable, but any reference to that graph offends me greatly. The graph is just plain stupid, and any suggestion that in the computer industry halons have been done away with does not even merit discussion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just having a look at part VI, which I have here in front of me.
—It is about time.

—That is the part to which the Minister has referred. I see part VI deals with protocol countries; import of scheduled substances from non-protocol countries; export of scheduled substances to non-protocol countries; import of products containing scheduled substances from non-protocol countries. Perhaps the Minister would care to indicate precisely where, in part VI of this Bill, there is a substantial difference from the protocol which makes that graph in any way not honestly representative of the situation of the Government?
—Mr Chairman, I should also refer Senator Coulter to part V.

—Mr Chairman, the Minister referred to part VI in his speech, saying that I had not read it and that it was an explanation as to why my graph was a dishonest representation. I am referring him back to part VI and asking him to indicate from part VI why that graph was dishonest. Could the Minister please come clean? Has he read his own Bill or has he not? Can he indicate where in part VI there is a difference between what I indicated and the true situation?

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to:

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 33 (Ascertainment of size of quota in respect of export of CFCs on renewal.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Page 16, clause 33, line 11, leave out ``5%'', insert ``20%''.

I think that we have already dealt with the substance of this amendment; that is, to reduce exports by 20 per cent per year instead of 5 per cent per year as indicated in clause 33 as it stands. I do not think that there is any need to labour the point further except to draw attention again to the way in which the Minister has indicated that the adoption of the starting figure is not related to the exports of any particular year and was in fact less than the contractual arrangements; in other words, undercutting the arguments which Senator Puplick first put up in defence of those, and that the figure of 5 per cent reduction per year again, by the Minister's own admission, was adopted quite arbitrarily and does not relate in any way to actual long term contracts. The figure of 20 per cent which I have just moved is consistent with the figure on which we have just voted. I shall, therefore, not be calling a division on it, but I ask the Government and the Opposition, bearing in mind the arbitrariness of the 5 per cent figure, whether perhaps they would be prepared to consider some other figure greater than 5 per cent. As I indicated both in my second reading speech and earlier this day, starting from the higher figure of 3.8 million units and reducing it 5 per cent per year on a previous year's quota-in other words, an exponential decay rate-Australia does not get to 50 per cent of its 1986 exports until the year 2013. It worries me that that indeed is an extension beyond the 50 per cent cut by 1999 which is included in the Montreal Protocol.

I only partly accept the assertion by the Minister that the Protocol does not mention exports; the Protocol does mention exports. I would have to agree that it does not mention exports. I would have to agree that it does not mention exports in terms of precise cuts in exports, but I think that the controls on exports which are written into the Protocol are sufficiently clear that there is an implied cut in exports, which this Bill does not achieve.

So I ask whether the Government and the Opposition, if not prepared to accept the figure of 20 per cent, which clearly they are not, are prepared to accept some other figure which would indeed achieve a 50 per cent reduction in exports by the year 1999.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator REYNOLDS

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that it picks up an error whereby the Northern Territory was omitted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The history of clause 37 is perhaps worth dealing with. I regret that the situation has arisen that it has turned out in this particular fashion. In November 1988 representations were made on the part of the Attorney-General of the Northern Territory to Senator Richardson drawing his attention to certain matters which I think were then in what was clause 33 of the Bill at that stage before the Bill had undergone certain amendments. In effect, the Government of the Northern Territory was drawing attention to the fact that in the current Bill as we have it before us, clause 37 subclause (3) states: In this section, `Territory' does not include the Northern Territory. If one had read the structure of the whole of clause 37 one would have seen that that sub-clause defined `Territory' as excluding the Northern Territory. As a result, a difficulty arose in terms of the proper understanding of paragraphs (b) and (c) of sub-clause (2) of the same clause to the effect that trade and commerce among the States and between a State and a Territory, other than the Northern Territory, was covered, but not trade or commerce between a State and the Northern Territory or between a Territory other than the Northern Territory and the Northern Territory. It was necessary, therefore, for some amendment to be drawn up which would overcome that problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has introduced three amendments to this clause which exclude the Northern Territory, by definition, from the precise operations of those activities which are covered in clause 37 (1) (d); which relates to `a body corporate incorporated in a Territory' other than the Northern Territory and clause 37 (2) (c) which relates to `trade or commerce within a Territory, between a State and a Territory or between 2 Territories'. They are now to include the words `other than the Northern Territory' and sub-clause (3) which defines `Territory' to exclude the Northern Territory has now been removed.

As I understand it, that is the purport of the whole thing. In November last year Mr Manzie, the Attorney-General of the Northern Territory, made representations to my friend and colleague Senator Tambling, the senator for the Northern Territory. Indeed, he is the senator who most ably and almost exclusively represents the proper interests of the Northern Territory in this place. Senator Tambling raised the matter with me as the shadow Minister concerned and I had the opportunity to discuss these matters with the Minister's advisers. I am grateful to the Minister's advisers for those discussions. I will not necessarily try, as Senator Coulter has on a previous occasion, to relate in detail the nature of the advice which I received from the Minister's advisers, or the advice which I received subsequently from the Minister about whether all of this was necessary; that is something for the memoirs. The more important point to make, however, is that because of the way the legislation currently before us had been drawn quite clearly there was a hiatus, a difficulty, in terms of regulating the degree of interstate trade and commerce, either within a Territory or between a State and a Territory or between two Territories and the definition of a body corporate incorporated in a Territory read against the sub-clause which defined `Territory' not to include the Northern Territory. The amendments which have been moved by the Government this evening are designed to expunge the clause which defines a Territory to not include the Northern Territory and include in the Bill words to the effect that a Territory in each of the sub-clauses here relevant is to be taken as a Territory other than the Northern Territory.

With that precise and lucid explanation, which I am sure Senator Reynolds would have given if she had been asked in a nicer fashion, that is the purport of the Government's amendments as I understand them. I am sure that the Minister would be only too happy to indicate the nature of the very civilised relationship which has taken place to bring about this significant improvement in a piece of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the words of a great learned judge, I concur. I said that I would not graciously acknowledge Senator Puplick's role, but I will do my best to come within the definition of grace by saying that this matter was raised last year, although Senator Tambling's correspondence from the Northern Territory was raised with me because Senator Puplick gave it to one of my staff during the second reading debate. I was not aware of the correspondence prior to that. Advice at the time suggested that this was not a problem and that no amendment was necessary. Senator Puplick again raised this matter with me in the chamber, I think prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner. Being diligent, as I always am, I had another look at it and asked my staff and officers of the Department to examine the question one more time. On that further examination we came to the conclusion that Senator Puplick and Senator Tambling were right in respect of the representations they had made; hence the amendments that are before us now, which Senator Reynolds moved before I returned to the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Having listened to Senator Puplick I do not think I will go into any detail about what is in the amendments as he seems to have covered them syllable by syllable. Finally, I am confident that this will resolve the problem which Senator Puplick and Senator Tambling have drawn to my attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot allow this to pass or leave Senator Puplick with a territorial claim on the English language. I hope that, when he writes his memoirs, he does not write them in the terms which he used in his explanation tonight. The clauses, as originally presented, used the word `Territory' in two different senses and then excluded both senses. What we have before us is the exclusion of one of those senses.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 33-by leave-recommitted.
Clause 33 (Ascertainment of size of quota in respect of export of CFCs on renewal).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (10) Page 16, clause 33, lines 13 and 14, leave out ``quota period prior to the quota period in respect of which the application for renewal is made'', insert ``first quota period''.

I will not seek to divide on this matter. The amendment which I have moved is to tie the reduction of the quota to the initial quota; in other words, the 5 per cent reduction is a 5 per cent reduction with respect to the previous year's quota, it is a 5 per cent absolute reduction each year with respect to the first quota. Five per cent per year absolute would mean that we would get a complete phase-out over 20 years. A 5 per cent reduction on each previous year's quota would mean that we would have a much longer period; indeed, we would have an infinite series and we would never get a complete reduction. So I commend that amendment to the committee. I believe that it is a very modest reduction in the amount of allowable ozone depleting substances which could be exported. Therefore, it is certainly quite defensible, even within the terms which the Minister has outlined.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Coulter thought that my penultimate comment was a massacre of the English language, I inform him that we now have a most interesting one which occurs in the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Imports) Bill at clause 4 (3) and in the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Manufacture) Bill at clause 4 (3). In both cases the clause reads:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of subsection (1), where a licence is only in force for part of a particular quarter, that part shall be taken to be a quarter.

In fact, the Bill should read: `where a licence is in force for only part of a particular quarter, that part shall be taken to be a quarter'. The word `only' has been misplaced. I repeat that the Bills before us state:
. . . where a licence is only in force for part of a particular quarter . . .

The clause should read: `where a licence is in force for only part of a particular quarter, that part shall be taken to be a quarter'. What the Committee should do is make a request, I presume, on these pieces legislation so that the subclause would read: `where a licence is in force for only part of a particular quarter, that part shall be taken to be a quarter'. I am sure that the Minister and his erudite advisers will have no difficulty whatsoever in accepting the request that ought to be made by the Committee. Seeing that the principal Bill has to go back to the House of Representatives for amendment, I am sure that the Minister will be only too happy to accept a request to both of the Bills so as to remove the word `only' from where it appears at the moment and recast it so that, instead of reading `where a licence is only in force for part of a particular quarter' it will read `where a licence is in force for only part of a particular quarter'. In respect of the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Imports) Bill I move:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment to clause 46 with which the Committee is now dealing was moved on 8 November by the Australian Democrats, the perennial populists, who are ever eager to add a few dupes to their electoral base. They moved an amendment which, on superficial examination, seems to protect or enhance the interests of some women who have been separated. In fact, it would impose a retrospective liability for capital gains taxation in particular circumstances. The technical details were put on record by me on 8 November and can be found in Hansard on pages 2225-6.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition at that time-I presume in ignorance-supported the Democrat amendment. The Opposition now knows that the amendment would impose a retrospective tax liability, to which the Opposition says it is trenchantly opposed. As I said, I believe the Opposition made that original decision in ignorance, but rather than admit to its ignorance, and by implication its indolence and incompetence, I understand that it intends to continue supporting the amendment and hoping that nobody will notice. Let me make it clear that everybody who votes for this amendment is voting for a proposal which will impose on some people-admittedly a small number, but that makes no difference to the principle-a retrospective liability for capital gains taxation. So everybody who votes for this amendment is saying to the electorate of this nation that he or she has no objection in principle to the application of retrospective taxation liabilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is being especially kind tonight, and his remarks have to be taken with exactly the same grain of salt as that with which we usually take his remarks on whatever matter he is dealing with. He is simply trying to throw a dead cat into the chamber and obviously does not understand, nor has he thought through, the implications of what he has just said. The fact is that he admitted that the number who would be affected as a result of the amendment, if carried, is very few indeed. It is clear from representations that have been made, and I am sure the Democrats agree with this, that there are considerably more people who will be affected by this situation if the matter is not corrected tonight in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3).

SPEECH.PARA: The simple fact is that the Government introduced the capital gains tax on 19 September 1985. It then announced on 20 January 1988, nearly 2 1/2 years later, that it would exclude a certain group of divorced persons who will have acquired assets in the breakup of a marriage from their former spouse and who previously with that spouse controlled a family company or trust. It is a highly technical situation, but the balance of concern on this issue falls clearly on the side of giving the benefit of the doubt to those people, mainly women, who would be trapped in a situation where they will suffer the capital gains tax, a factor which the Government now refuses to acknowledge. That is why the Opposition supports the amendment. The Government can carry on about some technical aspect, but clearly in our judgment a number of persons will suffer if the Bill is not amended. Therefore, we support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take part in this debate, as I did on 8 November last. The Minister for Finance said that the Opposition is acting on this matter in ignorance, but I can assure him that that is far from the truth.
—You are not ignorant, you are just a hypocrite.

—I have never been a hypocrite and I am never likely to be one, even in this place. The Minister admits that this is a highly complex matter and that it imposes a retrospective liability for capital gains tax on someone down the track. The Government has had since 8 November last year to work out a suitable system under which the same benefits could be passed on to these people who are getting assets.
—It is not our job to sort out scrambled brains.

—I repeat that the Minister has had since 8 November 1988, with all the expert advice he has from advisers, to sort out this matter. On that occasion Senator Walsh did not know what this was all about and was leaning over to take advice from his experts so that he would know what to say next. The Minister has had since last November to work out a system to prevent anomalies such as he has now put forward. He could have removed liability to capital gains tax when such a tax has been incurred following the breakdown of marriage. This could have been done in relation to any property held in trust or in a company which has passed to a spouse in a breakup. Action could have been taken by the Government to prevent this problem, and I believe it can still be done. In fact, I drafted an amendment for consideration on the previous occasion to cover this matter. However, the Opposition decided to support the amendment suggested by the Australian Democrats. I believe that even the amendment I envisaged would have fixed the matter. I believe that the situation can still be fixed now. The matter was postponed on 8 November because the Government and its advisers could not produce the right sort of wording in an amendment. I am disappointed that after so many months the Government still has not reached a solution. I believe that a satisfactory end to this matter can still be achieved by the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment that is being debated by the Committee to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) relates to the roll-over provisions. The particular group of people affected are those who in the period between 20 September 1985, when the capital gains tax came in, and 28 January 1988 were involved in a breakup of marriage. Any transfer of property that took place prior to 20 September 1985 would not have attracted capital gains tax as there was not any, and post-28 January, the period covered by this legislation, the same consideration will apply. However, in that other period there is a large group of people who potentially could be disadvantaged, and some actually have been disadvantaged.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Finance raised what I took to be debating points, although the Minister has the unfortunate manner of not wanting to debate a matter but rather to abuse other people. That is his particular style. We can contrast his style in opening this particular debate with that of the Minister in the previous debate, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson). He was willing to debate in a robust fashion but without abusing people. In this way we can travel through legislation; we may not get what we want, but at least there has been an effective and robust debate. There is not a debate with this Minister, because he thinks that abuse is a substitute for reason.

We have not yet heard whether the Minister believes there are any people who have been disadvantaged by the current law. What he was saying is that there may be some people who will be disadvantaged by the amendment. It seems that the Minister will not accept that there are people disadvantaged by the current law. I found his last comment by way of interjection a very strange one. He said, `It is not our responsibility'. I thought it probably was. It is the Government's Bill; honourable senators opposite are in government. I would have thought that if unintended consequences arise from previous legislation-and this is an unintended consequence, as has already been admitted in the debate-and are pointed out to the Government, it is their responsibility to make sure they fix up those unintended consequences. If they find technical defects in amendments which are presented, they can do what was done last time-adjourn the debate. That was a most reasonable move for the Senate to take. We adjourned the debate so that the Government could go back and consider the matter. It is fairly obvious-as is obvious in respect of most of these matters that the Minister is involved in-that there has not been any reconsideration of the matter. There has been the bluster and the normal abuse hurled around, which is the substitute that this Minister uses. It does not worry me; I do not think it worries many people here. But it is a pity that the Government has not been willing to address this issue.

I believe that the Senate is compelled to press on with this amendment, because we know the difficulty is there and the Government refuses to address the issue. I believe that the Senate should support the amendment that was moved on 8 November.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Haines's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 24, clause 37, after proposed section 160zwa (14), add the following new subsections:
``(15) Where:
(a) a Crown Lease (in this subsection called the ``original lease'') of land (in this subsection called the ``original land'') has been granted to a taxpayer;
(b) after the grant of the original lease, the original land came to be vested in or held by a government authority; and

(c) the government authority granted to the taxpayer under a statutory law of the Commonwealth, of a State or of a Territory a lease (in this subsection called the ``fresh lease'') of the original land, or of that land less an excised area or together with an additional area;
then, for the purposes of this section, the fresh lease shall be taken to be a Crown Lease and to have been granted by way of renewal of the original lease.

``(16) If there was a period between the end of the term of the original lease referred to in subsection (15) and the beginning of the term of the fresh lease so referred to, that period shall not be taken to preclude the fresh lease from being regarded for the purposes of that subsection as a renewal of the original lease provided that the taxpayer concerned continued in occupation of the original land during that period under a permission, licence or authority granted by the relevant government authority pending the grant of the fresh lease.''.

This amendment proposes the insertion of new subsections (15) and (16). It relates to capital gains tax roll-over provisions concerning crown leases. The Committee will probably not remember, but during discussion on this Bill in early November last year an amendment was carried to the legislation which protected persons who were forced by compulsory acquisition to accept terms and conditions by the acquirer for crown lease land which covered somewhat different circumstances than were set down in the original lease held by the leaseholder. The amendment concerned a particular case known as Yencken, in Melbourne. The amendment was moved by the Australian Democrats and had the support of the Liberal and National parties.

I now bring to the attention of the Committee a similar case, which is the subject of the amendment I have just moved. It goes to show how technically deficient and difficult is the capital gains tax, as are any amendments which need to be made to it. The situation, which affects the holder of a special lease of crown property administered by the Land Administration Commission for the Brisbane wharves has been brought to the attention of the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Democrats. The lease had been held for 28 years until its expiry on 30 September 1985. Subsequently, the holder of the lease for those wharves applied for a further lease of the wharf area. It was initially permitted and an interim lease was granted until 30 March 1987, after which a rather more formal and complete lease was granted by the Port of Brisbane Authority.

The Committee will have noted that two different bodies are involved here, firstly, the Land Administration Commission and, secondly, the Port of Brisbane Authority. We are talking about the continuation of the same lease for the same property. Yet, under the present Bill as it is drawn, the commencement of the new lease would not constitute a roll-over for the purposes of the capital gains tax. The expiry of the lease would constitute the end of the capital gains tax free period which was available to the lessee in the first place. This means that the property acquired by the new lease would become, upon any disposal of it in the future, subject to the capital gains tax.

We regard that as very unfair, as it involves only a technical change in the name of the lessor, from the Land Administration Commission to the Port of Brisbane Authority. The nature and circumstances of the lease have not changed. It is totally unreasonable that the Government's legislation does not provide a roll-over facility which would keep any future gain free of capital gains tax, within the original intention of the Government's capital gains tax legislation. For those reasons, and bearing in mind the similarity of this case to the case behind the amendment passed by the Committee in earlier debate on the matter of crown leases in November 1988, we have moved this amendment. We believe that it is just and reasonable and it will have have the support of the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We support this amendment. I do not believe there is any need to go over what Senator Messner has outlined. The amendment essentially seeks to correct an anomaly that has arisen, an anomaly which, legitimately, could not have been foreseen when the legislation was drafted. State instrumentalities which change their base and move from having a crown lease to not having a crown lease, as in the Bretts wharves case, could have had the roll-over if they had been granted a crown lease. The amendment is reasonable. The number of instances of this is probably quite small. It depends on a number of exercises undertaken by third parties over which people who are in possession of the property in question have no control.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think it was ever envisaged in the legislation that, because of technical changes by groups totally outside the control of the people who have the property, people would be penalised in any way, or be seen as seeking to make a gain. In these cases they did not get any technical gain. We believe that the Opposition's amendment, as in the case of the amendment passed previously, will cover such anomalies and grant people the roll-over relief from the capital gains tax that should have been provided in the legislation in the first place. But we are not critical of this omission because, obviously, it would have taken an extraordinary person to have foreseen such circumstances arising.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be opposing the amendment. We regard it as a pretty inconsequential thing.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
