DEBATE.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT (GENERAL CAPITAL INCREASE) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 December 1988, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (General Capital Increase) Bill 1988 touches upon the provision of increased finance from the Australian Government to the tune of $1,250m by way of share capital subscriptions to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development-better know as the World Bank. Of course, it is that organisation which assists the development of the Third World countries and those lesser developed nations in the world which are seeking softer concessional loans to develop their infrastructure and lift the standard of living of their inhabitants.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is somewhat of a machinery one but it has been a concern of the Liberal and National parties for some time that there has been a lack of accountability and some problems with administration of some of the aspects of the World Bank's operations in lesser developed countries (LDCs). Without going into chapter and verse, it is true that there have been cases in which money has not found its way to the most effective point of expenditure and has ended up in situations which would not, without putting too fine a point on it, stand too much scrutiny. There have been examples of contracts and development projects which have been contrary to the general interests of some lesser developed nations. For instance, the one that comes to mind is the Amazon highway project in Brazil which was financed by World Bank money. It ended up being a total disaster, both financially and in other ways.

It is, therefore, the intention of the Liberal and National parties to draw attention in this debate to the distribution of funds by the World Bank. Our Government, which is represented on the World Bank by its nominated governors, should ensure that the administrators of the Bank follow appropriate controls and exercise accountability.

We are certainly not opposed in any way to the humanitarian objectives of the World Bank in the development of a better standard of living for those who live in lesser developed countries-quite the contrary. We believe the objectives are sound and, in general terms, quite necessary. All we are saying is that it is necessary for those aspects to be patrolled carefully and watched to a very close degree as we are talking about Australian taxpayers' money contributing to such schemes.

That is a vital matter. We take some solace in the fact that the World Bank has acknowledged many of the problems that have occurred as a result of some mismanagement of projects in LDCs and by some lack of accountability by those managing those projects over the years. Indeed, it is taking up the cudgels on its own behalf to do something to improve those circumstances. Nevertheless, it behoves this Government to ensure that it exercises maximum control and supervision via our governors on the Board of the Bank who should ensure that this is properly carried through.

It goes without saying that no nation can continue a commitment to the assistance of the lesser developed countries in the world unless it is prosperous itself and capable of meeting its international obligations. It has to be said that this country is faced with some problems in that regard. We have a situation in which the debt owed by Australia to the rest of the world is escalating. It was only two years ago that Australia's debt was about $90,000m. A few years before that, at the time this Government came to power in 1983, that debt was as low as $30,000m-about a third of what it was two years ago. But today it is approaching $135,000m. In the first three years under this Government the debt multiplied by three. In the following two years it multiplied again by about 50 per cent. But looking over the whole period of this Government, the debt owing to the rest of the world has increased by a factor approaching four. In other words, it has multiplied by four.

The concern that the Liberal and National parties has is that there is no sign of change in that trend. It is not reversing. Notwithstanding that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) told us last August that he was bringing home the bacon in the Budget of 1988, the truth is that the only bacon that has come home to the Australian people is an increasing amount of debt being left on their doorsteps. Generations of Australians yet to be born and their parents will learn very early in life that this Government created an enormous amount of debt that they will have to pay off from their own income. Therefore, it will affect the standard of living of every Australian in the future. One might say, a little cynically, that we may be forced to seek the assistance of the World Bank in the future to help us out of our debt problems. It is easy, of course, to be very negative about this Government and its economic management. Of course, there is much to be negative about-not only the debt but also the high inflation that is running at around double that of not only the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development nations but also the United States.

We have seen an enormous rise in taxes per head of population under this Government as it has refused to take action to stop bracket creep and the effect of inflation on people's income as they move to higher brackets and, therefore, suffer artificially high taxes as a result. The taxes are not artificially high but the rates are. Australians have to shell out more of their hard earned dollars as a result of this Government's policy on taxation than they did under any government in the past.

A family on average weekly earnings of around $480 a week is suffering tax at 46 per cent on the next dollar earned by the family. That rate is absolutely prohibitive to incentive. It demonstrates clearly the problem that this Government has in getting proper leadership in the economy. I will return to that point a little later. We have seen the collapse of productivity growth in the economy in recent months. That is continuing. The futile and ludicrous promise that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made that by waving some magic wand we would get rid of child poverty by 1990 has been demonstrated to be a totally empty and, more than that, cruel promise for the population of this country.

Returning to the point about debt, the most tragic lesson to be learnt from our debt situation is what is happening with our currency. The combined effect of high inflation and a lack of productivity growth means that Australian companies are developing an interest in investing overseas rather than in Australia, where Australians could be employed. Australian companies are taking their capital, their expertise and their best brains to set up industries in Asia, America and other places. The reason for that is quite clear. Dutiful managers have a responsibility to their shareholders. They need to generate enough profits to return suitable capital to those shareholders. Therefore, they find the place where the most gain can be generated. Because of this Government's policies, that means that they find a place off-shore, which is what they are doing. Given that every month we need $1,500m to fill up the gap in our balance of payments, we have to drag in that money from the world financial community. The money comes from those lenders who seek short term gain either in the currency-by fluctuations in the value of the Australian dollar-or from high interest rates. They will chase those two things as long as the economy of Australia is managed in such a way as to provide gains to them.

The Government is in a cleft stick because it has to maintain a policy in favour of high interest rates and a fluctuating currency to drag money into the country to fill up the gap of $1,500m every month. That is its policy. That is what it has to do just to meet the bills every month. The effect of that is that Australian companies wanting to invest overseas are taking capital, which would otherwise have found its way into productive investment in Australia, to overseas where it goes into equity development of new projects, new plants, and the like. Hot money to replace it flows in from those lenders and speculators from overseas who are prepared to lend to us because they see a short term gain.

What kind of country is it that borrows short and pays high interest rates, offering profits in the short term to pay for the long-term development of the nation? That is precisely what this Government is doing to Australia. It is not borrowing for the long-term advantage of the country by developing its resources. It is merely bringing in money which can find its way out of Australia tomorrow morning if the situation changes, thus leaving us exposed to speculators and international financiers. That is the effect of the Government's policy. It is a great tragedy that in the last six or seven years since the Hawke-Keating-Walsh financial team came to power that is what is happening to this country. It is a disaster of great proportions and the Government knows it, but it does not know what to do. All it does is say, `We are on track'. However, the Australian people want to know what track we are on because they do not know where we will end up. They hear from the Ministers that even such things as taxes are good for them. It is a funny thing that the Government can offer tax cuts on sales taxes on beer, as happened in the Budget last year, and say it is a good thing, but it says it is bad if a private brewer like Carlton United Breweries cuts the price of beer to the consumer by saving taxes. Where is the logic? It is obviously puerile political nonsense to argue that kind of case and Senator Walsh knows it.

The Commission of Taxation preaches to the Australian people that taxes are building a better Australia. The Australian people do not agree, as Senator Walsh knows. When the tax cuts promised by the Government come, the Australian people will know that their only purpose is political. The people will get back only what the Government has already taken from their pockets by not adjusting income tax brackets. The Government is not giving back anything that it has not already robbed people of. The people of Australia know that. They will not be fooled by a trick, such as that which the Government thinks it can get away with. It just shows how far out of touch with the Australian people the Government is. It has no concern for individuals or families. All it is worried about is its political survival.

The arrogance of the leadership of this Government is monumental. It is not leading Australians, it is not unleashing the capacities and abilities of the Australian people to solve the problems brought on by the Government. The Government is locking us into a political circle which cannot be defeated. Until the Government is thrown out of office, it will continue on a downhill path. If we could see how the Government could improve the debt situation of the nation and where it was taking us we might have some faith in the Government. No longer do we have any faith in the Government. As has been evident for a long time, the Liberal Party and the National Party certainly do not have any faith in the Government's capacity.

I would like to quote a few words from a speech made by Sir Arvi Parbo only the other day. He made the very important point that the basic need for Australia to get itself out of its financial and economic problems is better performance. In Adelaide last Friday he said:

Our basic need is for better performance. This includes working harder, but it means far more than that. It means improving our skills, removing artificial obstacles to the efficient functioning of the economy and, above all, developing a community attitude which supports and applauds achievement. It means encouraging, not discouraging, the natural desire of individuals to improve themselves.

That is the essence of what the Government should be doing. It should be leading people to improve themselves, showing them ways in which they can do that. What has the Government done to improve the educational prowess of our people? It has introduced all kinds of projects which have been total failures. I refer to the Priority One scheme and the community employment program. The community employment program was an absolute failure in terms of giving people new skills or opportunities. The Government's schemes have been total failures. Sir Arvi Parbo mentioned `removing artificial obstacles to the efficient running of the economy'. We need look no further than the waterfront to see the problems in relation to our export trade. The Government refuses to address the problem because it does not have the guts to face up to its union masters.

The Government talks about telecommunications. Telecommunications provides one of the greatest opportunities for the Government to develop new industries in this country, but it sits with a dead hand on Telecom and on the Overseas Telecommunications Commission. The Government will not allow them to be deregulated without putting them in a monopoly position first. It takes that position because it wants to protect the union membership of those organisations. The Government should free up those organisations and allow them to compete fairly with the rest of the telecommunications industry. It would see the flowering of a brand new industry with enormous opportunities for Australians to participate and to build a new technological base. But no, that is not capable of being achieved by the Government because it is tied hand and foot by its commitment to the trade union movement. Let us look at the labour market. The biggest problem of all resides with our arbitration system and the way in which we fail to reward excellence, to reward opportunities, to give people a chance to improve their circumstances. The Government fails to recognise that the key to getting Australia back on its feet is to give people opportunity. But it does not do that. It will not face up to that. It is too hard. The only parties which have the solution are the Liberal and National parties through our industrial relations policy, conceived and designed by John Howard. That policy is the one which, when in government, we will put into place. It will drag Australia out of its problems and produce a new and vibrant Australia with an outlook that, as Sir Arvi Parbo says, will support and applaud achievement, not sit on it and drive it further down into the ground, as this Government is doing by every action it takes.

What is missing is leadership; that is what this Government does not provide. The Government talks about levers, about bits of paper with figures on them. If talks about numbers each month, and each week if it can. But it does not talk about people. It does not talk about families. It does not talk about the living standards which people have to endure under this Government. The average family with two children has suffered a decline in its standard of living of $58 a week since Labor came to power in 1983. Every family has lost $58 a week of its purchasing power. This means that it is tougher in the supermarket; it is tougher when one goes to buy petrol at the pumps; it is tougher, most of all, when it comes to paying off the mortgage every month. Not only is there less money in the pool from which to pay the mortgage but the payments have risen as a result of higher interest rates. This is a deliberate result of this Government's policies.

These are the effects on families and on individual Australians. These are the things which worry Australians, not only at a personal level as to how they can make ends meet, but also at a national level, because they see that debt of nearly $140,000m growing bigger and bigger every month. Under the Fraser Government, the percentage of exports being used to make interest and debt repayments was about 6 per cent of exports. That figure is now up to about 20 per cent. Those are the facts. That is why this country is in a hell of a mess, and this Government is not in a position to lead us out of it, nor is it capable of doing that.

The Government has tried for nearly three years to convince the Australian people that it has the answers-by talking up the economy, by telling us lies when elections come around, by telling us on the Friday before an election that there are not going to be interest rate rises and on the Monday interest rates go up. They have become past masters of that kind of disposable promise. That is the situation we face. The Government will not have to meet the problems. It will be out of office. It will be gone. Senator Bolkus will be sweeping the streets of Adelaide again. But although the Government will be gone, the Australian people will still be here, picking up the pieces of the wreckage of the Hawke-Keating Government when that Government is long gone and has been forgotten.

As I mentioned, our policy is a positive one. We adhere very strongly to the principle of encouraging individuals to do their best by providing them with incentive, something that this Government does not do. Our industrial relations policy will free up people's opportunities. People will have the freedom to move from job to job and to seek to improve themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —No jobs!
—I did not hear that interjection by Senator Jones but I take it that he was saluting us for our courage in putting down this policy, and I thank him for that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party has been peddling a lie recently that our approach to industrial relations would somehow lead to a wages breakout. Of course that is not true. The Government's argument is based on the proposition that we would maintain the present system of arbitration. However, if it read the policy it would understand that under our proposals that system would be significantly altered and employers and employees would be freer in their ability to make their own arrangements; productivity could grow; there would be greater production and therefore greater revenue to be split up between managers and employees, so that there would be better payments available to individual employees and their families.

That is how the situation would be under the Liberal and National parties' policy on industrial relations. If we are to recover at all from the mess the Labor Party has brought us to, we need to adopt such policies. We need to encourage people to work harder and better and, by so doing, to improve themselves. That is why the system has to change. This Government cannot change it because it is locked into its own political situation. It is controlled by the Australian Council of Trade Unions in Melbourne and as a result cannot adopt new policies without disrupting its own political situation. That is why the accord is dead, but the Labor Party will not pronounce it dead.

In summary, we need a far more progressive outlook from a new government, one that is prepared to lead people and to provide them with opportunities so that they can improve their circumstances. That is what Australia needs. That need will not be met under this Government. We, on the other hand, will be able to improve the total performance of the Australian economy-as Sir Arvi Parbo said last Friday-in such a way as to produce more goods more cheaply and sell them on the world markets in an effort to overcome our present difficulties in marketing very costly goods and services. In that way, we will overcome the deficit in our current account balance. Of course, we do not promise that this will be achieved overnight. What is needed is a government that is prepared to change direction and, indeed, to move the nation and its people in the right direction. This Government is locked into a situation where it cannot change our direction, and the situation is getting worse. Senator Bolkus, even in his saner moments, would recognise that.

What is needed is the institution of new systems to reward effort, so that people see the circumstances, react to them and, in fact, create positive advantages for themselves and the rest of the country. This will result in more Australians being employed in more effective jobs, which will produce better opportunities on the world markets. There is a need right now for the Government to rethink its strategy. Yesterday, the Senate carried a motion in favour of the Government immediately bringing down a mini-Budget to consider these problems. Certainly we in the Liberal and National parties urge that course.
It is now with the greatest of pleasure that I move:
At end of motion, add ``but the Senate:
(a) notes that a thorough analysis of Australia's contribution to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is long overdue;

(b) further notes that in future, the Australian Government should take a more active role in the forum of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, to explain this country's growing concerns with the Bank's management and direction, and to convey the message that a more efficient utilisation of the Bank's existing resources must eventuate before further contributions to its capital base will be provided;
(c) bearing in mind the fact that through the Bank Australia presumes to assist other economies:
(i) expresses alarm at the Hawke Government's lack of concern or urgency in addressing Australia's emerging economic crisis, which is evident to all but the out of touch Mr Keating and Mr Hawke;
(ii) further expresses concern at the collapse in family living standards since 1983, caused by a drop in purchasing power of a least $58 per week for families on average earnings;
(iii) urges the Hawke Labor Government to adopt policies to restore incentive to individuals to work and save, and to create job opportunities for their fellow Australians; and

(iv) condemns the Hawke Labor Government for its abject failure to implement change in vital areas of the economy such as the labor market, shipping and the waterfront, affecting Australia's ability to pay off its debts, raise living standards and compete on world markets''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (General Capital Increase) Bill. The purpose of this Bill, to reiterate the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), is to obtain parliamentary approval for Australia to take up part of its allocated share subscription to the third general capital increase of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD). As has been mentioned, the IBRD is one of the arms of the World Bank. The IBRD borrows on commercial terms from the international capital market and lends money to developing countries at an interest rate which gives it a small margin over its cost for administrative expenses.

SPEECH.PARA: Consequently, the Australian Democrats support this Bill. In addition, we urge the Government to take up Australia's full share entitlement. We believe that this is particularly important in the light of Third World debt and the drying up of funds to the developing world from commercial banks and other official bilateral assistance, including Australia's own development assistance and aid. We also urge the Government to play a much more active role in the forums of the IBRD and other affiliates of the World Bank. More information about the bank, including the many unclassified World Band documents that the bank provides to member country bureaucracies, should be made much more freely available to the Australian public by this Government.

In bank forums we wish Australia's representatives to pursue questions to do with the effectiveness of bank programs to alleviate poverty, prevent environmental degradation, and to take into account the views and needs of indigenous peoples. I reiterate that these are concerns that are held by many members of this Parliament and of this chamber in particular. I acknowledge here the response of the World Bank to those concerns, as indicated in its annual report of last year. We want Australia's representative at the World Bank to continue to promote these areas of endeavour, and to support and monitor the bank's efforts. To this purpose we propose an amendment to the motion for the second reading expressing these sentiments. Since Senator Messner has already moved an amendment to the motion for the second reading, I foreshadow that particular amendment if Senator Messner's amendment is not carried.

Given these particular concerns, the Democrats wish for greater information to be provided for the Parliament about Australia's participation in the bank and Australia's views of the effectiveness of the bank. We thus propose an amendment in the committee stage of this debate to secure more comprehensive annual reporting to Parliament, particularly in relation to the concerns that I have just noted. We do not believe that there is sufficient detail in the present annual reporting to Parliament of Australian participation in the International Monetary Fund, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which we are debating at the moment, as required under the International Monetary Agreements Act 1947.

We believe that the framework of this debate concerns the problems of development in the Third World and the response of the World Bank to those particular concerns. I must admit that I was extremely disappointed with Senator Messner's contribution, which did not pick up the substance of this debate, which I believe is vitally important. Instead, he concentrated on issues of our own economic concern and left aside the larger debate. This is extremely disappointing and presumably means that the Liberal and National parties do not wish to contribute to that broader discussion.

If we are to look at this issue, we should be looking at the share increase to the IBRD. It is fairly obvious that we should distinguish this from other affiliates of the World Bank, such as the International Development Association (IDA), which provides concessional loans. It raises money through grants from developed member governments and makes loans at nominal interest rates to poorer countries. The other arm, the International Finance Corporation, unlike the other two arms, invests mostly in privately-owned enterprises in developing countries. Australia is a member of all these three arms of the World Bank-the IBRD, the IDA and the IFC. Australia is not, however, a member of the latest arm of the World Bank-the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency, which was established last year. It was intended to increase the level of foreign investment in developing countries by guaranteeing investments against losses resulting from non-commercial risk. The nice thing about that, to put it in layman's terms, is that we are not actually going to go into an agency whose major concern is to compensate multinational companies when their activities have managed to create an overthrow of the government in those particular countries.

Let me focus again on the proposed share increase to the IBRD. The third general capital increase sought by the IBRD will allow it to expand its borrowing on world capital markets, and so increase its level of development assistance to more than $20 billion a year. The Australian Government is entitled to subscribe to an additional 10,734 shares. The Government has decided that Australia will subscribe to 7,880 shares. This is estimated to cost about $A35.65m between 1988-89 and 1992-93. The Government has not decided whether to take up the option of the additional shares.
At this stage, I note the sentiments contained in the coalition's amendment to the motion for the second reading. It states:
. . . a more efficient utilisation of the Bank's existing resources must eventuate before further contributions to its capital base will be provided;

The Democrats will not be supporting that amendment because we believe that those views are off target. First, the coalition seems to be saying that the IBRD is the World Bank. As I have noted, it is only one of its arms. Secondly, there is nothing in the literature about the Bank that suggests that it is an inefficient organisation in financial and narrow economic terms. It is, in fact, a very sophisticated, commercial operation. A very interesting article published in the Economist states:
Judged purely as a money manager, the bank . . . beats the pants off most of Wall Street.

I think that the focus of this debate over the IBRD and other affiliates of the World Bank is not their efficiency in those particular terms but, rather, the appropriateness of the development philosophy.

Finally, and most importantly, withholding further contributions to the bank is the last thing that one would want, given the decline of investment by commercial banks in the developing world, the decline of government to government bilateral assistance, and the growing Third World debt. I think the words of the Prime Minister of India, Rajiv Gandhi, explain well the results of these changes. At an international conference in Delhi in March last year, he said:

About 25 billion dollars are being channelled every year from the developing to the developed (countries) in the form of a reverse flow of resources. The most heavily indebted countries find themselves diverting to debt repayment more than half the value of their mercantile exports and close to 5 per cent of their gross domestic product. Developing countries face serious shortages of finance to manage their balance-of-payments problems and meet their requirements of development. Yet, sources of development assistance are drying up . . . It is a sad comment on the inequity and inefficiency of the current order that developing countries are, in effect, financing the developed.

According to the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau submission to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, the Australian Government must share some of the responsibility for this absurd situation. Official government development assistance and aid has dropped from about 0.56 per cent of gross domestic product to 0.36 per cent in the three years to 1988. The Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development said that no other member country had ever reduced aid volume so dramatically. Clearly, increased investment through a capital increase at the IBRD of the World Bank will help redress the international problem. The Democrats, therefore, support this Bill. Furthermore, we urge the Australian Government to take up its full share entitlement as a step towards reversing the decline in Australia's aid and development assistance efforts.

At this point I believe that it would be worth while to indicate our support for the concept of a new multilateral debt management agency that would buy the discounted Third World debt now being sold by commercial banks. The agency would pass on that discount to debtor countries, thereby allowing them to restructure their debt. This would give their economies some breathing space. It would be appropriate if such an agency, with members and financial contributions from developed countries, were associated with the World Bank. We urge Australia to promote such an idea in the international financial fora.

Returning to the proposed share increase that is before us in this Bill, I would like to reply to those who have argued publicly that this will cost too much. I point out that taking up a share entitlement that allows the IBRD to increase its borrowings and, hence, development assistance does not mean that Australia must buy each and every one of those shares it elects to take up. A distinction must be made between paid-in capital-money that governments actually provide to the bank-and callable capital; that is, funds that member governments promise to provide if the bank ever needs to service its debts. As far as Australia is concerned, of the total proposed share increase a mere 3 per cent will be the paid-in portion of $35m-that is the immediate financial cost to Australia-while the other 97 per cent represents callable shares. Of course, these shares are a contingent liability which the Government must take into account but it is highly unlikely that such a contingency would fall due. If it happened the bank obviously would have to be, to all practical intents and purposes, in receivership.

However, this callable capital gives the bank the ability to borrow much larger sums in the financial markets and it provides those financial markets with the security which is necessary. On that basis we believe that the relatively small financial contribution, in terms of paid-in shares by Australia, will multiply the IBRD's development assistance many times because of the presence of the complementary callable shares. I think it is important for the Government to make that distinction known to the Australian public because I do not think it is well understood in the aid debate generally.

If we took up our full share entitlement it would give us increased leverage and influence in the policies and programs of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development since our voting rights in the IBRD are in proportion to our shareholding. However, as I said in another debate last year on the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (Share Increase) Bill, it is not evident whether Australia has used the leverage available to it, through its representatives on the bank's board of executive directors in Washington, to look at that development philosophy that I referred to previously. Like other major shareholders, Australia has a right to shape policies for management but, in the absence of contrary information from the Government-of course, we have a massive dearth of information-one must assume that Australia is content simply to play a passive role in that institution. The Democrats would want Australia's representatives to have a much more active involvement-an involvement which has been aired by politicians from all parties in this Parliament over the last few years.

In the last few years in particular, two letters have been sent to the President of the World Bank calling on the bank to focus more on poverty alleviation and the prevention of environmental degradation. Both letters have been signed by more than 100 members of all political parties in this Parliament. Of course, similar letters have been sent by other legislatures, in particular those of Canada, the United Kingdom and the United States of America. Interestingly enough, I believe that the World Bank has been responding to the concerns of members of legislatures around the world. Let us look, for example, at two recent bank documents. I cite in particular The World Bank's Support for the Alleviation of Poverty, published in June 1988 and Environment and Development: Implementing the World Bank's New Policies, published in July last year. One can see that those concerns which have been expressed around the world have hit home and that the bank is now cognisant of those types of concerns. We want Australia to support, encourage and further develop the bank's efforts in this regard and to monitor the effectiveness of the bank's efforts to pursue those three major prongs.

Let us look at each of those three items-poverty alleviation, environmental degradation and the problem associated with indigenous people which is the item the World Bank has not yet responded to in a formal sense. The statistics of extreme poverty on this planet must lead one to a massive amount of concern. Previously Senator Messner was talking about our concerns in the Australian context. How much more would one be concerned in the world context? The following quote from the World Bank's document I think is as good as any:

It is probable that more than 900 million people now live in absolute poverty-a condition of malnutrition, illiteracy, disease, short life expectancy, and high rates of infant mortality. Although no part of the developing world is spared these problems, perhaps a little more than half these poor people live in Asia and a third in Sub-Saharan Africa.

We might become ashamed when we actually compare this with military expenditure on this planet. According to American economist Ruth Sivard, the world's annual military budget equals the income of 2.6 billion people in the 44 poorest countries. Poor country governments cannot be excused because they are guilty of excessive military expenditure in many of their efforts. The 1985 United Nations report on the world social situation indicates that at least four of the 20 countries with the largest foreign debt imported arms amounting to 40 per cent or more of their debt. Those are extraordinary figures. Already impoverished countries are spending up to 40 per cent on further military imports.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Northern Territory: Economy-Pension Overpayment-People in Custody: Deaths-Tariff on Lightweight Woollen Cloth

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to make some specific comments about the economy of the Northern Territory and, in particular, the Federal Labor Government's support for that economy, or perhaps I should say `the lack of support' that brings on a decent and general acceptance of what is required. Some honourable senators will recall that in last night's adjournment debate when I raised issues connected with airports at Darwin and Alice Springs I met with a very sensitive, vitriolic and personal attack from my Territory Senate colleague, Senator Collins. One can always tell from Senator Collins's reaction when something hurts or embarrasses him because he responds with a vicious attack.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I shall be more specific and talk about the economy of the Northern Territory, what stage it is at and the important contribution that the Commonwealth must make to continuing that economic stability. It was pleasing today, finally, to get the acknowledgment from the Federal Airports Corporation that target dates would be put on the airports at Darwin and Alice Springs. As I said last night, it has been a long time coming. There has been some five years of lapsed promises and constant renegotiations. Whilst Senator Collins said last night that he has had a difficult time over the last two years, I would say that the Government should look at its history over the five-year period. We will certainly keep this Government to its commitments on these target dates-that is, that commencement will take place no later than 1 November this year and that the airports will be open for business by 30 June 1992.

We will certainly file away those strong commitments and remind the Government, as part of the Budget process, of them. I cannot help but be reminded that in August last year when Senator Collins and Mr Snowdon gave a personal commitment to these projects they said that the airports would be operational within three years. Three years from last August has now slipped to an additional year in today's announcement and the airports will not now be open for business until 30 June 1992. So in the space of that 12-month period, the completion dates and the commitment of the members has already slipped an additional 12 months.

As Senator Collins said last night, the capital underpinning of this $90m worth of capital works projects is terribly important to the Northern Territory economy. The Northern Territory's economy has gone through a very difficult period, just as the Australian economy has. However, the Territory economy has improved and is showing a strengthening. This has been reflected in some good results in the last couple of years. I believe that that has been because of the dedication of the Northern Territory Government and its management of the economy in the face of these very difficult Federal times, Federal funding and the stimulus that has been given by the private sector in the Northern Territory. Population growth, particularly in Darwin, did dip for some time, but in the last year it has shown signs of improving. The labour market is also increasing significantly. The Darwin inflation rate is currently the lowest of all the capital cities. That reflects a lot on what is going on.

Tourism, building and mineral exploration are areas that are being stimulated by the private sector. It is good to see that there is encouragement in that respect. The growth in exports stems largely from oil and gas production. In the local community there has been an additional improvement in the building industry, especially housing. We have seen increases in the number of building approvals. These are terribly important economic overviews in that area. This has occurred in the face of a very strong decreasing real change in commitment to the Northern Territory by the Federal Labor Government. In fact, since it has been in office Commonwealth funding to the Northern Territory has dropped by 17 per cent-that is over the past five years. The significance of that is appreciated when one bears in mind that approximately $1 billion of the Northern Territory Government's funding-that is, $1.5 billion-is generated from the funds, the total payments and the Loan Council borrowings from the Commonwealth. This 17 per cent real change and decrease from the Federal Government over the last five years has had to be managed by the Northern Territory Government in its provision of essential services.

For the first time the Northern Territory Government has been moved, by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), into determining, as far as possible, the same methodology of provision of financing as for the States. This change has induced and produced significant changes to the Territory Budget. We can see that from the time of self-government in 1978 total payments rose continually to the financial year 1984-85 and have fallen steadily since then. The decline has been more significant in the general purpose and capital funds. By any measure, that declining investment in the Northern Territory-I make no apology for saying that it is an investment in the north of Australia, because of what is going on there-has compounded the problems, particularly the economic management problems.

We also need to put into context the Commonwealth's commitment to its own capital works program of development in the Northern Territory where there is economic concern and worry. We are aware that the Government is not honouring its commitments. Whilst Senator Collins and I had a fight yesterday about the commitment and timing that is so necessary for airport developments, we also need to challenge the Commonwealth Government on its slippage of capital works in other important areas, particularly that of defence. It is easy to let defence programs slip. I refer, for example, to the Coonawarra naval base near Darwin. A commitment was given, it is on the program and there is now very real concern that this slippage will amount to millions of dollars over a number of years. The development of stage 2 of Tindal Royal Australian Air Force base near Katherine is also significant. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) intends to open the Tindal base on 31 March and that is a time at which he must give a real commitment to the defence of northern Australia and outline the real programs that he has in place so that the very economic underpinning of the north can go on undaunted. We need no slippage in that area, as we had with airports.

This issue is of major concern to the Master Builders Association of the Northern Territory. It has been unable to get a reasonable commitment from the Federal Labor Government. It comments that the cutbacks in Federal Government expenditure in the current financial year amount to a massive 64 per cent. Whilst some expenditure is being moved off-Budget, such as the airports situation about which we have heard in the last day or so, groups such as the Master Builders Association have a lack of confidence as they know that the Government has got it locked into a certainty for its program and where it is going. It is very important that we do not see further slippages in those areas.

Linking this to the airports issue, I inform the Senate that the radar station No. 2 CRU near Darwin was planned to be complemented by other radar facilities at Port Keats and Tindal. It now appears that the Department of Defence has decided to pick up the one from No. 2 CRU and relocate it at Port Keats. That will be an exercise to save millions of dollars in moving into additional facilities which are necessary and required for northern defence. Again, it reflects on the commitment to capital and civil works programs. Not only is there a defence concern about Darwin not being properly surveilled and looked at from a defence point of view, but again we are seeing the slippage in works programs. A number of people, including leading defence strategists, have claimed very clearly that the movement of the Darwin radar system to Port Keats is purely a money saving exercise by this Government. That is totally unacceptable, not only for defence reasons but also in detecting drug runners and as a backup to search and rescue operations in northern Australia.

At the same time as the Government is undertaking at its Budget review this year, I would ask it to look seriously at the matter of zone allowances for people living in remote areas. The Federal member for the Northern Territory, Warren Snowdon, and I were both present at a meeting with pensioners in Darwin several weeks ago. We were looking at the liabilities and disadvantages suffered by pensioners. Many pensioners are also taxpayers. They have additional income and they are topped up. Pensioners living in remote parts of Australia depend substantially on the $270 zone A taxation allowance for living in remote areas. I had heard around the traps that the Labor Government was out to cut, slash, review or whatever that zone allowance. I challenged Mr Snowdon to tell me whether the Labor Government was intending to do anything to the zone allowance this year. He came straight back with a qualified answer to the effect that yes, it was under review. That $270 for a pensioner is crucial and most important. But it is even more important to an average family living in outback Australia, particularly a family with a dependent spouse and two children. The taxation advantage to that family would be in excess of $1,100. It now appears that that is to be ripped off.

If we look at the issue of support for families we cannot help but see that right across Australia high interest rates, high taxation and high inflation are forcing many young people to weigh up the demands on both mortgages and children-and we know the severe options that people have to face. Furthermore, one has to consider a few of the facts and figures as they relate to families. Disposable income for families is down 30 per cent since 1983, when this Labor Government came into office. The number of households living in poverty is up from 11.5 per cent in 1982-83 to 12.4 per cent in 1985-86. Family allowances are down 36 per cent in real terms, which is quite significant. The dependent spouse rebate for a family with children is down 27 per cent in real terms. The average home repayments, now at $675 a month, is up 93 per cent since March 1983. They are dramatic changes in a period of very high inflation, high interest rates and high taxation. The impost that this is putting on families astounds many people. Late last year the Federal Opposition Leader, John Howard, echoed the sentiments of many home buyers when he said:
Bob Hawke has really become the Prime Minister for `DINKS'-double income, no kids. You cannot afford to have them and buy a house if you're a new home buyer'.
Even the financial world agreed. The Commonwealth Bank's chief manager of retailing banking, Mr Murray Westgarth, warned:
To handle a mortgage you need to put off having a family. Couples once would have thought of having a family at an early age, but that's being put back now.

Basically we need to remember that home ownership is part of the family dream and the family is the fundamental unit in our society. It provides a positive environment in which individuals can develop the most effective means of caring for children and a source of happiness and social support. Unfortunately, the rapid pace of economic and technological change means that relationships, marriages and families are now under more pressure than ever before. It is this pressure and the pressures that have now been induced by the Labor Government that make it so hard on families around Australia.

My task tonight has been to stress that the Labor Government's commitment to northern Australia has waned. In the period since Prime Minister Hawke came to office we have seen a continual depreciation of support for people who live in remote areas of Australia. Whether that applies to groups such as the Northern Territory Government or to individual families who live in these remote areas, the issues must be addressed. They must be addressed urgently and in the next Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to raise an important issue on behalf of a constituent regarding the repayment of an overpayment of service pension between 1980 and 1987. The overpayment was caused by a departmental clerical error that resulted in a failure to adjust the service pension of my constituent in accordance with variations in the constituent's superannuation. The point I wish to make this evening is that the rate of this repayment has been set at such a level that it is putting financial stress on my constituent and his wife, and has also led to the diagnosed stress related illness of his wife. In my opinion there should be no repayment or, at best, it should be over an extended period.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go back in history a little to detail the background of this case. I would have hoped that the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) would listen to my outline of this problem, because it is a very serious one. It is a little distressing to find that the Minister has now suddenly occupied Black Rod's seat in the chamber. This is a very important subject and I would like the Minister to comment on it at the end of the adjournment debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know what it is all about.

—I do not know how the Minister could know because he has not been listening, he has been playing games. To return to the history of this matter, the rate of service pension is dependent upon the rate of superannuation. That rate is adjusted automatically by the Department of Veterans' Affairs, based upon information provided to that Department by the Minister responsible for the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund, more recently known as the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office. Again, the Minister is not listening. If he were to find himself in the position of my constituent, I am sure that he would want someone who has the ability to fix this matter to pay some attention. The Minister cannot even sit in his place. This is getting a little beyond a joke.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. Unlike other senators, I am capable of doing two things at one time. I have been following what Senator Knowles has been contributing to the debate. She might as well keep on going, make her point, and I shall take it up in the proper way.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr President. I am sorry that the Minister raised that smart alec point of order because the information I am providing is particularly serious. The information to which I have referred is based upon details supplied to the Department by the Minister with responsibility for the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund, now known as the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office. That information is supplied on computer tape. The constituent was regularly required to complete an income statement upon which appears a declaration of the correctness of various particulars set out therein and an acknowledgment of the obligation to advise the Department of any change in particulars.

SPEECH.PARA: During 1980 a clerical error was made by the Department of Veterans' Affairs which resulted in my constituent ceasing to be noted as a superannuation recipient. As a consequence of that the periodic information supplied to the Department by which the pension was automatically varied in accordance with variations in Commonwealth superannuation ceased to be applied to my constituent's entitlement. As a result, the Department failed to make any adjustment in the service pension until the error was discovered seven years later in 1987. I remind the Senate that this came about through a clerical error made by the Department of Veterans' Affairs, not by the constituent, and there was no desire whatsoever by my constituent to defraud the system. He had quite willingly, up until the time the Department ceased sending him the forms, completed those forms and sent them back. But it is my understanding that adjustments in the service pension of recipients such as my constituent are consequent upon changes in the rate of Commonwealth superannuation and are actuated by information passing between the Commonwealth bodies rather than information from the recipients.

The effect of the error made by the Department is, of course, in this case a cumulative one. In the first year the error resulted in a relatively minimal change in the total income received by the recipient. However, with each successive year the rate of change was similar and over a period of seven years the accumulated difference between the proper entitlement and the sum being paid by the Commonwealth is significant. In fact, that amount was in excess of $6,000. I might add that, while the amount is quite significant to pensioners in this instance, it is quite insignificant in comparison with the amounts involved in the cases of those people who quite willingly defraud the system and get far better treatment than this couple are currently getting.

The Commonwealth superannuation of which my constituent was in receipt was, during the period from 1980 to 1987, regularly increased in accordance with changes in the consumer price index (CPI). During the period within which my constituent's service pension was not adjusted corresponding to the changes in the Commonwealth superannuation payment, he may have perceived a periodic increase in his total income from pension and superannuation corresponding roughly to increases in the CPI. The Minister, in one response to the constituent, said that the constituent should have recognised the difference and notified the Department. In all seriousness I do not believe that many aged pensioners are true financial wizards who can distinguish one rise from another, particularly those who are not seeking in any way to defraud the system and simply trust the system to deliver exactly what they are entitled to.

It is well established in correspondence that the Department of Veterans' Affairs received information, in the form of the computer tapes to which I referred earlier, relating to variations in the superannuation entitlement as a basis for adjusting the service pension. I therefore submit that a person with no income other than the Commonwealth payments, being aware of the fact that adjustments are automatically effected, would not readily assume that the total responsibility rested with him to ensure that the Commonwealth failed to make any errors in relation to his payment. This couple have really been penalised because, as I said before, they trusted the system and were unaware that they in fact had to be a check on the system instead of the situation that applied prior to that where the system was a check on them. Many other pensioners do not sign the declaration, such as this couple did, which obliges the pensioner to notify the Department. I suppose, in hindsight, my constituent's mistake is that he thought that he was doing what everyone else did and that it was obligatory.

All correspondence currently available contains consistent errors in the emphasis placed upon these circumstances by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. One example of such an error is in the final sentence of a letter from the Minister dated 24 May 1988 in which he states:
. . . consequently, any service pension which was incorrectly paid as a result of failure to notify changes is a debt to the Commonwealth and must be repaid.

I suggest that the statement is simply wrong. The service pension was incorrectly paid as a result of an error by the Department, not a failure of the constituent to notify changes. It was not his fault. It has been declared that it was the Department's fault. My constituent's recognition of that error may have halted that error earlier and relieved him of the stress of the present situation; however, it can in no way be said to have caused the incorrect payment.

I further submit that it is neither necessary nor realistic for the Department to approach my constituent's case on the basis of guidelines which may have little or no relevance to his circumstances. Whilst a lot can be said about the obligation to advise and the nature of the declarations made, the reality of the situation is that the adjustment of the total pension income was a matter that should have correctly taken place based upon the system for adjustment which is maintained by the agencies in question. I suppose this really begs the question: If the Department has made this error, how many more errors has it made for the same reasons but for a greater value, or even a lesser value for that matter?

When the Department forwarded the form to my constituent it was duly filled out, signed and returned. I believe, therefore, that it cannot be realistically suggested that he be held culpable to any material degree for failing to recognise and subsequently alert the Department to the gradual changes in his entitlement which he had no way of knowing were not just CPI increases or would place him in the position in which he now finds himself of serious financial liability.

I recognise that the repayments have already been reduced from $84 each per fortnight to $30 each per fortnight. Nonetheless, $60 per fortnight to an elderly couple is a lot of money, particularly when it comes on top of an additional loss of income in the form of the reduced pension. I ask the Minister to consider the question of repayment by my constituent and his wife, based upon his particular facts. He is 74 years of age and his wife is approximately the same age. They are of most moderate means, with only the part service pension and the small superannuation. In order to repay the total debt claimed by the Commonwealth, each of their pensions has been reduced by $30 per fortnight for some four years. At this time of life such a period of indebtedness brought about through no real fault of theirs is a severe penalty.

The effect of the present reduction of service pension payable is, in general terms, a far greater hardship than the largely unrecognised benefit that was received over a period of some seven years. Once again, I remind the Senate that it has to be repaid over four years, not over the seven years that it took to accumulate-nor over the longer periods applying to people who have quite willingly defrauded the system. Some such people pay back a couple of dollars over 10, 20 or 30 years. This fellow did not try to defraud the system, and yet he is being penalised by a reduction in pension of $60 per fortnight over four years. The level of reduction of the pension itself continues to be relatively substantial, considering that the total weekly pension and superannuation income of both people together is only $251.07. I challenge the Minister, or anyone else in this place for that matter, to try as part of a couple to live on $251 a week. The present rate of payment from the meagre weekly income referred to constitutes a significant financial penalty.

The total effect upon this couple of the recognition and correction of the Department's error is enormous. In the first place, his and his wife's pensions have been reduced to the correct level. In addition, the substantial further reduction of $30 per week has been effected. If they are to continue to have deducted from their pensions repayments of the overpayment claimed by the Commonwealth at the present rate, I suggest that it is inequitable for such an impost to be maintained for the full period which would be required in order to repay the whole of the sum in question. I therefore ask the Minister for a review of the case with a view to a write-off, as a result of a bona fide error. There are circumstances on the basis of which the Department does that, and I cannot understand why this has not been done on this occasion. Alternatively, at the minimum, there should be a reduction of the present rate of repayment or a substantial increase in the period over which the repayment is to be made.

I do not think anyone in this Parliament would be so bold as to suggest that pensioners in Australia are on any great gravy train or live a life of luxury. As I have said, this couple certainly live a very modest lifestyle and are concerned, honest Australians. I saw this gentleman a few weeks ago. I have subsequently spoken to him on the telephone. I can testify to the fact that he is a very sincere person. I can also testify to the fact that he is a very concerned person. Having gone through his details over the last couple of weeks, I can certainly understand why he is so concerned.

I believe that the case I have detailed here tonight needs the Minister's further consideration, as it was not this gentleman's fault that the Department made the error in the first place. All he and I are really seeking is a fair go which would enable him and his wife to live without hardship. The Minister also stated the following in one of his letters:
If the recoverable overpayment can be repaid by a person then the options of write-off or waiver cannot be taken by a delegate.

That is probably quite true. However, I contend that the delegate cannot make a decision outside the guidelines. The Minister certainly can, however, particularly in extreme circumstances. There are sufficient precedents for action to be taken in this case. As I have said, many other people have willingly and intentionally received money under false circumstances. I think that my constituents should be given the consideration that they deserve as honest Australian citizens. I trust that the Minister will look sympathetically at this case and act accordingly and quickly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Muirhead Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody has justifiably focused much attention on the cell deaths of Aboriginal Australians who are alleged to have hanged themselves. The media point of view has been that the majority of the deaths are of this nature. However, in my home State of Western Australia this is definitely not true. There is grave concern about the number of deaths in custody of both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians and about the high imprisonment rate of both. The high imprisonment rates of Aboriginal Australians are a cause of particular concern. The statistics I will now cite cover the period from 1 January 1980 to the present. Of a total of 73 cell deaths in Western Australia, 25 were allegedly self-inflicted. Of these, seven were Aboriginal hangings. Of the 10 hangings in prison, one was an Aboriginal, and of the 13 hangings in police lockups, six were Aboriginal. The remaining two deaths were the result of slashing and an overdose. The first case was an Aboriginal death and the second case a non-Aboriginal death.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to detract in any way from the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, which is exposing to the public view the horrific happenings behind the closed doors of our penal institutions. Without the Australia-wide public uproar from the Aboriginal people, this Royal Commission would never have received its letters patent. But the time has come for the whole of the population to make its voice heard to obtain better conditions for all those still incarcerated in our mental institutions, prisons and lockups. The neglect of prisoner health and welfare in these places of imprisonment is a national shame. Conditions and attitudes that horrified our ancestors in the last century have not changed to this day. I seek leave, Mr President, to table figures and graphs which have been extracted by researcher Jennifer Searcy, whose son Nicholas died of encephalitis.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you Mr President. Nicholas Searcy was a victim of medical help being denied. As an example of an unnecessary and tragic prison death, I would like to tell the Senate Nicholas's story and of the callous treatment meted out to him. Nicholas, a brilliant scholar-he had qualified for medicine at the age of 14, becoming the youngest holder of a technical and further education diploma in applied science-a poet, musician and sculptor, was an honours chemistry student and graduate research worker at a Perth University. In late 1986, when rushing to get medical help for a severe burn, he was arrested for driving while under suspension and was subsequently gaoled for the minimum mandatory term of one month. He was jailed for the minimum mandatory term of one month which, less remissions, was 17 days. He was to serve his sentence in Canning Vale Prison and entered that institution on Friday, 13 December, as a fit and healthy young man.

SPEECH.PARA: On Sunday, 21 December, on the ninth day of his imprisonment, Nicholas was very, very sick and in great pain, unable to eat and hardly able to walk. Such was his distress that when taken to the visitors room to see his fiancee he had to leave and return to bed. As he left the visiting area he staggered visibly for all to see. During the night Nicholas was reported by a prisoner in the next cell as crying in agony and sounding as if he was having a fit. He told the warders of this at the time, but they just walked away, leaving Nicholas moaning with pain. Another prisoner told the warders on the Monday morning that Nicholas was very ill and that he had not been drinking, but the warders took no notice and placed him in an observation cell for disciplinary reasons. He was so ill he could not report sick for himself and the warders had decided he was either drunk or drugged. This was later totally disproved. It is an undisputed medical fact that drunkenness with severe loss of coordination cannot last more than six hours at most without further consumption of alcohol. He was kept in solitary confinement until finally being sent to Fremantle Hospital in chains on the following Tuesday, at which time he had five days of his sentence to run and only 12 days to live.

In all probability, this young man's illness became irreversible in the period from the Sunday to the Tuesday. Despite Nicholas's being mortally ill and physically unable to move off the bed, as well as being guarded by a warder at all times, the Acting Superintendent of Canning Vale Prison insisted that the young man remain chained to the bed. All this time Nicholas was tossing in his delirium with the chain painfully pulling against his leg. The doctor protested that he could not properly treat so seriously ill a patient while he remained shackled. Nicholas's mother pleaded with the Acting Superintendent to remove the chains but she was told to go to a higher authority. Because it was obvious that Nicholas might die, Mrs Searcy could not leave him and asked the then chairman of the Christian Justice Association, the Reverend David Robinson, to act on her behalf in this matter. Reverend Robinson approached the Western Australian Attorney-General, Joe Berinson, who said he would consider the matter but procrastinated for two days before yielding to the insistence of the medical specialist.

Nicholas died on 4 January 1987. There is very much more. But these points alone tell a story of a disgraceful treatment of a young man with a deadly illness while in prison on a driving charge. The reason given for chaining him to the hospital bed was that he was said to be a medium security risk. At the coronial inquest no evidence was given supporting the assertion that a person in jail for a minor offence, with no record of escape attempts, and with only a few days left to serve, was any sort of security risk. I shudder to think of all the others who, like Nicholas, are incarcerated for whatever reason and are subjected to such malicious, brutal and uncaring treatment.

This abuse of prisoners is not unique to Western Australia but appears to be fairly standard in most States, as is indicated by the recent case of Malcolm Hatch, aged 21, who died on 18 July last year as a result of custody in New South Wales. Malcolm died of meningitis after transfer from Cessnock Gaol to Prince Henry Hospital, Sydney. His infections were bacterial and could have been responsive to timely treatment by antibiotics. There are certain facts that demand explanation. Although fellow prisoners at Cessnock Gaol had claimed that Malcolm Hatch had complained of long term severe headaches, the first record was on Sunday, 3 July, when the headache was diagnosed as flu and he was given aspirin. Six days later, on Saturday, 9 July, Malcolm phoned his family and told them he had terrible headaches but was not allowed to see a doctor. On the next day, Sunday, 10 July, the young man collapsed but still a doctor was not called. On Monday 11 July, Malcolm was transferred to the medical unit at Long Bay Jail and then to Prince Henry Hospital where he was immediately placed on a life support system. Malcolm's mother travelled from Queensland to be with her son but he did not regain consciousness and died on Monday, 18 July, 1988. The autopsy was delayed until Friday, 22 July. Infection cannot be reliably identified after 36 hours at the outside.

Two sharp questions need to be asked: Firstly, who chose to deprive him of treatment for so long, and why? Secondly, who chose to delay the autopsy, and why? The answers must be forthcoming. The relevant Ministers must take action to ensure that the barbaric practice of condoning denial of medical help to prisoners ceases forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the Senate's time briefly-it is an opportunity I will probably never get again-to comment on the recent decision to remove the 40 per cent tariff on lightweight woollen cloth, which is sometimes called `cool wool'. The removal of this silly tax, as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) called it, will allow the fashion garment industry once again to use this unique cloth and not to have the unfair competition from lightweight cotton and synthetic material.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Wool Corporation, with the help of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and its own research, has developed techniques for producing lightweight woollen cloths of exceptional quality. It has allowed overseas mills to produce printed materials that are as delicate as silk and as colourful as any fabrics ever produced. The fashion industry in Australia has designers with unique talents who will now be able to purchase the best cloth in the world and produce garments that will compete with the best fashion houses in the world. The people of Australia will once again be able to purchase world quality clothing at a more reasonable price.

It has always seemed ludicrous to me, when we have a Wool Corporation spending many millions of dollars on wool promotion and the Government contributing to it something like $33m annually, that the Government would see fit to impose a tariff that would torpedo the promotional efforts of the Wool Corporation that it has already invested in. Those honourable senators who may have seen the Bicentennial Wool Parade or the recent Australian Wool Collection that took place at Darling Harbour would appreciate how lightweight woollen cloths are the showpiece or centrepiece of our promotional activities with wool. Why then would a government try to impede the wonderful marketing exercise that the Australian Wool Corporation is carrying out? The only answer I have is that it must have been an oversight, a mistake or an anomaly. For better or worse, it has been removed, so my congratulations to those responsible for correcting this mistake are forthcoming. Let us hope it has not damaged the industry too much and that once again confidence will be returned.

Early last year this matter was brought to my attention by a Mrs Wallis, a fashion consultant with the Australian Wool Corporation. As a result of that, I conducted a survey of garment manufacturers who were using lightweight wools. The results were quite alarming. The changeover from wool to synthetics and the reduction in the use of wool was quite significant. It was disappointing to me as a woolgrower to see manufacturers losing confidence in the `cool wool' promotion that the Australian Wool Corporation had spent so much time and money developing.

The collated results of my survey were made available to the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority, the Australian Wool Corporation, Mr Kerin's office, and also to the office of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). I hope they were helpful in assisting the Government in its decisions. I go on record as thanking all of those who participated so willingly in the survey, and I hope that their confidence in the industry has returned.

Once again, I commend the Government for its commonsense approach. As far as this situation is concerned, I sum up by quoting the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, who in reply to this decision said:

Hopefully, Australian designers will now pick up the very best lightweight woollen fabrics, from wherever they're made and make clothes out of them here so we in Australia can wear the very best of our own product.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will say just a few words in summing up. In respect to Senator Tambling's contribution, I do not think anyone needs to say any more than to acknowledge it as a political speech based very much in rhetoric and fantasy rather than fact. With respect to Senator Knowles's speech, there are a couple of points she raised which I will definitely bring to the attention of the relevant Minister. In doing so, however, I wish to alert Senator Knowles to a number of decisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in areas similar to this in the Social Security portfolio which may assist her in pursuing that matter as well. In terms of the responsibilities of clients as opposed to Government departments in this area, these decisions might be useful to her.

SPEECH.PARA: The matters raised by Senator Jenkins obviously are ones that affect people who have been listening to the debate, and I will raise them with Senator Tate who has some indirect responsibility in this area. As to Senator Calvert, I say, on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), that it is good to see someone from the Opposition recognising some good.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 November 1988 (Hansard, page 2892), Senator Durack asked me, inter alia, as the Minister representing the Attorney-General, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (i) how many of the 500 or so individual files which have been opened by the Special Investigations Unit, as disclosed in evidence to Senate Estimates committees, have resulted in police calling on suspects, and how many statements have been obtained from these people by this method?
(ii) have Australian Federal Police officers explained to these people the origin of the allegations and the fact that the War Crimes Bill has not yet been passed by the Parliament?
(iii) have the police explained carefully to these people their rights under existing law in regard to answering question?

(iv) in light of the evidence that is now available about the number of people who have been questioned, why has a spokesman for the Attorney-General, as reported in the Age on Wednesday, denied as `absolute nonsense' that any such visits have taken place?
The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The first 3 questions were dealt with comprehensively in the course of debate on the war crimes legislation. I refer the Honourable Senator to pp. 4468-4470 and 4498-4503 of the Senate Hansard of 19 December 1988.

In relation to the last question I understand that the description of `absolute nonsense' applied to the term `interrogation' and not to the fact that interviews had taken place. As is clear from the Hansard record, such interviews do not and have not constituted `interrogations' as that term is generally understood.
